proctext.para: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: â€”Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

petition.title: Hail Mary
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned in the State of Queensland respectfully showeth that the film `Hail Mary' is blasphemous and gravely offends our religious beliefs and those of the vast majority of Australian Christians.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Parliament will respect the will of the undersigned and have the blasphemous film `Hail Mary' banned in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Chirita Family
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.

The petition of the undersigned shows: Your petitioners, as in duty bound, will humbly pray that a public inquiry be conducted for the migration of the Chirita family, (father) Marin Chirita and (fiance) Marc Codruta to be allowed into Australia and that the rights of Ion Chirita be recognised in Queensland.

petition.title: Bill of Rights Legislation
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows: The we urge you to oppose the Australian Bill of Rights because:
This Bill does not guarantee vital rights such as:
The right to own your own home and other property and not be deprived of it without just compensation.
The right to insulate our children from radical forms of education and the right to choice of schools.
The right to a referendum for constitutional amendments.
The right to true freedom of speech.
The Bill gives dangerous, unlimited powers to an unelected Human Rights Commission with no appeal, no legal representation and closed hearings.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should vote to reject the Bill, believing that such a Bill should only be determined by the people at a referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: National Flag
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. The present Australian national flag is not distinctively and uniquely Australian and is confused with other national flags.
2. The people of Australia have never had an opportunity to express their views on an appropriate Australian national flag in a referendum.
3. The present Australian national flag does not properly represent Australia as a sovereign, independent nation.
4. The present Australian national flag falsely proclaims Australia as a colony, homeland, protectorate, dominion or government department of Great Britain.
5. The first condition in the flag competition of 1901 required that the design should show Australia's loyalty to the British Empire. The British Empire no longer exists.
6. A public opinion poll held in 1984 using the Gallup Method revealed that 52% of Australians surveyed wanted a competition for a new design for the Australian flag.
7. There is no inherent link between Australia proclaiming a unique and distinctive flag and the political issue of Australia moving to a republican form of government.
8. The adoption of a truly Australian national flag would serve as a focal point for Australia's bicentennial celebrations in 1988.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable house will:
(a) Appoint a Committee of the Parliament with representatives from both Houses and all parties to invite and consider proposals for the design of a new Australian national flag, and

(b) Require that committee to make recommendations on the form of a minimum cost referendum at the time of the next general elections, in which the electors will be given the opportunity to vote for a flag from a selection of at least three designs which will include the present national flag and the winner of the Ausflag-Bulletin-2MMM.FM competition of March 1985.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Bill of Rights Legislation
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we oppose utterly the proposed Bill of Rights because this Bill will
Restrict our rights to those listed in the Bill
Transfer to government powers not given nor intended to be given by the Constitution
Threaten our rights by making them subject to the will of this or any future Government
Turn the Human Rights Commission into a political Star Chamber with unjustifiable power
Abrogate Common Law and common liberty
Set the State above the individual
We the undersigned believe in democracy and freedom and earnestly entreat you to recognise that this Bill will undermine the fundamental basis of these.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should reject the Bill of Rights.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Bill of Rights Legislation
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we deplore the Bill of Rights because it adversely affects areas of the liberty and freedom of Australians. It will operate against:
The States and our Federal system of Government
Criminal Justice
The Police
Education
Families
Employer/Employee relations

It will remove the power of the people through Parliament, by giving power to a new more powerful Human Rights Commission which is not elected, but can act as a Star Chamber. We do most earnestly wish to keep our system of Common Law.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should reject this Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

debate.title: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON TELECOMMUNICATIONS INTERCEPTIONS

interject.speaker: The PRESIDENT

talk.start.para: â€”I have received the following message from the House of Representatives:

interject.para: Message No. 372
MR PRESIDENT,

The House of Representatives transmits to the Senate the following Resolution which was agreed to by the House of Representatives this day, and requests that the Senate concur and take action accordingly:
(1) That a joint select committee be appointed:

(a) to examine and report upon the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill 1986 and, in particular, the appropriateness of the mechanism for conducting interceptions and the safeguards for their authorisation, recording, transcribing, dissemination and retention, and

(b) to examine and report upon the recommendation contained in Mr Justice Stewart's report of the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Alleged Telephone Interceptions to the effect that the power of interception be extended to cover all serious offences.

(2) That the committee consist of 9 members, 3 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by either the Prime Minister, the Leader of the House or the Government Whip, 1 Member of the House of Representatives to be nominated by either the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Leader of Opposition or the Opposition Whip, 1 Member of the House of Representatives to be nominated by either the Leader of the National Party or the National Party Whip, 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the senate, 1 Senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and 1 Senator to be nominated by any minority group or groups or independent Senator or independent Senators.
(3) That every nomination of a member of the committee be forthwith notified in writing to the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives.
(4) That the committee elect a Government member as its chairman.

(5) That the committee elect a deputy chairman who shall perform the duties of the chairman of the committee at any time when the chairman is not present at a meeting of the committee, and at any time when the chairman and deputy chairman are not present at a meeting of the committee, the members present shall elect another member to perform the duties of the chairman at that meeting.
(6) That 4 members of the committee constitute a quorum of the committee.
(7) That the committee have power to send for persons, papers and records, and to move from place to place.
(8) That the committee have leave to report from time to time.
(9) That the committee present its final report as soon as possible.
(10) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the standing orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the standing orders.
SPEAKER
Motion (by Senator Ryan) agreed to:
That consideration of the message in Committee of the Whole be an order of the day for the next day of sitting.

debate.title:
INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT (CAPITAL GAINS) BILL 1986
INCOME TAX (RATES) AMENDMENT (CAPITAL GAINS) BILL 1986

proctext.para: Debate resumed from 4 June, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Knowles Sen S.C.

talk.start.para: â€”We heard some very interesting debate last night on the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill and the Income Tax (Rates) Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill. It is interesting to note that out of 19 speakers on the speakers list only four are from the Australian Labor Party.
â€”Don't you start. We are trying to keep them down at your request.

â€”I have included Senator Siddons in those four speakers because the Australian Democrats, as Senator Hill said yesterday, are the fifth wing of the Labor Party. If Senator Robertson is getting all upset, I suggest he go and take another day off. It is amazing to see the absolute smorgasbord of taxes that this Government has started to dish up to us. In the past year we have seen an entertainment tax, the abolition of negative gearing, a fringe benefits tax, the abolition of the quarantining of farm losses and now we have a capital gains tax. It is really amazing. If anyone is in any doubt as to whether or not we have a socialist Government, the real definition of socialism is where a socia-list government stands for the redistribution of wealth, whereas a conservative government stands for the creation of wealth. At the moment we are seeing a massive assault on the redistribution of wealth.

speech.para: The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has been exposed as one who has little or no regard for his own promises. My colleagues Senator Mess- ner and Senator MacGibbon reminded the Senate last night of the promise that the Prime Minister made prior to the 1983 election, when he said quite emphatically that under his Government there would be no capital gains. So what are we debating today? A capital gains tax? It is worth remembering also, as I mentioned in the fringe benefits tax debate, that the Prime Minister also promised a fairer and simpler tax system. I repeat that this Government has now increased the Income Tax Assessment Act, which was already running at 1,100 pages, by some 350 pages. So much for the promises.

We should be reminded also that the Democrats should not be seen to have their hands clean in any of these Bills, because they were elected originally on the catch cry of `We will keep the bastards honest', meaning that they would keep any government to its promises. The Democrats, too, obviously have short term memories, because all of these taxes, which are contrary to the Government's promises, are being supported by the Democrats. The question that should be asked now is: Who is going to keep the Democrats honest? I am not too sure who will keep the Democrats honest, because they cannot keep themselves honest.

talk.start.para: â€”Because they are in bed with other people.

â€”That is exactly right, they are in bed with other people; they vote with the Labor Government all the time. These Bills are more than just another plank in an anti-free enterprise tax package and involve more than just unfairness or insensitive application. The Liberal Party of Australia believes, firstly, that capital gains tax is wrong in principle, being levied not on income or turnover but in fact on assets. Once the Parliament presumes to tax assets, other than for the most short term of asset gains, it is on a very dangerous path. A capital gains tax belongs in the same stable as death duties and wealth tax. I can say with pride that it was the Liberal Party of Australia under the Fraser Government that saw the scandal of death duties ended at both State and Federal levels. Therefore I can say with equal pride that a future Liberal government would end this unfair capital gains tax as well. These reforms are essential to the future economic wealth of Australians generally and their country. At a time when other Western nations are turning away from a capital gains tax, this bright spark Government in Australia is foisting it on Australians. Last night we heard repeatedly how wonderful it was that other countries had instituted capital gains taxes. Great reference was made also to the United States. But the US has seen capital gains tax rates fall from 35 per cent to 17.5 per cent with a likelihood of further reductions in the near future. Even the New Zealand Labour Government in its taxation scrambling exercise opted against a capital gains tax. But no, not this Australian Government; it goes the full hog.

speech.para: In its pragmatic efforts the Hawke Government has tried to sell these taxes by saying that they will fund tax cuts. But this capital gains tax will not even raise large amounts of revenue. How can the Government ever justify any tax that is wrong in principle? The fact is that after five years this capital gains tax is expected to raise $25m in revenue. By 1991 this will have an effective value of $17m, less than 10 per cent of the amount raised in the current Budget by the bank account debits tax-a tax that in turn constitutes 0.3 per cent of the total revenue of $64 billion received by the Government this financial year. This tax has been introduced simply for political and not economic reasons. Australians are copping this tax which they do not want because the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions feel the need to appease the left wing and those motivated by the politics of envy. The unions and welfare groups made it crystal clear at the National Taxation Summit charade last year that they wanted some kind of punitive tax on capital, so this Government is delivering it. The Government, unions and welfare groups are determined to adopt policies which redistribute wealth in preference to providing incentive for all people to obtain wealth. When I say all people, I mean all people, including middle Australians, and not just the wealthy. This tax will not necessarily affect large wealth creators but will have a most deleterious effect on the small investors and those who rely heavily on a preponderance of small investors.

One of the most important things to remember with this tax is that the Australian economy simply cannot afford it. A Treasurer who believes that we are becoming a banana republic would surely realise that Australia needs more, not less, capital investment. Private business fixed investment rose only 4 per cent in the last financial year after a 10 per cent drop in 1983-84. So far this total investment in plant, equipment and non-dwelling construction in the 1985-86 year has declined in both the September and December quarters. Yet here we are today debating a tax Bill that will discourage capital formation and investment when we have a survey by the National Australia Bank and the Australian Chamber of Commerce of private firms in the tertiary sector which shows the fourth successive quarterly decline in those firms expecting to increase capital expenditure. The private sector is being given absolutely no incentive to invest or create jobs when it now has a fringe benefits tax, increased company tax from 46 per cent to 49 per cent and now a capital gains tax.

The Australian Democrats and Australian Labor Party senators who vote in favour of this legislation should do so in the full knowledge that there has been a steady decline in the real rate of return from business enterprise. In the last decade the real return on private sector funds declined from 10.2 per cent to 9.7 per cent and the advantage enjoyed by these investments over Treasury bonds fell from a difference of 14 per cent to one of 3 per cent. Given all that, this Government believes business can afford yet another assault on its profits. It is worth remembering that governments-especially this Government-do not create wealth; they distribute it. Governments do not take risks to provide initiative for investment capital; they simply make it harder for the private sector to survive. If the Government thinks the private sector will be able to survive with another one of these punitive tax measures, it should think again. Australia already has 600,000 people out of work, with the rate of 15 to 19-year-old unemployment running at 23 per cent, and the average duration of unemployed now stands at 49 weeks as opposed to 35 weeks when this Government took office. It is also interesting to note that the rate of youth unemployment between 15 and 19-year olds has risen since the introduction of the now famous Priority One campaign.

The public sector is the one sector in which employment is growing, and this capital gains tax will certainly ensure that it remains the only sector that is growing. In relation to that public sector growth, I ask honourable senators to think of the number of public servants that will be added to the payroll in the Department of the Treasury to administer all these new taxes. We have a huge trade deficit and the overseas debt of this country has doubled from $35 billion to $70 billion in just three years under the world's greatest Treasurer and this Government. The Treasurer has managed to double that figure. Make no mistakes about it. Australia is in dire financial straits. This situation owes much to the fact that we have too much overseas borrowing and too little overseas investment. This legislation will provide an even greater disincentive to foreign investment capital.

No one should believe for one second that all of these crippling taxes came out of the Keating-Hawke Summit show. These taxes came straight out of a hotel room occupied by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The Prime Minister shot the Treasurer in the foot yet again. It is very interesting that the Government talks about consensus and seeking approval from the business sector, and so on. It completely ignored the private sector last year. There is no point in Senator Robertson shaking his head. He knows that last year that deal was negotiated in a hotel room with the Prime Minister and the trade union movement.

talk.start.para: â€”It is not a fact, and you know it.

â€”It is a fact. The negotiation that was meant to go on with the private sector did not occur. It was all aborted for a lovely little meeting in a hotel room late at night. It is amazing that the Prime Minister can be summoned to a hotel room by the union movement but the union movement was not invited to Parliament House to discuss the issue with him. It is all a little sinister. However, it is worth recalling how cynical this proposal is. On one hand we had the Prime Minister promising not to introduce a capital gains tax; on the other hand the Treasurer, prior to becoming Treasurer, said that he was absolutely opposed to the imposition of a capital gains tax, but after he became Treasurer he sang a very different tune, which went something like this:

speech.para: What you say when you are in opposition at Party conferences, is for the purpose of getting into government. It does not really count once you get in.

There we have the promises of the Prime Minister and the statements and beliefs of the world's greatest Treasurer, who is sending this country down the tube. He has admitted that what one says prior to coming into government bears no relation to what one does when one gets in. Under that philosophy one must ask what will be the fate of the tax cuts supposedly to be introduced later this year. Needless to say, we will be given the same old story by the Government which we got last night ad nauseam-that this Bill will stamp out tax avoidance. That is the Government's predictable fall-back time and time again whenever it is challenged over the effects of this tax on business and on ordinary Australians. It was the Fraser Government in fact that took the steps to stamp out tax avoidance, and not one piece of legislation introduced by this Government goes anywhere near tackling tax avoidance or the cash economy, which is the real tax evasion rip-off in Australia.

This Government is not prepared to bite the bullet on the hard decisions. Instead, with this capital gains tax, it will tax family members on the realisation of their farms and it will tax beneficiaries of a will when the family farm is sold. If that is not a back door death duty, what is? The Government was originally wanting to rip this tax from beneficiaries at the time of death. It decided, in its political wisdom, that that could not happen. This tax hits very hard at middle Australia. We should be reminded that it hits not just the wealthy but also those who are fighting to provide a secure income and future for themselves-people who should be encouraged to invest, grow, take risks, prosper and be self-reliant. There should be more and more people who want to do those things. So much for the attempt of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to dress up this decayed socialist legislation in the language of economic rationalism, claiming that the lack of a capital gains tax distorts investment choices to less productive areas. I submit that this will be the exact consequence of the tax.

Sadly, this capital gains tax has the support of the Australian Democrats and, with their aid, it will, like the fringe benefits tax, become law. This is the epitome of contradiction of the `Trust me' campaign of the Prime Minister and the `Keep the bastards honest' campaign run by the dealing Democrats. A future Liberal government is committed to repealing this draconian legislation and to return incentive to those capable of making Australia what it should be-a wealthy country for those Australians who want to earn a living in it.

speech.speaker: Parer Sen W.R.

talk.start.para: â€”We are discussing today the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986 and the Income Tax (Rates) Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986. These Bills represent a breach, initially, of the principles of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on taxation as reflected in this package. Let us just look at a few of the principles by the Prime Minister at the time. He said that there would be no increase in the overall tax burden. Firstly, we are seeing the promised tax cuts being delayed and, secondly, the cuts are to be paid by inflation or fiscal drag, whatever honourable senators wish to call it. Everyone knows that these tax cuts are phoney tax cuts as we now have new and extra taxes. One of the other principles was what was called `a simpler system'. Let me turn to the Government's White Paper last year before the disastrous National Taxation Summit of July. Under the heading `Simplicity' the White Paper states in words that I think even honourable senators on the other side of the chamber will be able to understand:

speech.para: A good tax system should be as simple as possible. A complex tax system makes it difficult for people to understand the law and apply it to their circumstances. The present law has become so complex that it is difficult to convey its meaning simply and adequately on tax return forms and in other printed matter. Complexity imposes high compliance costs on the community and high administrative costs on the tax authorities. Complex tax laws also result in socially unproductive and costly tax litigation. These considerations suggest that, where possible, tax reform measures capable of ready comprehension and application should be preferred over more complex alternatives.

So much for the simplicity of the system! We have before us 1,100 pages of tax legislation, to which 625 pages have been added. There will be an increase in complexity, not a decrease. It will simply increase the work load of tax lawyers and accountants and become an administrative nightmare for the Australian Taxation Office.

Another principle was that it would not disadvantage welfare beneficiaries. With high interest rates and the abolition of negative gearing we have seen rents skyrocketing and we have a reduced availability of private rental accommodation for those who cannot afford to own their own home. A Hooker survey recently showed that 20 per cent rent increases in some State capitals had come about simply because of these tax packages combined with the higher interest rates which are the result, of course, of the Government's policy. These new measures will hurt those they are meant to help. Another principle was that we must provide the best climate for investment, growth and jobs. As everybody knows, Australia is hungry for capital. At present we have declining jobs, no growth, high interest rates, huge debts, high inflation and low investment. Therefore, business needs every incentive it can get to invest, not obstacles and road blocks in the way of investment.

One of the other major points raised at the same time was widespread community support. With this total package of Bills, what a joke that is. At the moment we have a tax revolt on our hands which I do not think we have seen the size of anywhere in the history of this country. The National Farmers Federation, the newly formed Australian Federation of Employers, the Australian Small Business Association Ltd and even individuals like Bob Ansett are saying that they will not pay. I believe this is a first for Australia. We have before us yet again a new tax which reflects a failed Taxation Summit and yet another broken promise by the Prime Mi-nister. The people of Australia will recall that in 1983 the Prime Minister said:
Let me make one point so that even our opponents can understand it, and let me make it beyond all their powers of misrepresentation and distortion-there will be no new capital gains tax.

That is what the Prime Minister said. What do we have today? We have a new capital gains tax. When the man who, from time to time, purports to lead this country cannot be trusted, is it any wonder that he and his Government are on a slippery slide? If the Prime Minister had not been so specific, he perhaps could have been forgiven. Like so many other promises that have been broken, the Prime Minister is now cynically working on the basis that ordinary people, who are going to be so badly affected by this and the other taxes we have been considering over the past few days, will forget. How can they forget?

Let us look at the state of Australia today. We have a balance of payments which is heading towards a $14 billion current account deficit for 1985-86 which is $3 billion over Budget projections. Our foreign debt is increasing at the rate of $1 billion a month. We have an inflation rate of 9.2 per cent annually and rising. This is several times higher than our major competitors and it is being fed by wage indexation. From an inflation point of view Australia is the worst of all the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries and is the worst comparison of the OECD countries for 30 years. Unemployment is still at 8 per cent and too high and youth unemployment is over 20 per cent and likely to rise in 1986-87. Negative growth for March has come out in the recent figures which technically is equal to recession. We have a stagnant business investment and that is unlikely to improve. Our currency has collapsed and on a trade-weighted index basis is probably the weakest of any currency in the world.

talk.start.para: â€”And getting worse by the minute.

â€”It cannot improve. Again, this new capital gains tax is the result of directions given to the Government by its unelected masters, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, at the quite extraordinary and obscene meeting held in the middle of the night in a Canberra motel. It represents one of the remnants of a failed tax summit. The preferred option C of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) of a broadly-based consumption tax was torpedoed by the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Left of the Australian Labor Party. The Prime Minister was content, to the obvious chagrin of his Treasurer, to throw the Left the capital gains tax bone. Who will forget, after the sell-out in a motel room, the Prime Minister patting the Treasurer on the hand and saying: `Don't worry about it, Paul, it will be all right'. Again, we will hear from the Government that the purpose of this tax is to attack the minority of people who could be termed tax evaders. I repeat that the existing provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act are such that those who deliberately evade their taxation responsibilities could have and should have been picked up. What will happen? The same thing will happen with the fringe benefits tax. By aiming at the minority the Government will shoot the innocent bystanders. The Government claims that this is a mild form of capital gains tax and that it applies only to gains over and above the inflation rate. However, the important point is that it is a foot in the door. If this Government is returned to power there is no doubt that that tax will be widened.

speech.para: What we desperately need in Australia today is the incentive for more people to get into the private sector and develop and expand the wealth and employment generating sector of this economy. Every action by this Government and the string-pulling ACTU militates against that incentive, whether it be industrial monopolies, high interest rates, taxation and over-regulation or a prices and incomes accord which guarantees a wage spiral. By every economic indication Australia is in the worst recession since the Great Depression and it may be the worst in our history. Even knowing these indisputable facts, the Government continues to attack that sector of the economy which feeds it. From time to time I wonder what members of this Government have been doing all their lives. Are these actions crippling the small business sector deliberate or are they simply the results of ignorance? People go into small business and work 80 hours a week in the hope that they will do better than they would by working on a wage. People seek to implement new ideas hoping to gain a sense of satisfaction from achievement. Is this not what this country needs?

I refer honourable senators to remarks made by Mr Max Leibler, who is a leading Melbourne tax specialist and lawyer. According to an article in the Herald he indicated that the tax constituted `an unwarranted and premeditated attack on the rights of individuals in a democratic society'. He said that the legislation bordered on the incomprehensible and said that it was `over 100 pages of confusion and complexity'. So much for the principles of simplicity as outlined by the Prime Minister before the National Taxation Summit. Mr Leibler said that on some points the capital gains legislation was not in accordance with the first announcement by the Treasurer, Mr Keating, on 20 September 1985 and that the proposed legislation undermined the rule of law in a democracy. He is reported as saying:

The thrust of Government's blatant attack on individual freedom lies in its intent to impose capital gains tax on transactions relating to assets held before September 20, 1985, and to impose this insidious tax on virtually every capital element in every transaction-irrespective of whether the transaction involves the disposal of an asset.
The article continued:

He said many taxpayers would have incurred liabilities in terms of the proposed capital gains tax for about eight months `which could have been avoided and which would have arisen only by reasons of misplaced reliance on the text of the Treasurer's original statement'.

One can only give view with considerable scepticism the claim that the Capital Gains Tax Assessment Bill-over 100 pages of complexity and confusion-will in some way make our taxation system `fairer' or `more equitable'.
As examples of cases where the CGT would apply to gains on assets purchased or acquired before 20 September last year, Mr Leibler quoted:
A gain from the grant of an option to purchase an asset held before September 20 for an option fee.
The granting of a lease of an asset held before September 20 in consideration of a premium; and
A forfeiture of a deposit received in connection with a prospective sale of an asset held before September 20 which did not proceed.
The article continued:

Mr Leibler said the CGT was to be assessed on the full amount of the payments received-it did not deem the taxpayers to have paid or given any consideration or incurred any cost in acquiring or creating the assets sold.

Mr Leibler is reported as saying that this was a strange paradox and an unbelievable inconsistency. The Bill seeks to impose a capital gains on virtually every capital element in every transaction other than a straight gift of cash, irrespective of whether the transaction involves the disposal of an asset. The Bill also contains many anomalies which undoubtedly will distort the investment pattern and decision making in the business world. Mr Leibler is reported as saying:

For instance, . . . where real estate was sold on an instalment-payment basis, the whole of the capital gain was taxed on the exchange of contracts even though the balance of the purchase might not be payable for several years. . . . The proposed CGT would lead to a substantial bias in favour of equity, as distinct from debt.

Companies with paid capital of only $2 will have the indexing of their cost base operating on a very small base for example, . . . people with access to sophisticated tax advice would find ways to minimise the burden of capital gains taxes. Others, without the benefit of this advice, in many cases would incur unexpected and avoidable tax imposts.

Why is this Government continually throwing up road blocks to hinder the very thing so desperately needed in Australia today? We need investment, risk taking, initiative, and thus employment. The Liberal-led coalition on return to government is committed to the repeal of this negative tax and the iniquitous fringe benefits tax.

speech.speaker: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

talk.start.para: â€”In speaking on the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986 and the Income Tax (Rates) Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986 I would first like to establish the type of economic climate into which this capital gains tax will be thrown. It is important to look at the whole question of taxation in the current economic climate, so as to see the whole sorry mess in some sort of perspective. We had the capital gains tax, quarantining of farm losses, and the negative gearing legislation nearly all day yesterday. We were discussing amendments to taxation laws which will not be for the benefit of Australians generally, but will be for the benefit of the Government.

speech.para: Inflation in Australia is currently running at 9.2 per cent. This is triple the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average, four times the figure in the United States, and eight times the figure in Japan. Unemployment in Australia is currently running at about 8 per cent. We hear lots of questions in this chamber about the unemployment situation in Queensland. Some of our Labor Party senators from Queensland continually raise this matter. We have to realise that this is due in no small way to Federal costs, and of course, the overseas prices of rural products. Another contributing factor is that conditions in rural Queensland have become so bad that wives have had to apply for the unemployment benefit. This has occurred not only in Queensland but also in many parts of Australia. We have the jobless youth rate now over 30 per cent. Across Australia it is about 20 per cent which is higher now than at the start of the Priority One: Young Australia campaign.

Australia's current account deficit is expected to be about $14 billion this financial year which is an increase of some 40 per cent on last year's deficit and is twice the level for 1983-84. It amounts to 6 per cent of the gross domestic product. Honourable senators might be interested to know that only Greece has a greater deficit, in relation to GDP among the OECD countries. Our international debt looks like being around $80 billion by the end of this financial year and up to $100 billion by the end of 1986-87. When honourable senators opposite ask questions about Queensland and the problems which they think they see there-which they really do not-they should look at the debt which Australia as a whole has. The Queensland Government believes in making sure that its books balance, whereas Australia as a whole has a tremendous deficit.

It is not difficult to understand how a recent survey conducted by Murdoch University shows that in the 12 months to November this year a household on $300 a week faced a drop of 2.4 per cent in their living standard.

The outlook for rural Australia is similarly bleak. Average income for a farm this year is expected to be $6,700. I mentioned in the Senate on one other occasion that 35 per cent of rural properties have a zero or negative income.

talk.start.para: â€”It is a terrible situation.

â€”It is a very bad situation, indeed. Of course, we have to realise that rural production creates export income. Unfortunately, this year the real net value of rural production is expected to fall by 20 to 25 per cent, which will be the second lowest level in 30 years.

speech.para: We have just seen the introduction of the disastrous fringe benefits tax which will hit the productive sectors in the community, including the rural sector, very hard. Of course, we are now debating the capital gains tax which presumably is designed to syphon off some more money from the Australian taxpayer to pay for the Government's inept handling of the economy.

talk.start.para: â€”It is just wasted.

â€”I am quite sure that the Government could make savings in many ways instead of taxing people all the time. Of course, the Government wants to pursue a system of socialism and bring us all down to the same level. It is interested only in the redistribution of wealth, not the creation of it.

speech.para: I believe that the Government has to give incentive to small business, big business and rural Australia so that jobs and job opportunities can be provided. Make no mistake about it, the problems we are experiencing today are not the inherited problems that the Australian Labor Party would have us believe. The problem at the moment is directly attributable to the prices and incomes accord and to the Government's blatant subservience to the powerful unions of this country. The Government keeps talking about how it inherited a deficit of $9.6 billion. However, it forgets to say that this Treasurer-the so-called greatest Treasurer in the world; but, of course, called that only by the Labor Party-has presided over Budget deficits far larger than any in the seven years of the Fraser Government. So, as with all of the Labor Party's decisions so far, it is a matter of when in doubt, introduce a new tax.

Even though the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promised that we would not have a capital gains tax, we are getting one. The capital gains tax will apply to capital gains realised on assets acquired after 19 September 1985. The family home will be exempt. The tax is to be calculated in line with inflation. On present indications, we can look forward to an outrageously high figure. It is estimated that the amount of tax collected will be $5m in 1987-88 and will grow to $25m in the fifth year of operation. I suppose that one would not say that that was an outrageously high figure, but it is all money --

talk.start.para: â€”That is only the start.

â€”That is right. One might say that the Government has one foot in the door. I am sure that it will increase that burden with a burst. As with the fringe benefits tax, taxpayers will be subject to major record keeping requirements under this legislation. At present farms or business enterprises that were acquired before 19 September 1985 are capital gains tax free. However, if one passes the enterprise on to one's family tomorrow, the capital gains liability begins from that date. The capital gains tax liability is postponed only as long as the property remains in the hands of the immediate family. So, over time, all assets owned by all Australians, except for the immediate family home, will be subject to capital gains tax. However, the tax will affect some assets acquired before 20 September 1985 and thus will have a significantly wider impact than was indicated in the Treasurer's September announcement. I understand that if a taxpayer uses part of his family home for business purposes, capital gains tax will apply on a part of the cost of the house. That seems to me to be very poor indeed. Assets disposed of or bequeathed to charitable organisations also are subject to the capital gains tax, even if the previous probate duty exemptions were granted for assets disposed of to such charitable institutions.
â€”That is right.

â€”I am glad to hear from Senator Crichton-Browne that that information is correct. He has verified it for me. The Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, told a meeting of the Victorian Farmers and Graziers Association at Horsham on 23 October 1984 that he would oppose any new capital gains taxes and death duties in the strongest terms. He was quoted in the Australian newspaper of 9 April 1984 as saying:

speech.para: My objection to a capital gains tax is the same as probate in that it has the effect of rendering the rural sector in the long term less viable. The family has to sell part of the property to pay probate or capital gains tax.
Now, two years down the track, Mr Kerin is telling farmers that the capital gains tax is a good thing for them. I do not think that too many farmers would agree with Mr Kerin. I am sure about that.

The capital gains tax is yet another misguided impediment to incentive and hard work. The Government seems intent upon taxing the backside out of Australian business. In so doing, it is ensuring that the employment level continues to remain at the disastrously low level shown by the latest Australian Bureau of Statistics figures. My recommendation, if the Government wants to bring in another tax, is to bring in a single rate of tax.

talk.start.para: â€”Beauty.

â€”Yes, I think that is a very good idea, although one hears other people say that it would not be fair to people who do not get so much income. My feeling about the matter is that if one earns five times more than people on lower incomes, one pays five times more tax. It seems fairly equit- able to me.
â€”Look at Switzerland.

â€”That is right. Switzerland, Hong Kong, Singapore and many other places find that this single rate of tax is a very good proposition. Instead of bringing in a capital gains tax which will hit everybody very hard, I think the Government ought to give consideration to a single rate of tax. Actually, I proposed it when I made my maiden speech in the Senate. I am afraid that I have not heard anyone do much about it since then. But it does not hurt to keep talking about it. I do not understand the thinking of the Treasurer.
â€”Who does?

â€”That is quite true, but he certainly manages his Budget on a basis which is different from that of most other economies and certainly on a different basis from that of a housewife looking after the money at home. One must balance one's books. Even on properties, if one does not balance one's books, the bank manager comes along and says: `We have to fix something up'. Apparently that does not apply federally, as far as this Government is concerned.

speech.para: I do not see the logic in taxing the hide out of the productive sector of the economy, nor in paying out so much in welfare benefits. The average taxpayer in this country is supporting himself or herself, plus a single mother and two children, as well as his or her own family. I do not see the logic in making it so hard for a person to start up his or her own business. That person, in doing so, will create employment opportunities for other people. That person will only be faced by almost certain ruination because of the massive taxes and charges which this Government seems intent upon introducing. I do not support the capital gains tax legislation which has been introduced by this Government. I certainly join my colleagues in saying that it will be repealed when the coalition returns to office at the next election.

speech.speaker: Sheil Sen G.

talk.start.para: â€”The Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill and the Income Tax (Rates) Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill represent the last salvo in the barrage of tax Bills that have been foisted on us in recent times. Certainly they have been delayed a long time and the Government has been more or less governing by fear rather than fiat, because people have had to anticipate and try to organise their affairs in the light of the types of Bills that may be brought in.
â€”That shows the small calibre of this Treasurer and Prime Minister.
â€”Yes, and the difference in thinking between the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The Treasurer seems to march to a more distant drum than the Prime Minister.
â€”The more distant the better.

â€”Yes. These two Bills are part five of the barrage I have mentioned and they represent an attack on capital. I have been pointing out, as all these Bills have been going through, that anything the Government wants more of it subsidises and anything it wants less of it taxes. Now that it is taxing capital it will get less capital. As night follows day that will be what happens here and people will be frightened to organise their affairs so that they gene-rate capital, which is the only way to generate wealth and jobs. The whole economy of the nation is involved in the generation of capital.

speech.para: I have seen people quoting from their maiden speeches. When I made my maiden speech in 1974, Gough Whitlam was in power and I remember warning about the Robin Hood philo-sophy in politics where one takes from the rich to give to the poor. I said then that it did not matter what one thought about Robin Hood, the fact remains that he was still a hood. This is what is happening here. The Government is bringing on the robbery of people, stimulated by envy and jealousy.

talk.start.para: â€”Malice.

â€”Malice, probably, thinking it will hit the big guys for the benefit of the little guys. That is simply not true because, as always, it is the bulk of the people who will pay the bulk of the taxes, and in the case of capital gains it will be the working people who will pay it. After all, what is a capital gain? It represents more work, more goodwill, more business and an increase in the capital value. Certainly that is added to by such things as inflation, but that does not alter the value of the capital; all it means is that one needs more dollars to buy it. If a government budgets for a deficit and makes the deficit all right, then prints the difference, the value of the money is diluted by just that amount every year. That has been going on year after year, so the value of our money has gone down but the value of the assets has not. On top of that, of course, we have had a devaluation of the money, which has compounded the whole situation. I remember when I was in the tribal areas of Africa, they did not have a cash economy or even a cash mentality. Their currency was women, children and cattle and had been for 4,000 years, and no inflation was involved.
â€”In that order?

â€”I do not know about the order. They would have had different values. They had no inflation for years. Those parts of the tribe who had been converted to a cash economy all at once found themselves faced with inflation and it was a concept to which they could not adapt. We have had to adapt to it over years, to our detriment. The capital gains tax will be a tax on incentives and investments and as such will distort the patterns of our investment in Australia. Combined with the other taxes that have been introduced, we will have further distortions and skewing of our economy to the detriment of the generation of wealth.

speech.para: I am sorry that the Australian Democrats are a high tax party, but they have gone along supporting these Bills for increased taxes all the way. I suppose there is come misguided feeling that the Bills represent part of the Government's economic policy and that the Democrats were elected not to interfere with that, but the Bills will be to the detriment of the little guys. I know that Senator Chipp has given us examples of big share deal operators who have made $10m overnight. He said that this is obscene, but he is not really taking cognisance of the fact that if a guy is investing in the share market he has to have the money to put into it for a start, he has to know where he is investing and he has to take a risk. The odds are, if he has made $10m overnight, he has probably lost $10m overnight on another deal somewhere else, but the money he has put into the share market has provided money for the capital development of other industries. I think that is a very miserable way to look at the operations of the share market, not that I am all in favour of what has been happening on the share market lately. The stock market came into being in order to provide a pool of money for people who wanted to start businesses. Now those people have started trading in the stock market and I think that is a distortion of the stock market. However, that is another argument, but it is involved with the capital gains tax and the stock market will be affected dramatically by the capital gains tax.

The fringe benefits tax legislation and the capital gains tax legislation represent an attack on those areas where people could get some relief from the high tax policies of successive governments in this country. Rather than reducing the high taxes and creating a boom, as has been shown to occur around the world, the Government has not reduced the taxes. It has increased taxes, which will put some dire stringency on the people and I think we will see a lack of wealth generation and prosperity in the country. The National Party of Australia is completely opposed to the Bills. Not only that, but also we have promised that if ever we get the chance we will repeal them.

speech.speaker: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

talk.start.para: â€”We are debating the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill and the Income Tax (Rates) Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill. After listening to Senator Siddons last night I wonder whether these are the Australian Democrats' Bills or the Australian Labor Party's Bills, because in his speech last night he claimed these were his Bills. If these Bills are his, I say that the Democrats can be damned with the Bills as well as the Labor Party. This package of tax legislation is every bit as vicious, pernicious, anomalous and garbled as the fringe benefits tax package which has just been passed. We on this side of the chamber will be forced to listen to the same old tired lines of the Government, which continually claims that we are protecting tax cheats by opposing such shoddy legislation of which we have had far too much lately.

speech.para: For the Government's sake and for the record I repeat that the National and Liberal parties are very much opposed to this legislation, just as they are to the fringe benefits taxes; not because the legislation will hurt the tax rorters, because I do not believe that it will for very long, but because it will hurt the little people, the battlers and those struggling to improve their lot. The legislation is a classic demonstration of the hypocrisy of our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). As has already been said by many people earlier in the debate, in February 1983 the Prime Minister made it very clear that he would not introduce any new capital gains tax, yet today we have that very thing. The Prime Minister said also, when the Government's White Paper on tax reform was published, that the essence of any new tax scheme should be simplicity. If this is the Government's idea of simple, I hope we do not see any of its complicated legislation in this place. These Bills, along with the fringe benefits tax package, will be an accountant's nightmare. As Benjamin Franklin said:
. . . in this world nothing can be said to be certain, except death and taxes.

Of course, Franklin did not know how this Government operates. With this Government nothing is certain, save that it is likely to do the opposite to what it has said it will do. The legislation follows the debate on fringe benefits tax, as I have already said. I hope that the Prime Minister is more aware of the implications of this legislation and more familiar with its contents than he was with the fringe benefits tax legislation when he went to Canowindra last weekend. In case he or any other member of the Government tries to plead ignorance to the impact of this legislation, I will spell it out clearly to them. This legislation is not welcome in the rural community. This legislation will discriminate against farmers and small and large businesses. This legislation has a death duty element in it and the Opposition will repeal it on return to government.

Under existing legislation capital taxes already take about $30m a year from the taxpayers' pockets. But this Government is not satisfied with that; it wants more. It cannot keep its sticky little fingers out of our pockets. It claims that in its fifth year of operation the capital gains tax will raise only an additional $25m. I am at a loss to know why it wants this legislation with its death duty element for the sake of extracting an additional $25m from the already overburdened taxpayer. The whole philosophy behind this new tax is offensive. It is a tax on incentive and a discouragement to investment. Basically it means that investors might as well put their money into a savings bank and gain the lower rate of interest. If they put their efforts into an investment which will give returns which might be more than the rate of inflation, the Government will penalise them for doing so. In other words the Government is saying to the person who wants to invest money in capital: `You just drift along'. Only last week the Trea-surer (Mr Keating) told us all that ours was a country short of capital. Is it any wonder? Anyone who invests in this country with the object of making more profit than the average person is called a tax dodger, a cheat, or a parasite living off the rest of Australia.

I have said that the farmers of this country will not wear a capital gains tax and I will tell honourable senators why. The threat of capital gain taxes will deter investment in farming by the traditional farming family and the Pitt Street and Collins Street farmers. This legislation is all right for those who happened to own a farm or a small business before 19 September last year. It is pretty tough, however, on anyone who bought land on 20 September or, indeed, any time after that date. Not everyone who buys and sells assets during his lifetime is necessarily a vicious speculator. People tend to buy assets at a rate and of a size that they can afford at that time in their lives. That means that there is an incentive for them to buy small, improve, make a profit and buy better. What is wrong with that? This happens whether the person lives in Mt Druitt and starts with a small two-roomed fibro house and then moves up to a four-bedroomed brick house, or whether a person buys a small, run-down grocery business on an undesirable corner because that is all he can afford, and through hard work and initiative-and let us not knock hard work-he builds the business up into a desirable commodity and then sells it. The incentive is the same for both those people, but the tax is not. Because the grocer makes a profit the Go-vernment says: `You have no right to be successful, we will tax you'. But the man who buys and sells his family home is not taxed.

I do not believe that the Government should tax the home buyer and seller, but equally I do not think it is fair that it should tax the grocery shop buyer and seller either, simply because he chooses to make an effort to improve his financial position under the existing tax legislation. But this is the constant theme of this Government-to tax the person who wants to have a go and not to tax the person who just drifts along. The Government is saying: `Let us make sure that no-one rises above mediocrity. If a person tries to do so we will tax him until he stops trying'. So the reason this legislation is not welcome in the community is that it kills incentive. Overseas experience is precisely the same. While capital gains taxes are never large revenue raisers, they are generally regarded as having disincentive effects on investment.

The next aspect to which the rural community is opposed is the element of retrospectivity. If a farmer owned land before 19 September 1985, and this year built a large shearing shed, machinery shed or whatever else he required to make the land functional, and in five years time sold the property as a working, viable farm, he would be taxed on the capital gains on the buildings on that land. It does not matter that he owned the land before; the fact that he built on it after 19 September makes him eligible for capital gains tax.

The Government has denied that there is a death duty element attached to this Bill. But of course there is. It is just that it is delayed. A person can bequeath property-be it land, works of art, antiques or shares-to his or her spouse or children. That in itself does not constitute a capital gain. But if, for example, that property must be sold because the family has no money to live on, then a capital gain is deemed to have accrued and the spouse or family is taxed accordingly. Of course if those people cash in the property early the tax will be minimal, but if they retain the property for some years and sell it later only to provide for themselves, they could quite conceivably be up for a lot of money. Why does the Government not act honestly and call this tax a form of death duty in the first place instead of dressing it up in another guise? Will the Prime Minister now plead that he was not aware of that aspect of the legislation? When he next meets farmers who complain that they will be caught in a capital gains tax net with their farms, will he act innocent and with mock shock admit that he was not aware that was happening?

There are a number of questions and anomalies associated with this legislation that I wish to canvass. According to a Melbourne taxation accountant, the legislation will discriminate against companies in voluntary liquidation. The accountant claims that the legislation provides continued tax-free status in the form of rolled over exemption from tax for assets transferred between wholly owned companies if these were acquired before 20 September last year. However, he says that it fails to extend this exemption to the distribution of investments, property and other assets when this is done in another form, such as liquidation. In these instances it appears that there is what amounts to a retrospective capital gains tax obligation, even if the liquidation arrangements were underway before 20 September last. Another query relates to bonus shares. It is unclear how the profit on sales of bonus shares will be taxed and what cost will be attributed to those shares. Options are another grey area. It would appear that if someone entered into a contract to purchase an asset prior to 20 September last, that asset would be deemed to have been owned prior to that date. I do not know whether that includes options on assets. What about company owned housing? Would the principal residence exemption still apply if the house were purchased by a trust or in a company name?

Apart from the anomalies, there are a number of inequities. Take for example the treatment of capital loss. If an asset is sold for less than the amount for which it was purchased, there will be no deduction or right of offset for that loss. Another inequity relates to goodwill. The introduction of the consumer price index to calculate the cost base of an asset will extend to goodwill. When goodwill grows at the same rate as the CPI no capital gains tax will apply. However, if the proprietors of a small business build up the goodwill through sheer hard work, as Senator Sheil said earlier, the goodwill component of the sale will attract capital gains tax. In essence, those people will be penalised for working that much harder and making their business just that much more attractive to a purchaser. The Australian Democrats have forced a concession on the exemption of 20 per cent goodwill. Why 20 per cent? Why not 50 per cent or, better still, why not 100 per cent?

I regard this legislation as yet another slug on the private sector. The private sector cannot and will not put up with the continuing attacks on its viability. We have started to see the rumblings with many sectors of the business community demonstrating their anger at the actions of the Government with fringe benefits taxation. Capital gains tax is no less repulsive. The Opposition will oppose the legislation and, in the future, will repeal it. In the meantime, the people of Australia must suffer the burdens that will come with the tax, but they must remember that it was the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats who foisted this legislation and all those other draconian tax measures on to the community. The community will not forget that, and the Opposition intends to make sure that it does not. This Bill might be the thin end of the wedge, but the wedge will not have much time to get any bigger. This legislation, the Government and the Democrats will all be thrown out at the earliest opportunity.

speech.speaker: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

talk.start.para: â€”Today we are debating the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986 and the Income Tax (Rates) Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986, one day after the fringe benefits tax legislation was passed by the Parliament of Australia. This Government, with its left-right combination, certainly has business, small business and farmers out on the ropes. This Government has to take the cake for the terrible things it has done in its continued and sustained attack on the productive sector of the community. I do not think we can ever talk about capital gains tax without referring to a certain quote. I know that everyone has used it, but it has to be referred to again and again until it gets out into the community. I will use it, and I hope that every honourable senator on this side of the chamber who speaks in this debate will use it. It is a quote from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). He said:

speech.para: Let me make one point so that even our opponents can understand it; and let me make it beyond all their powers of misrepresentation and distortion. There will be no capital gains tax.

talk.start.para: â€”He got into government by deceit.

â€”As Senator Sheil so wisely says, the Prime Minister got into government by deceit, but what did he say in 1984? I told the people of Australia that there would be a capital gains tax. It was as obvious as the nose on one's face that this Government was a high taxing government. The continued remarks made by Government members in the Senate that the Government would redistribute the wealth of Australia told me very clearly that there would be a capital gains tax. I warned the people of Australia that there would be such a tax. I said at a National Party Senate campaign launch that there would be a capital gains tax and that the National Party would oppose it. That was 12 or 14 months ago. We are now debating the capital gains tax and the National Party and the Liberal Party are opposing it.
â€”Can you trust this Government?
â€”Of course one cannot trust this Government. One could not trust it at all.
â€”You are a clairvoyant.
â€”I do not think I am clairvoyant. I think any person who had been a member of the Senate for three years could obviously see the way that this Government was going.

speech.para: Australia, at this time, is having very serious financial problems. The deficit will be $14 billion by the end of the 1986 financial year. The internal economy of Australia has stalled or is in a depression. Despite various front bench members of the Labor Party trying to talk it up, it has stalled. Members of the Labor Party would do very well in the winter recess-I recommend this option to them-to set aside one week to go out into their electorates and talk to the business people. They should not just talk to the union people. Of course, they have to talk to them, but they must balance things, as we do in the National Party. It is necessary to talk to the workers, to the business people and to the captains of industry.

talk.start.para: â€”Come on! When did you talk to the workers?

â€”We talk to all people. I suggest that when the honourable senator returns to Western Australia she should go and talk to her greengrocer, to those who work in her local hardware store and to a couple of manufacturers in her State. I am sure that the honourable senator will find that most people in the business sector and the farming sector in Australia will not be able to tell her that they had a good year. They will certainly not be able to tell her that they are looking forward to a better year. If the honourable senator goes out to talk to the productive sectors of the community-the business people-she had better take a double bed sheet to cry on. That is how bad things are under the honourable senator's Government. Very few people are making a great profit.
â€”It is 100 per cent better than it was under your Government.

â€”I do not accept that for one minute. Every economic pointer is showing Australia up in a bad light. Our inflation rate is higher than that of our trading partners. Australia's rate of inflation stands at 9.2 per cent. Japan's rate is 1.1, the United States of America has a rate of 2.3 and West Germany 0.1.
â€”And they are all falling.

â€”Those countries' inflation rates are going down. We cannot expect to trade with them. We are pricing ourselves right off the market at every turn. Our standard of living has fallen from third highest to twenty-first in the world. The Labor Party's policy solution to this problem is to introduce a fringe benefits tax and to follow it up on the next day by introducing a capital gains tax. The Labor Party believes the answer to Australia's economic problems is to tax the productive sector, tax the farming communities and tax the mining sector. These measures will cost the mining sector $61m. Goodness knows how much the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax will cost the rural sector, but it will certainly be considerable. Out of 72,000 rural workers 20,000 are expected to lose their jobs just due to the fringe benefits tax, not to mention the capital gains tax. That is certainly not the right way to go. When Australia is crying out for investment, the Labor Government has introduced two of the most anti-investment taxes ever to go before the Parliament.

speech.para: This Government, in its desperation to crank up the economy, is saying that it will give some form of interest rate subsidy to encourage manufacturers to invest in more efficient production methods. Most manufacturing companies or businesses will not invest any type of money-they would not even invest confederate money-while this Government is in power. There is no incentive to invest. Why would anyone invest? As some of my colleagues have pointed out, one is better off putting one's money in an interest bearing deposit than investing it in a business and taking the risks involved. With these two taxes the Government has killed incentive in this country. It has taxed the farmers. It has bled them dry. They have nothing left to give. The next people on the list are those in the manufacturing industries. The other day, in my speech on the fringe benefits tax legislation, I mentioned that 360,000 people in the manufacturing industry have lost their jobs over the last nine or 10 years because of redundancy payments, the holiday loading, the 38-hour week and the 3 per cent productivity claim which have made this country unproductive and uneconomic. The interest subsidies that the Government proposes to give will not work.

We have seen the Government try and crank up and kick start the economy by pork barrelling the car industry and the steel industry. Only the other day the heavy engineering industry was given $84m. I believe that the steel and car industries received about $200m. At the same time the Government has taken $440m away from the rural producers. That is what the rural producers have lost under this Government, not to mention the effects of the fringe benefits tax or the capital gains tax. Of course, those two taxes will impact heavily not only on the manufacturing industries but also on the rural industries.

For four years this Government has engaged in a sustained and vicious attack against the primary producers. The disgraceful behaviour of the Prime Minister at Canowindra is a typical case in point. He got carried away by the friendly country people out there who gave him a nice country welcome because he was the Prime Minister. He told them that he would look into the impact of the fringe benefits tax on rural homes.

talk.start.para: â€”It has not had any yet.

â€”It started to have an impact as from yesterday. He said to those people at Canowindra: `I will go back and have a look at the situation.' He built up their expectations. They trusted him because he was the Prime Minister. He returned to Canberra and did not one thing about it. It was the most disgraceful behaviour that any Prime Minister has ever engaged in. He told the people exactly what they wanted to hear. He got carried away. Even the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, said: `I think he is doing the wrong thing. He is building up their expectations. He will never be able to deliver.' That was the advice that the Minister for Primary Industry gave the Prime Minister out there. The Prime Minister's performance was disgraceful-one of which he should be absolutely ashamed.

speech.para: I want to talk now about the impact that this capital gains tax will have not only as a capital gains tax but also with the built-in death duty. After a number of years the Queensland Premier fought to abolish death duties. He forced every State in Australia to follow suit and he then forced the Commonwealth to follow suit. So death duties were abolished throughout Australia. It was a great move.

talk.start.para: â€”A very good man.

â€”Senator Bjelke- Petersen has a right to be proud of her husband. He did a great service to Australia and the productive sector. We now find that this Government is going to undo all that good work that was done in removing those death duties by introducing a capital gains tax. I will tell honourable senators on the other side of the chamber why it is a capital gains tax. There are no capital gains when a farmer or businessman passes a farm or a business on to his wife or his sons and daughters. Let me instance my own case. My father-in-law, who passed away 12 months ago, had five daughters. Those daughters are married and live all over Queensland. His farm will have to be sold to another person-it cannot be passed on to a son-in-law who wishes to work it-and the capital gains tax and death duties will apply to it. That is not an uncommon thing. Every time that a family divides a property for probate a capital gains tax and death duties will be applied.
â€”It does not apply in those circumstances.

â€”I have just explained it. Even the Minister for Veterans' Affairs should understand what I am saying. It is not hard-it is about grade 4 standard. The Minister should be able to understand that there is a death duties tax when a farm is passed on after the owner dies so that the probate can be settled. This tax will be retrospective for farmers and businesses from 19 September 1985. Any person who has a business or a farm and who wishes to make that business or that farm more efficient may put capital into it. All businesses run on capital. This is something that members of the Australian Labor Party fail to understand because not many of them have had to run a business. I do not think that anyone on the opposite side of the chamber has ever run a business. As I look around at the honourable senators on the Government side of the chamber at the moment, I do not think anyone over there is capable of running a business. The facts of the matter are that, if a businessman puts in some new shelving or a farmer builds another shed, the capital gains tax is working against him as it is retrospective from 19 September 1985.
â€”It is only fourth grade wording and you can't understand it, can you?

â€”If the honourable senator wants to develop an argument on the capital gains tax I would be very willing to hear it. If the good senator wants to develop an argument on the capital gains tax, I suggest that she gets up and puts her Party's position on it. Very few people from the other side of the Senate have been prepared to stand up and put their position. I must admit that Senator Cooney has, but he is one of the few. This Government has now put a capital gains tax on accommodation. It has put the squeeze on rental accommodation. Building approvals for domestic residences have fallen nationally by 26 per cent since August. Because of the capital gains tax, domestic rents have risen by 20 per cent nationally in the last six months and they have risen by up to 35 per cent in Sydney.

speech.para: The Labor Party and the Australian Democrats should be ashamed of themselves for introducing both the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax. But I think the Democrats should be especially condemned for building up expectations in the rural community as the Prime Minister has. When these taxes were first introduced into the Senate the Democrats said that they would reduce the goodwill component on a farm by 20 per cent. I asked them, I asked Senator Walsh, who is a farmer and the Minister for Finance, I asked the National Farmers Federation and various other people whether they had ever heard of a goodwill component on a farm. Senator Walsh told me that he had never heard of one. The publishers of the Queensland Country Life newspaper had never heard of one and the National Farmers Federation had never heard of one, so I asked the Democrats. I even sent Senator Chipp a letter as Leader of the Democrats and I asked him how they were going to reduce the goodwill component on farming properties. I am still waiting for a reply to the letter which I sent to him six months ago. I think the best reply that I received came from the publishers of the Queensland Country Life newspaper. They told their readers that the only way to defeat a capital gains tax and a fringe benefits tax was to vote for the National-Liberal Party. That is a good piece of advice.

talk.start.para: â€”The Liberal- National Party.

â€”It depends on who is speaking. The capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax will be repealed when the coalition parties are returned to government and I believe that that will be after the next election. We know that the only way that Australians will enjoy prosperity will be by creating a business atmosphere that will give incentive for investment and allow people to make a profit without being taxed. The Government has its policy wrong. It devalued the dollar in a dirty float in order to cut off imports and encourage local manufacturing resulting in exports and investment. That is what should happen. But this Government has brought in so many taxes, such as the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax, and taxes on expenses, that there is no incentive left in Australia for people to produce anything-whether they are primary producers or secondary producers-and they just will not invest. People who were fortunate enough to sell their businesses when this Government came into power have the money in income-earning deposits. The less fortunate ones are hanging on by their fingernails waiting in anticipation for this Government to change. When this Government came to power on the promise of no extra taxes-that is what it promised-it had, to some extent, a reasonable rapport with the mining industry. I do not think that primary industry ever voted for this Government but it has had a reasonable rapport with primary industry and some manufacturers. This Government has squandered that goodwill and now the business and mining communities are waiting for the day when this Government will be thrown out of office before the predictions of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) come true and we truly become the banana republic of the South Pacific.

speech.speaker: Watson Sen J.O.W.

talk.start.para: â€”In his second reading speech on the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) said:

speech.para: . . . it will make the tax system much more efficient by encouraging investment that will generate growth and jobs.

I have always regarded Senator Walsh as someone who prides himself on his economic prowess or expertise, but the primary criticism of this Bill is precisely the devastating effect that it will have on investment. In a classic example of poor timing the Government has chosen to introduce legislation which would act as a veritable brick wall to all investors. At a time when this country is in desperate need of continued, if not increased, investment, the Government has decided to push through a tax which will do absolutely nothing for the wellbeing of this nation. On 30 May the Australian Financial Review, which the Government assured us last week was an independent commentator, stated:
. . . one thing is certain, the new tax will force every Australian to think twice and maybe once again before making any decision which may affect their tax and financial position:

People will effectively be discouraged from creating wealth. Capital gains will remove the incentive to take risks-risks which, given the present economic climate, are already very substantial.
