The tax will virtually halve any profit. Who is going to place in jeopardy hard-earned capital when a large slice of that return is just spirited away to the Government? With this impost the Government is effectively saying to every Australian: `We will take half your earnings on any particular gain on a capital asset regardless of the risk factor which you must bear'. For this reason the tax can only be seen as an unmitigated assault on enterprise and hard work which will destroy the backbone of this nation, namely, small business and the rural sector. I cannot see how this Government can be so shortsighted. It is obvious that the capital gains tax is destroying incentive. What is even more mind boggling is that the Government will be imposing this tax for relatively little financial gain. It is unpopular. Even the Government recognised this in 1983 when, while it attempted to woo all the voters of Australia, it swore emphatically that it would not introduce a capital gains tax, and in a short time we have this legislation before the Senate.

I think it is recognised by the Government that this tax will not be a significant money spinner, even though it will be charged at the taxpayer's highest rate of 61c in the dollar. Revenue, even after five years, is expected to be only about $25m, which is less than 10 per cent of the bank account debits tax. In the long run it is not expected to become a major income producer-unless it is going to be amended; that is where the rub is-because of the complete exemption of assets owned prior to 20 September 1985. It will take at least a generation before its full impact is felt. In the meantime incentive is crushed, investment is stifled and the state of the nation's economy sinks further and further into the mire. Ironically, the imposition of a capital gains tax will hurt the very people that this Government purports to represent. Like the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill, this tax will ultimately hit those people on low incomes. It will do this in several ways: Firstly, no investment means no jobs; it is as simple as that. Those with the capital resources to generate wealth by establishing new businesses will have little incentive to do so. The result is that the creation of new jobs will be restricted. The growth of employment will be severely hampered if investment declines. This can surely do nothing for the welfare of the people and will merely lead to a drop in living standards.

The most undesirable aspect of this tax is that it is effectively a tax on the young. As I said earlier, the capital gains tax legislation exempts assets before September 1985. This is all very well for the older generation who have already built up their investments and accumulated their assets, but spare a thought for the young people who have been placed fairly and squarely behind the eight ball. They are the people who are yet to establish themselves in business and are to be further burdened with a tax which will reduce their chances of becoming self-reliant in our society. It is obvious that the people who will suffer most under this tax will be the very people that this Government should be trying to encourage, the individuals upon whom the future of this nation relies. I hope that the voters of Australia will note that it is the present Labor Government which proposes to handicap our young people before they have even left the starting blocks.

The Government seems to be intent on making life as difficult as possible for Australia's welfare institutions. Under this legislation, the estate of a deceased will have to pay tax on the capital gains of gifts to churches and charities. Clearly this will result in a substantial decrease in the number of bequests made to these institutions. The Government attempted to tax the charities yesterday through its fringe benefits taxation. If it had not been for the Opposition, the legislation would have gone through. Fortunately we passed an amendment which saved the charities from the imposition of the fringe benefits tax.

A further effect of this Bill will be the creation of distortions in the market-place. The Government claims that the introduction of a capital gains tax will result in a more efficient allocation of scarce resources. I believe that such a statement is no more than completely misguided. The legislation will not foster wealth creation; rather it will encourage negative investment and even greater speculation. As principal residences are to be exempt from the tax, investment is likely to be channelled into this direction rather than towards business. In effect, the wealthy will be encouraged to sink capital into the home, a bigger home, a more grandiose home which can later be sold without incurring a capital gain levy. With the present high interest rates people will not be encouraged to build and the demand for existing housing will artificially inflate the price of the home even further. If honourable senators ask members of the real estate market they will tell them that this is happening already.

This method of avoidance is only one of the various ways in which a capital gains tax could be circumvented by those who have adequate resources at their disposal. By far the simplest way of doing so is merely by not realising the asset. It will effectively lock investment into existing, often uneconomic, enterprises, many of which may not be in the best interests of the nation. There is no reward for risk taking. The Government is effectively locking people into existing investments, preventing people from moving into better investments. This will be done if the asset is not reinvested, because then no tax will be payable. People will be encouraged to hang on to their assets in order to avoid a tax on any capital gain. With people being reluctant to buy and sell, the market will invariably stagnate. Adding to this arithmetic effect will be the bias generated in the takeover market. The proposed capital gains tax will favour existing company management and disadvantage the bidder as individuals will be unwilling to relinquish exempt shares. This could have the further effect of retarding the progress of business as its moves towards greater efficiency could be obstructed by the rort created by the taxation system.

I believe that the Government had an opportunity to avoid the introduction of a capital gains tax. The existing tax system provides mechanisms by which it could effectively have caught individuals. The Government deliberately avoided taking that line. These opportunities included a more stringent application of section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Also amendments could have been made to section 26 of that Act. However, the Government effectively now has a foot in the door. That is the purpose of the legislation presently before us. The Government is taking one step now; it will take a second step and a third step down the track at a later time. All these so-called mitigating effects of allowing for losses and allowing for inflation and so on within a year or so-maybe in a shorter time-will be wiped out under the score that people are using these as tax avoiding mechanisms to defeat the intention of the tax. We will see a lot of these so-called cushion effects being wiped away by subsequent amendments. In other words, the proposed new capital gains tax is but a first step; it is but a foot in the door.

I believe that the present legislation is merely a kite-flying exercise by the Government. Therefore, once the tax goes through it will be easy to bring in further amendments. Also it is an attack on people's ability to save and to accumulate capital and income. It will make people more dependent on the government. From the time of the first economic statement an attack was made on capital. I ask honourable senators whether they remember the tax on lump sum payments. The attack started there. Ever since the Government has been in office we have had a litany of legislation effectively attacking people's ability to save and making people more dependent on government handouts and less dependent on their own initiative and resources. Effectively the tax will be a double sort of tax because people already pay income tax. They will have to pay tax again if they invest and realise on their capital investment and make a profit. I believe that this is a very retrograde tax. I believe that it is a tax that is not in the best interests of Australia or Australians. Certainly, it is a tax on the young. I believe that the fact that this tax is on the young is one of the most serious and understated reasons for our opposing it. That is an important reason. I ask the Government to think again.

speech.speaker: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

talk.start.para: â€”We are debating the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986 and the Income Tax (Rates) Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986. We are debating a capital gains tax despite the promise of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his 1983 election speech. Again I will quote that statement that has been quoted by so many other senators in their speeches. The Prime Minister said:

speech.para: . . . there will be no new capital gains tax.

This legislation, however, does introduce a new capital gains tax. Of course, the Opposition is absolutely opposed to the introduction of such a tax. It has said on many occasions that on its election to government it will repeal any capital gains tax that has been introduced. The Opposition is opposed to a capital gains tax because, unlike the Government, it recognises that production in our economy is generated not by government nor by trade unions but by the daring, skill and straight-out old-fashioned hard work of entrepreneurs.

The capital gains tax of course threatens to rob businessmen, both big and small alike, of the fruits of their labour. It will take away almost half the value of any gains made on business property. Of course, the tax represents another attempt to rob those people who are willing to go out and have a go to seek a just reward. In so doing the tax will hit not only the speculators in the share markets but also the smallest of businessmen. Having been forced to pay yet another impost introduced by this Government many business people will decide that they have reached the end of the line. Having been battered by this Government for the final time they may well decide it is just not worth the effort any more. They will not invest and take the risks. They will not create the jobs which of course the country needs so very badly at this time. Our society depends on a healthy business sector which in turn depends on sufficient incentive to make investment worthwhile. The imposition of a capital gains tax will be another tax like the fringe benefits tax which will destroy incentive, deter entrepreneurs and, ultimately, be to the detriment, of course, of the living standards of all Australians.

Let me outline how the tax as I understand it will operate and indicate how in my view some people will be affected and, finally, how I believe in turn it will harm the entire economy. As a general rule any taxpayer who bought property after 19 September 1985 will be liable to pay tax on any real capital gain made on this property when it is sold. By taxing real capital gains the Government has decided to tax only those gains which are made over and above the level of inflation. Any losses which are made on property bought after 19 September may be deducted from capital gains. A taxpayer's house used exclusively for residential purposes will be exempt from the tax. As a general rule, the goodwill of businesses will be made subject to a capital gains tax although there will be a 20 per cent remission or concession given on goodwill on businesses of less than $1m value. Certain limited roll-over provisions exist but they do not go so far as to include a situation in which a business sells an asset simply in order to buy another asset. I instance the case in which a business moves, perhaps, from small premises to larger premises. Sales of such assets will of course be made liable to a capital gains tax.

In many ways this tax will operate unfairly and, interestingly enough, will not adhere to the Government's oft-stated aim of horizontal equity-that is that taxpayers who derive the same amount of income should pay the same amount of tax. The first of these inequities is that although the capital gains tax taxes real capital gains it does not allow for the deduction of real capital losses. The Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill will allow only the deduction of nominal capital losses. Therefore, if the price of an asset rises perhaps by 50 per cent simply as a result of inflation and the owner of the asset sells it only for the same price for which it was purchased originally, in reality the owner has made a capital loss.

talk.start.para: â€”It is a better deal than the wage and salary earners get.

â€”I do not believe that it is. Those people in the community who by their skill, courage, enterprise and endeavour are prepared to risk, to strive for reward and invest are being asked to carry all the responsibility of private sector investment without having the mitigating or offsetting losses available to them in the event that there is a downturn or that the business or commercial decisions that they make are not viable in the economic climate of the time. In my view there ought to be some reward for effort and endeavour. Certainly, there ought to be some reward for the courage to invest. If the capital gains tax were to operate equitably it would allow not only for the effect of inflation when gains are made but also for the effect of inflation when losses are made. Therefore, a person who makes both capital gains and capital losses would be at a disadvantage compared with a person who makes only capital gains. This tax also will operate unfairly because capital losses are deductible only against capital gains. The effect of this is that if a person makes a capital gain it is added to his ordinary taxable income and may well put him into a higher tax bracket. If the opposite occurs and a person makes a capital loss, can this be deducted from his ordinary income so as perhaps to reduce his marginal tax rate which is paid, in the same way as capital gains increases his marginal tax rate. The answer is: Not at all. When the system is likely to result in more tax, the Government will gladly put out its hand. If, however, it is likely to result in less tax, the same rules do not apply; they are set aside conveniently, comfortably and expeditiously by the Government. Capital losses must be carried forward until there is a capital gain against which they can be offset. In some instances this may be years, in some cases it may be never.

speech.para: It is not only the wealthy in the community who will have to pay the Government's capital gains tax, it will often be the small businessman. One interesting attribute which the people who pay the capital gains tax will have in common is that they will be the people who have been prepared to take the risks, to make the effort, to acquire property, and who try to improve their own lives and the lives of their families. The small corner store keeper, who has so often been referred to in this debate, will be caught by this tax. If a person opens a shop and works in that shop for his lifetime he may only earn sufficient income from that small shop to pay for the day to day running of his life and that of his family. Previously, such a person would know that after a lifetime of work he would have obtained a substantial asset in the shop which he could sell ultimately to provide a nest-egg for his retirement. It is now almost inevitable that, after a lifetime of work in such a shop, the shopkeeper will be liable to pay the government capital gains tax. The diligent work of the shopkeeper would contribute substantially to the goodwill of the business. A clean, well-stocked shop which has acquired itself a reputation in the neighbourhood will have accrued a substantial amount of goodwill amongst its clients and neighbours.

With the passing of time one could normally expect land prices to rise. These two factors mean that a substantial capital gain is likely to have accrued. Despite, as I said, the concession of 20 per cent for goodwill, the taxpayer may well find that almost half the gain in his shop is handed over to the tax man. Half the earnings of his life's endeavours are taken, are plucked from him; half the rewards, half the nest egg which he would have put aside for his retirement is taken from him by this legislation. I find it amazing that, at a time when the present Government has shown that it is prepared to go to great lengths to have all employees in this country paid part of their earnings in the form of superannuation so that they will have provision for themselves when they retire, it is introducing a capital gains tax which will be a major disincentive for small business people to provide for themselves and their families in their retirement. This Government has shown that it is prepared to introduce legislation which will destroy much of the incentive for a small businessman to work hard throughout his life. It is taking a large part of his retirement nest egg.

The capital gains tax will be a major disadvantage for the small businessman who is attempting to expand his business. Many of today's great companies started off in tiny premises, and as time has gone on they have grown, expanded and acquired new assets, new buildings and new factories. But what will happen under this legislation? The owner, of course, will be liable to pay capital gains tax. No provision is made in this legislation for people who sell one business asset in order to purchase another larger asset, and thereby expand their business. There is no incentive for people to upgrade their equipment. There is no incentive for people to expand their business, to take future and further risks, and so stimulate the economy and increase the work- force. This will represent enormous obstacles for the small businessman because in most cases it is the money obtained from the sale of the smaller assets which makes up a substantial proportion of funds available for the larger asset. When the Government takes away substantial proportion of the money made from the sale, the business has no alternative but to increase borrowings, thus increasing future interest payments and reducing future profits.

Under this legislation there will be people who will be faced with a capital gains tax who currently may not imagine that the tax will hit them. This is most likely to occur in relation to the taxpayer's home. The Government has, as I said earlier, given an exemption for gains made on the sale of the taxpayer's principal or sole place of residence. However, this exemption is partly removed if the taxpayer uses his home for earning income. Proposed section 160ZZQ (21) provides this qualification. Examples of this include the doctor who uses his home as his surgery, the self-employed person who works out of his home, the shop which is attached to the taxpayer's residence, and the person who takes in boarders. In this case the Commissioner of Taxation is to make some apportionment of the liability to pay capital gains tax based on the length and extent to which the house has been used to earn the taxpayer assessable income.

The effect of this part of the Bill will perhaps be most iniquitous to those people who are required to take in boarders. It is frequently those people who cannot earn income in more active ways who are forced to take in boarders in order to supplement their income. Many pensioners do this to supplement their pension income. Little do they realise that in so doing they are using their principal place of residence to earn assessable income and may be liable for capital gains tax if they sell their home. As we know, many pensioners ultimately, because of their fragility, are required to sell their homes and move into frail aged homes. These people will now find themselves subject to a capital gains tax on what has been their principal private residence which they may have occupied for that purpose for the better part of their lives.

Another group which will be unexpectedly hit by this tax are charities. How any government can stoop so low as to attempt to tax charities, to me, is almost beyond belief, least of all from a government which pretends to reek of compassion and of concern, which claims a sensitivity to the underprivileged, to the deprived, and to the disadvantaged. Yet we find that this is the Government which is prepared to tax those charities which set themselves up to assist the very people which this Government pretends to represent and the very people who now will be disadvantaged. Those charities are generally exempt under the legislation for capital gains which occur on their own assets. This is not the case when assets are bequeathed to them.

While proposed section 160x in this Bill will ensure that the passing of assets on the death of a taxpayer is not deemed to be a disposition and therefore assessable, proposed section 160y in the Bill specifically deems dispositions to a tax exempt body liable to a capital gain as if those assets were sold at the current market price. Charities are tax exempt bodies and will be affected by the capital gains on assets which are bequeathed to them. For the second time in a week this Government, which tries to claim an affinity with the disadvantaged in the community, has shown that it is prepared to tax charitable organisations. First there was the fringe benefits tax levied on cars provided to employees. Now we have the taxation of bequests to charities.

Other groups in the community will suffer because of this tax although not directly. The effect of the capital gains tax combined with the negative gearing proposal will be to force up rents charged to tenants. Primarily, that will affect those people who require low rental housing; welfare housing. In many cities at the present time, landlords do not receive enough rent from the properties which they own to cover the interest which they have to pay on the loans used to pay for houses. They are, however, prepared to carry this loss because it is partly reduced by being deductible against other income, and also because the landlord may well make a tax free capital gain when the property is sold. In other words, it is an incentive for him to invest in a commercial asset in which he would not normally invest. The losers in this case are going to be those who will not be able to rent homes at a reasonable rate-at a rate they can afford.

When this legislation is passed, with the help of the Australian Democrats, as has been the case with all of the Bills relating to tax packages, none of the advantages I have referred to will remain. Landlords will have to look at housing in the same light as they would look at any other investment. The houses which they buy will have to provide normal commercial returns. They will now be making hardheaded decisions as to where they will invest their funds, and one can reasonably assume that this certainly will not be in the low rental market. Working on normal commercial interest rates charged for investment purposes, a house would have to return at least 20 per cent, after payment of running costs, to be a viable proposition. On a house valued at $100,000, if a capital gain of 12 per cent were to be averaged, approximately $8,000 at the very least would have to be charged to make the house a worthwhile investment. However, this does not allow the investor a return on the money which he has outlayed, nor does it allow for the payment of expenses associated with a house, such as maintenance, rates and insurance. In these circumstances one could imagine the rent on such a house to be about $250 a week.

The tax will also have an effect on many existing asset holders even though they may have bought assets before 19 September 1985. This is simply because anyone who buys these assets subsequently will be liable to pay capital gains tax. Inevitably, this means that the subsequent purchasers will reduce what they are prepared to pay for the assets. In this way, another group will be indirectly harmed by the introduction of this tax, although they may not realise it. These are the people who are faced with reduced selling prices for assets which they currently hold. In other words, the person purchasing the asset knows that the asset itself is worth less to him because it is going to be subject to a capital gains tax. So, in making his commercial decision in terms of the return on the investment, he is going to discount it by that much. To that extent, the tax will affect and apply to those people who presently imagine themselves to be exempt from the provisions.

When a tax such as this has such a wide effect on so many individuals throughout the community, it ends up affecting the entire community. The facts are that all Australians will lose when this tax is introduced. This Government is showing its usual bad timing. It is going to introduce a bad measure at precisely the worst time. As I have said, this tax will deter enterprise because it will rob investors of reward for hard work and risk-taking. If ever there was a time when Australia needed strong and healthy business, it is now. In April, 7.9 per cent of the work force-or one in every 12 persons-was in unemployment lines. Around 600,000 Australians who were looking for work could not find it. One in five persons between the ages of 15 and 19 years is unemployed. What is needed to provide these people with the work they need is a high level of investment. This investment has not been occurring under this Government's high interest rate policies. In fact, investment is falling. Investment in new fixed capital fell by 3.3 per cent in the December quarter and fell by another 2.1 per cent in the March quarter. I know that is a matter of concern to honourable senators such as Senator Button. This is dreadful news for those people looking for work because it means that their chances of finding employment are falling. In my view, a capital gains tax is lunacy in such circumstances. It can only reduce investment and reduce the chances that job seekers will find work.

talk.start.para: â€”Investment in what, Senator?

â€”Investment in a whole range of areas; investment, for instance, in buying new equipment and new premises, in purchasing assets which will create wealth; investment in the manufacturing sector, in the Minister's area of responsibility.

speech.para: In the recent Economic Planning Advisory Council paper titled `Business Investment and the Capital Stock', the Council indicated that there had been a marked decline in the rate of investment growth in Australia since the early 1970s. The growth in investment has slipped from around 6 per cent in the 1950s-this was under a conservative government, of course-to an average of only 2 per cent for the decade until 1985. The level of investment reached its lowest point during the life, period and times of this Government. The Council went on to indicate:

. . . estimates that are available suggest that the deceleration in the growth of capital stock has significantly reduced the capacity of the Australian economy to employ fully the available labour force.
The Council indicated that capital stock in Australia had to grow by 3.4 per cent each year-and I draw Senator Button's attention to this-to avoid increases in unemployment. The Council also said:

Nevertheless the overall trend rise in unemployment over the past decade is closely related to the slowdown in capital accumulation. To the extent that this is so the unemployment problem will have to be addressed over the medium term by the development of an economic environment favourable to expanding levels of business investment.

Not only has this Government been incapable of increasing capital expenditure but also it has pursued policies which have led to investment actually falling. This is a sure sign that Australia is heading into a recession. Yet the Government's response is to ignore advice which it has received from EPAC by failing to create an environment which is favourable to business investment. Instead, it is introducing taxes, such as the one before the Senate, which will have an effect opposite to that which the Australian economy needs at the present time.

I have indicated that I believe that the sector most adversely affected by this tax will be the Australian small business, given that it employs the vast majority of the labour force. In another EPAC paper titled `Some Features of Small Business and its Policy Environment', EPAC indicated that small businesses could employ as much as 55 per cent of private sector employment. Thirty-four per cent of employment in small business occurs in wholesaling and retailing, and other significant proportions of employment occur in small manufacturing enterprises and storage. These are the types of industries which require considerable investment in fixed assets and which will be particularly susceptible to a capital gains tax. As I indicated, if many small entrepreneurs no longer see sufficient returns available to them after the imposition of this tax, the employment consequences for this country will be severe, to say the least.

There is one aspect of this tax which I would like to raise, and that is the question of the Australian rate of capital gains taxation in relation to overseas rates, particularly that of the United States of America. The Hawke Government's capital gains tax legislation will result in the taxation at 49 per cent of capital gains made by companies and, despite tax averaging provisions, the 49 per cent rate will also apply in respect of many ordinary taxpayers. I raise that point because last night the modest number of senators from the other side of the House who contributed to this debate put to me that countries such as the United States had a capital gains tax and that it had been in place for many years. However, they did not point out that the level of company tax in the United States is a great deal lower than that in Australia. The present capital gains tax in the United States is of the order of 20 per cent-in fact, it is 20 per cent exactly-although there is some speculation that that rate is likely to rise to 27 per cent in the near future. But whatever it might be, it is certainly less than half the rate that the Government is seeking to inflict upon business in Australia.

talk.start.para: â€”But we index the gains. We index the asset values for inflation.

â€”I accept that point that the inflation rate is indexed. But even if the gains are discounted, by any measure the level of capital gains tax and company tax under this Government is greater than that of the United States.

speech.para: I am running out of time. As much as I enjoy debating this point with the honourable senator, I must press on. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his second reading speech on this legislation said that the total tax payable by foreign investors under this legislation will only increase where tax crediting exists in the home country if the Australian tax liability is larger than the liability in the home country. The Australian rate for companies will be almost double the rate in the United States. Obviously, this will be a significant disincentive for investment from the United States. I simply ask the Government whether it has ever stopped to consider the enormous amount of development which has occurred in Australia through investment from the United States. This aspect of the tax also reveals another glaring inconsistency in the policies of this Government. In the recent rural package, one of the measures announced for the relief of the rural sector was an easing of the Foreign Investment Review Board guidelines for rural landholdings. This was presumably to encourage greater foreign investment. Now the Government is imposing a capital gains tax which will have precisely the opposite effect.
I conclude by quoting from the National Australia Bank's Monthly Summary of November 1985. No doubt Senator Button will have read it with some dismay. The bank stated:

Capital gains are seen as the mainspring of entrepreneurial incentive-a spur to innovation, investment and consequently real growth. Considering the relatively insignificant tax expected to be gained from it ($25 million in the fifth year of operation) and the likelihood of significant damage to business incentive, both real and psychological, the tax is hard to justify.

I would go further than the National Australia Bank and say that, especially in the present economic climate, the tax is impossible to justify. It will make business nervous and apprehensive. I am quite sure we will see a continuing decline in capital investment in this country. This Government, of course, is again going on some type of ideological binge so as to placate those elements of the Labor Party which believe that anything which represents initiative and enterprise is fair game for any kind of taxation or regulation which it can impose. The capital gains tax, like many other aspects of the tax package, is the product of a weak government, a government which, despite its claims of seeking community support and consensus on tax changes, was prepared to hand over taxation responsibility for the changes it was going to make to the tax system to the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Under these circumstances the result is predictable. The tax changes have borne a consistently anti-enterprise theme. When taxes such as the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax have their inevitable effect and cause business to contract, the blame will lie with the weakness and failure of this Government to provide the leadership and strength in government that Australia so desperately needs.

As I say, it is very regrettable that, at a time when we need capital investment, capital formation and stimulation of the private sector, this Government, as a result of its obsession and its ideological bent, its determination to screw the system and anybody who has the courage, fortitude, initiative and enterprise to invest so as to make this a great country, has missed an opportunity to make a positive contribution. Its contribution will be detrimental to the community as a whole. I really wonder how serious it is about stimulating the economy of this country. I will be curious to see what banal statements the Prime Minister chooses to make next week to explain how he can solve the problems of this country.

talk.start.para: â€”Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: â€”The Senate should not forget that this capital gains tax is simply a piece of political window dressing which will raise very little money, but which will cause immense inconvenience and immense disturbance and is, as Senator Crichton-Browne pointed out, an inhibitor of activity in the private sector at a time when that activity must increase, particularly in the investment area.
â€”Why are they buying record numbers of shares at this moment? Why is the share market showing record highs week after week?

â€”That is a very interesting point, Senator Maguire. I will make certain that I respond, so that the honourable senator's lack of knowledge will be recorded. If Senator Maguire has any knowledge of what is a yield, he will know that when yields on government securities and other fixed interest securities fall, there is a concurrent fall in the yields available on other securities-that is, equities. In other words, prices rise. I am giving Senator Maguire a first year economics lesson. When yields on fixed interest securities fall, there is a tendency for them to fall also in regard to equities.
â€”In other words they are coming down.

â€”If Senator Maguire is incapable of understanding that proposition, I suggest that he cease interjecting. Given the reality that this is a political and not an economic piece of activity, we should consider what are the economic costs of this brand of politics.

speech.para: Let us recognise how this tax emerged. It was one of the package of nasties which was introduced at the National Taxation Summit last year by the Treasurer, Mr Keating, who has a fixation with summits. On that occasion, as in the case of his recent venture, he was rolled by his leader. On that occasion he introduced the concept of these tax nasties as a bribe-and no more than that-to encourage the union movement to put up with his very sensible attempts to reduce personal income tax rates by having an offsetting increase in indirect taxes. This was regarded by most thinking Australians-except, of course, the trade union movement, whose leadership is immediately disqualified on that ground-as an excellent and much needed reform. It was a reform, for example, which the previous Government had endeavoured to move towards until the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats in this chamber defeated the first moves towards an expansion of the indirect tax base. This expansion, of course, is necessary if one is to reduce direct taxes.

The Labor Party has maintained its consistent stupidity on this matter. When its Treasurer very sensibly endeavoured to move down the track of reducing personal income tax and increasing indirect tax-which, of course, has the advantage of being very difficult to avoid or evade-he got rolled by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), along with leaders of the union movement, in a back room deal in a local hotel. That is why all we have left now is the bribe without the reform. The Australian Labor Party or anyone else who keeps talking about these tax measures as being a great reform is forgetting what has really happened. These are the bribes for the reform. All we are doing is paying the bribe to the union movement without getting the reform.

We have seen the consequences of the elements of the package that have so far been passed by the Senate. For example, today's headline in the Australian, following the passage of the fringe benefits element of the package yesterday, reads: `Fringe benefits: rents will soar in Victoria'. The article reads:
The controversial fringe benefits tax has forced the Victorian Government to abandon its long-held policy of giving heavily subsidised housing to public sector employees.

The story which appears next to that article has this headline: `Big rises in fares, charges in three States.' We will see consistently that the impact of this package-this bribe to the union movement-will be disastrous in terms of employment, in terms of investment, and in terms of economic development in Australia. We have further evidence in this morning's newspapers. There is an open letter. I do not refer to the very interesting open letter to Senator Chipp, which I hope he sticks on his wall and keeps looking at to remind him of his and his Party's perfidy to the people who have elected them. This open letter is an open letter of support to Mr Keating. That is why I want to make certain that it is clearly recorded in Hansard. It comes from a registered company liquidator. Naturally, he would be very keen to support Mr Keating. He is a registered trustee in bankruptcy. His open letter of support for Mr Keating is as follows:
Dear Mr Keating
I hope you take heart from this letter and press on with your sweeping tax reforms.

People don't seem to realize that many new jobs will be created in the Public Service to police these taxes, and just think of the extra leisure time that small-business owners will now have! Many of these business owners have previously only dreamt of an early retirement. Your new taxes will make this a reality for them.
Yes, Mr Keating, I'm on your side.
I expect my own business to actually increase by at least 50% over the next financial year!
yours sincerely,
John H. Mann
Registered Company Liquidator.

talk.start.para: â€”Terrific stuff!

â€”I am glad that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce interjects `good stuff' because I agree with him. It is very high quality stuff which reflects the concerns that this Government could not care less about and which it has refused to listen to. Those concerns come from the business community, particularly the small business community, which this Government does not want to talk to. It consistently talks with big business and big unions, but most Australians are employed in the small business sector. I see that the Minister yawns at the suggestion of small business and employment.
â€”It is getting smaller.

â€”As Senator Sir John Carrick says, it is getting smaller. We are now left with this package dealing with the capital gains tax. So far the Australian Labor Party has been able to put up only two senators who have been prepared to defend this absurd and damaging tax which we will repeal on election to office. There is one good thing about this tax; it will make even more certain the return of the coalition parties at the next election because there is wider and wider recognition that this tax package reflects an assault on those Australians with any initiative who are prepared to get off their tails. People who are employed by those Australians with initiative also will be at risk and threatened and under pressure from this kind of tax.

speech.para: What is the justification for this kind of tax? We have heard from only two Labor speakers. The Government has said consistently that it is wrong to allow revenue, for example, to be converted into capital if revenue is taxed and capital is not. The Government has admitted that section 25a of the Income Tax Assessment Act does tax gains made on assets when those gains are judged to be for the purpose of making a profit. What I find incredible about the Labor supporters of this tax is that they have failed to concede that section 25a, with the uncertainty that they point out exists in that section, will persist despite the passing of this legislation. There will still be uncertainty, except this time the uncertainty will be whether one is taxed at the marginal tax rate or on a capital gains tax basis which allows one to deduct the inflationary impact. In other words, people will be caught one way or another, but the uncertainty of the manner in which people will be caught will in no wit be changed by this proposed legislation.

In my view, section 25a should be changed so that, instead of being simply part of this uncertainty and madness that is going on at present, it becomes a genuine speculative gains tax. I think everyone on both sides of the Senate would accept the proposition that speculative gains should be subjected to taxation. Speculative gains were taxed under the previous Government and they had been under this Government even before this tax measure came into place. For members of the Labor Party to pretend somehow that speculative gains are not taxed is absolute nonsense. The big question is: What is the best way to do it?

I put very strongly the point that we could cope with both problems simply by changing the existing legislation so that section 25A would provide, for example, that if one acquires an asset and sells it within 12 months it should be subject to the marginal tax rate. If it is sold, say, between 12 months and two years after it was acquired, it should be subject to a slightly lower tax rate-say, 75 per cent of the marginal tax rate-and so on, wiping out at five years, so that if something was held for five years it would be deemed to have been an investment and that gain would not then be subject to a capital gains tax. I should imagine that this would have very little impact on revenue and it would be directed specifically at those people who are taking a speculative gain, whereas this tax will hit people who have no intention of taking speculative gains, those people who are seeking to build up an asset or a business and who-I know these are dreadful words for the Labor Party-reflect an incentive and reflect their own determination to do better for themselves. Those are all things which a government which seeks to encourage people to become dependent on it would find unattractive.

Given that there is a need for a tax on speculative gains, let us see what this new capital gains tax, in conjunction with the fringe benefits tax, the negative gearing tax and so on, will do to our nation. We have heard from Senator Crichton-Browne and many others about the consequences of the capital gains tax in many areas. We know of the consequences it is having for example, on rural property values. It is all very well for the Government to say: `But look, it applies only to properties purchased after 19 September'. The fact is that the potential purchasers of those properties will be subjected to this tax, therefore, they will not be prepared to pay as much for those properties. In other words, the market for those properties will be diminished accordingly.

talk.start.para: â€”They will discount the asset by that amount.

â€”As Senator Crichton-Browne says, they will discount the asset by that amount. One should combine that with all the other things that are happening to the rural sector, particularly as demonstrated by a feature article in the Australian newspaper today, which outlines the increase in the cost of a stationhand, for example, as a result of the fringe benefits tax element of this package. The article points out that the tax will increase the cost of a stationhand from about $309.10 per week to $340.22 per week, and this at a time when the rural sector is in serious distress.

speech.para: I turn now specifically, because time is running out, to deal with a couple of matters. I should say before passing on to them that it is extraordinary that the Australian Democrats are supporting the Labor Party in this case. It is extraordinary in intellectual terms but not extraordinary in terms of political integrity because one would expect the Australian Democrats to maintain the double dealing position they have adopted with the Labor Party in this case. Here is Australia, a capital hungry nation, having to import multi-millions of dollars a year in capital to provide the investment funds we need. Certainly we need investment funds if we are to expand our manufacturing capacity in order to replace imports which are now flooding in as a result of the Government's extraordinary economic policies, which have damaged almost irreparably, but I hope not entirely, our international status, our currency and our balance of payments on current account. The Australian Democrats have asked: What is so different about Australia? Why should we not have a capital gains tax when everywhere else in the world has a capital gains tax? Let us recognise this: The nations that the Australian Democrats were talking about are generally exporters of capital. We are importers of capital. We are so short of a capital base in this nation that we must import it.

talk.start.para: â€”A very good point.

â€”I thank Senator Sir John Carrick for his interjection. Here we have a nation that is totally different from those that the Democrats point to as examples of the need for and the propriety of having a capital gains tax. It is absurd for a nation as dependent as ours on importing capital to diminish our own capital stock by taxing it and giving it to a government-particularly this Government-which is overjoyed at the thought of spending that money which it has taken from the private capital stock and spending it in the most extraordinary and reckless way. Let me remind the Senate that there would be no deficit whatsoever this year if this Government had not, in each of its three Budgets so far, added enormous new spending programs. In its first Budget the Government introduced new spending programs totalling $2.5 billion. In its second it introduced programs totalling about $1.3 billion and in its third it introduced programs which, in a full year, would add another $700m-odd. When one applies the full year impact and the inflation impact to those new programs introduced by this Government, it adds up to more than $5 billion and that is the deficit it is seeking. Had this Government been responsible, we would not have faced these problems. I wish to deal with a matter that has been raised with me by some accountants. This relates to the announcement by the Treasurer on 20 March concerning roll- over provisions which will apply in this capital gains tax legislation. The Treasurer said on that occasion:

speech.para: In my 19 September statement I indicated that the Government intended to give further consideration to the question of providing rollovers (i.e. deferral of capital gains tax liability) for asset ownership changes associated with certain types of business reorganisations. The Government has come to the view that rollovers can be justified in this area in certain situations where no change occurs in the underlying ownership of the asset concerned or where the underlying assets against which the taxpayer has a claim do not change.

I make the point in passing that this was a fairly significant alteration made on 20 March to a law which did not exist, of course, but which was applying from 19 September 1985. That is the great way this Government runs this country. It tells people that they are not allowed to do something or that something will happen from 19 September. People do not know what the law is or whether they are meeting it. Six months later the Government changes this non-existent law anyway and changes the initial impact of the statement, then 10 months after that initial statement was made it comes out with the legislation which people were supposed to have been abiding by all that time. More specifically on this matter, the Treasurer said that it was proposed to provide rollovers in situations which he then outlined. My correspondent, who is an accountant, wrote this to me:
It is submitted that the proposed rollover provisions should be extended to provide relief in the following circumstances:-
Firstly, a distribution of property by a company in specie to individual shareholders who are 100% owners of the company;
secondly, the distribution of property to the partners of a partnership upon the dissolution of the partnership;
thirdly, the distribution of assets in specie by a trustee.

In particular it is submitted that where an asset acquired prior to 20th September, 1985 is distributed in specie in the above circumstances it should retain its capital-gains-tex-exempt status in the hands of the transferee. In such situations there will have been no change in the ultimate ownership of the asset. Furthermore those situations bear a very close similarity to certain of the situations already covered in the Treasurer's 20th March, 1986 announcement.

There are cases where solvent companies were placed in voluntary liquidation prior to 20th September, 1985 solely for the purpose of dispensing with the companies and distributing the company assets, in specie, to the beneficial owners i.e. the shareholders. In certain instances such voluntary liquidations had not been completed at 19th September, 1985-some of the assets had been distributed in specie to shareholders prior to 19th September, 1985 and other assets still remained to be distributed in specie to shareholders after 19th September, 1985.
In those cases it is quite unacceptable that the remaining assets distributed in specie after 19th September, 1985 should lose their capital-gain-tax-exempt status.

Clearly, the tax should provide rollover relief for distributions of property in specie in the same way as has already been proposed by the Treasurer for transfers of assets between companies in the same group, where such companies share 100% common ownership.

Transitional provisions are most definitely required in the case of companies which were placed in voluntary liquidation prior to 19th September, 1985 and where the distributions of assets had not been completed at that date.

This is just another example of the many confusions and messes that are involved in this kind of legislation. I hope that it is not too late for the Government at least to consider the merits of the point made in that letter relating to rollovers. After all the Government belatedly admitted that it has to look at the question of rollovers six months after it made its announcement, so perhaps now it will belatedly look at this question of fixing up what it has not yet properly fixed up.

I turn to the question of goodwill and the handling of it which still causes a great deal of trouble. The Senate will remember that the word `goodwill' was not understood by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) when this matter was first raised by the Opposition. We claimed that there would be an unfair impact of this tax on goodwill. It would be natural for Senator Walsh not to understand the meaning of the word `goodwill'. He certainly has none in this place. The reality is that goodwill is simply the difference between the net value of the assets of an operation or a business that are sold and the price paid for that business. There is no special definition involved. Goodwill is simply that difference between the value of the net assets and the price paid. In other words, on many occasions it is worth while for a purchaser to pay more than the value of the assets because the business is good. It might be a dry cleaning shop in a country town which, because it has provided a good service, is highly regarded and has an established clientele.

talk.start.para: â€”And a growing clientele.

â€”Yes, and a growing clientele, as Senator Crichton-Browne said. It may be worth while for a purchaser to buy that business for more than the value of the dry cleaning equipment, the lease or even the freehold property because that business is a going concern which has proved its ability to earn money on those assets. If the purchaser had to start without a going concern-suppose he just bought a shop and put in the equipment-he would have no guarantee that people would want to use that equipment. This concept of goodwill is very meaningful. It was only as a result of pressure from the Opposition and a belated recognition by the Democrats that once again they had put their feet in their mouth, that the Government has conceded to a degree that goodwill must be treated in a special way. However, the way it has treated it is inadequate and absurd.

speech.para: I draw attention to the fact that six months later-once again-the Government has decided to exempt 20 per cent of the otherwise taxable capital gain on the sale of business goodwill wholly created by the taxpayer where the net value of the taxpayer's business interests-that is plural-is less than $1m. In other words, a small drycleaning business which is sold for less than $1m is subject to this exemption where that is the sole activity of the owner. If in fact the owner has another dry cleaning business in another town, and the combined value of those businesses is more than $1m, even though he wishes to sell only one of them, somehow that business is regarded as a bad dry cleaning business and will not receive the 20 per cent exemption. That is the same sort of principle that the Australian Labor Party applies to uranium-some uranium is good uranium and some uranium is bad uranium and must not be mined. A dry cleaning business in a town will, when sold, get a 20 per cent exemption on the otherwise taxable capital gains if that business is owned by a taxpayer who does not have another dry cleaning shop in another town, the net value of which results in that person's business interests adding up to less than $1m.

Let us deal with the general question of the extent to which this measure is fair and proper. Let us recognise that this is of major moment to small business, even though it will get the 20 per cent exemption. When one starts a business with no goodwill one cannot get the benefit of this indexation which, according to the Labor Party's figures in this Bill, is supposed to protect people from the impact of inflation on their assets. If a person such as a dry cleaner in a country town starts a business by renting a shop and renting equipment-having done all that, there will be no goodwill-how can goodwill be indexed when there is none, in order to provide the basis for diminishing the sale price when that business is eventually sold and there is a capital profit? The reality is that that cannot be done. That is why the Government has had to introduce this 20 per cent concession. But this concession goes nowhere near meeting the basic problem, and the problem is that this Government is going to tax the rewards of hard work. It will tax success, tax the--

talk.start.para: â€”Tax labour.

â€”Yes, it will tax labour. The reality is that if people have worked hard all their lives, have succeeded in building up a business and they want to sell that business because, say, they want to retire, when they retire the difference between the net value of the assets and the value of that business because of the way they worked it up, will be subject to this capital gains tax and most of it will not be indexed for inflation. Twenty per cent will be indexed, but the basic amount-80 per cent-will still be subject to taxation. This is simply one of the many instances where this tax-this bribe to the union movement to get a type of tax reform that did not come about-is a disaster. It is another of Mr Keating's summit pratfalls. The last time he had a summit-the National Taxation Summit-he got rolled by his Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). This time, when he tried to have another summit, he was rolled by his Prime Minister again. This tax is another of Mr Keating's disasters.

speech.para: Debate (on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick) adjourned.

proctext.para: Motion (by Senator Button) agreed to:
That, unless otherwise ordered, till 2 p.m. this day, matters of public interest may be discussed by senators, provided that no senator shall speak for more than 15 minutes.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: â€”In October 1984, the Minister for Health, Dr Neal Blewett, commissioned a review of the future development and promotion of public health education research in Australia. He commissioned an American, Dr Kerr L. White, to undertake that job as head of a review team. I rise today to say something about the outcome of that study and to suggest to honourable senators that a miscarriage of justice in relation to the School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine may take place as a result of the report.

speech.para: I want to deal with only one aspect of the report; that is, the recommendation that the School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine within the University of Sydney be replaced. It is proposed that it be replaced by a new multidisciplinary, independent national centre for epidemiology and population health at the Australian National University in Canberra and by the further development of existing health courses, particularly an initiative by the University of Sydney at Westmead Hospital, together with courses at the universities of Adelaide and Newcastle. I pause here to declare appropriate interest; that is, I was a student in the School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine some years ago, more than a quarter of a century ago, and I am presently on the Council of the Australian National University, which stands to be one of the beneficiaries of this recommendation.

It is the recommendation that the School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine at the University of Sydney be closed that concerns me. I am told that it is likely that Dr Blewett will recommend to Cabinet that that be done. It is important to raise for the Senate my belief that it is based upon poor evidence and a biased approach. The recommendation arose from a scathing attack launched on the school by Dr Kerr White's committee. The committee reported as follows:

. . . the School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine has outlived its usefulness. Multiple reviews over the past decade or more have been unable to help the school to define its mission, recruit permanent leadership, or have an observable impact on contemporary health affairs in the country. Dual masters for funding, leadership and performance, ambiguous organisational relationship, rapid turnover of faculty, conflicts between goal-oriented and investigator-initiated research, incompatible mixes of students, use of courses primarily for purposes of job advancement, unco-ordinated lectures by visiting office-holders, variable academic standards, inability to attract many young students, an uneven research output, uneasy tension with the medical faculty, limited administrative support from the medical faculty, discordance between school priorities and perceived national problems are among the many manifestations said to be associated with the widespread perception of inadequacy. It is a sad litany and there is no point in attempting to apportion blame.

Honourable senators may gather that the review team was not impressed with the School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine. The only evidence, however, provided by the report to back up such an absolutely stinging and total condemnation of the School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine is the following introductory comment:

The consensus of the great majority of submissions and opinions expressed during the interviews, and at the Sydney seminar . . . is that the School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine has outlived its usefulness.

It is incumbent upon members of that review team, if they wish to make that recommendation and if they wish to condemn so roundly and with such extreme language the School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine, to produce some evidence to back up their findings. As neither the transcripts of the interviews to which they refer nor the submissions to which they refer are attached to the report, and as people cannot test the transcripts of evidence, the transcripts of interview or the submissions, there is no evidence available which can be tested to support the attack which has been made upon the School. We do not know who made the damning submissions. We do not know what weight should be attached to their contribution. We really do not know whether enough evidence has been adduced to support any attack upon the School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine. Really, I would say that much more evidence would have to be available to me before I, were I again the Minister for Health, would agree to close down an established school within an established university.

Let us test the Kerr White report conclusions against such data as has been provided to me. This material casts serious doubt upon the report's conclusions and in many instances it leads to conclusions completely opposite to those which have been advanced criticising the School. Before I do that, I would like to look at Dr Kerr White's own background and his competence to be put forward by Dr Blewett as, to use Dr Blewett's words, an `independent expert'. My information indicates that Dr Kerr White approached the review with preconceived opinions. I am told that at a meeting on 1 March 1982 he already advocated the closure of the School in a meeting with the Vice-Chancellor and the Dean of the Faculty of Medicine at the University of Sydney. On 2 March, one day later, he met with senior Health bureaucrats to advocate the same approach. All this, I am told, occurred before he had any personal knowledge, any interviews or any submissions about the School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine.

Dr Kerr White's bias against schools of public health should not come as a surprise. It is well known in the United States. It is said-and I believe it may well be true-that it is related to personal bitterness and envy. I have a letter from Jacob Brody, Dean of the Office of Public Health, University of Illinois, in which he offers the following reason for Dr White's bias. Dr Brody says:
I suspect they stem-
that is the bias-
at least in some part, from the fact that he was fired from Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene and Public Health Faculty and harbours some bitterness about this.
Or we could note the remarks of Dr Henderson, the Dean of the School of Hygiene and Public Health from the Johns Hopkins School. He said:

You should know that for at least 10-15 years, Kerr White has publicly and vehemently asserted that school of public health should be abolished. Thus, he unquestionably concluded what the role of your school should be long before he arrived in Australia. I agree that clinical medicine has lacked a population perspective but this I believe has less to do with the schools of public health than with the public and political fascination with high technology and tertiary care medicine. It should be noted that in this country-
that is, the United States-
during recent years, departments of community medicine, social medicine, epidemiology, et cetera, et cetera, in medical schools have steadily diminished in number and quality.

The tone of a comment on page 13 of the report about the history of public health research supports these comments. Without saying it directly, the report makes it clear that it has little confidence in the public health school approach to dealing with public health problems. Paragraph 2.5 of the report commences thus:

Seventy years ago the Rockefeller Foundation, on the basis of a hastily drafted document, decided to embark on a new approach to training medical officers of health who would undertake strategies for the control of environmentally based diseases and for the immunisation of populations against selected communicable diseases . . . The history of both the intellectual and political basis for this decision has only recently been explored and is yet to be fully evaluated and published. The net effect of this seventy-year-old experiment has been that schools of medicine were deprived of the population-based perspective.

To me the tone of these assertions indicates quite clearly a preconceived bias against schools of public health which Dr Kerr White had before he arrived and which he has allowed to pervade his report.
Finally, in this area, I should refer to the words of Professor James Banta, Dean of the School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine at Tulane University in New Orleans, who wrote:

The hubris of Dr White and his ilk of self-anointed prophets profane the discipline of public health. They arrogantly speak with great authority, but with rather sparse, biased appraisal of the data, both concerning needs and resources . . . You should be aware that for some reason unknown to me the present Medical Director of the Rockefeller Foundation is hostile to schools of public health. If Dr Kerr White was his emissary, then I am not surprised at his inability to be objective.

In summary, Dr Blewett appointed to head a major inquiry into public health in Australia a man who was so bitter and so biased against schools of public health that he could not be objective. Dr Blewett must have known, or should have known, of Dr Kerr White's record. There seems little doubt that Dr Blewett has chosen Dr Kerr White deliberately and for good reason, to produce the kind of report that the Minister wanted; and no doubt Dr Blewett was looking to Dr Kerr White to manipulate the outcome of the inquiry.

What of the conclusions themselves? Let us test them. The White report accused the School of having a high staff turnover, but figures made available to me show, firstly, that 90 per cent of the faculty present in 1985 had been at the School for four years or more; and, secondly, that apart from retirements and major promotions, that is, to professorships, staff turnover has been just under 5 per cent per year. These figures, quite contrary to the conclusions of the report, represent a model of stability. Why did Dr Kerr White say otherwise without giving any evidence? The White report questions the performance of the staff, but information provided to me shows, firstly, that the 21 academic staff members of the school published 43 articles in referred journals and four books, a publication rate of over two per year, which is considered reasonable by most academic standards. Dr Kerr White offered no evidence of his attack. I offer some evidence in defence. Next, the staff attracted grants totalling $4.2m for research into public health at an average of $200,000 per staff member. This record is far superior to that of most similar institutions. I have a letter here from past and current students of the School questioning Dr White's conclusions on fact and expressing support for the School. Finally, I have a work program for the School's 1985 year which to me is a model of order and discipline and does not at all suggest the conclusion of the White report that the School suffers from `conflicts between goal-oriented and investigator- oriented research', et cetera.

Dr White's accusations are made without any evidence offered to back them up. They are accusations which may lead to the winding down of a school which has served Australia well over many decades. No evidence is offered to back up these accusations and there is plenty of evidence available to refute them and knock them over. In fact, all the evidence available is against Dr Kerr White, against his report and against his conclusions. I am not about to allow the School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine to be closed down on the basis of an inaccurate, biased report based upon the preconceptions of a bitter man who has been sacked from a similar job. I am not prepared to do that without a fight. I intend to find out what is going on and, if necessary, will use questions and freedom of information and the Estimates to try to get to the bottom of it.

Dr Blewett has yet to obtain Cabinet support for the recommendations of Dr Kerr White's suggestions. I suggest to the Minister and his colleagues in the Cabinet that they demand some access to the evidence on which the recommendations are based if they wish to do justice and fairness to the academic community in Australia. Unless some very strong evidence can be produced to support the closure of the School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine and if the evidence in defence of the school can be verified-and indeed it can-I think the School should continue, and I hope that Dr Blewett would not obtain Cabinet support for any proposal to abolish it.

speech.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: â€”I rise to comment upon the current relationship between Australia and our nearest northern neighbour, Indonesia. Like so many Australians, I am disturbed that, arising from a series of recent incidents, there appears to be a significant degeneration in that relationship. I am disturbed primarily not because of merits or otherwise of issues, but because I believe that the bonds that should unite Indonesia and Australia in a working co-partnership of near neighbours ought to be so much stronger than any incidents that should divide us. If indeed that is not so, it points to a fragility of the relationship which ought not to be-a fragility which reflects upon the failure of our Government in particular to build the bridges and to make an understanding that is vital to this country. I therefore believe that we should look at the problem very closely indeed. We ought to be seeking to put aside misunderstandings and to get on with the working relationship, because Australia and Indonesia are cast for eternity as next door neighbours in an exciting, growing and perilous area. We are cast together in a region of immense growth, immense opportunities and, indeed, dangers. Indonesia and Australia straddle two great oceans-the Indian Ocean to the west and the Pacific Ocean to the east. Indonesia itself provides the north-south gateway through the Malacca and Makassar straits to those oceans.

speech.para: We in Australia, in my judgment, have failed to orientate ourselves to a full understanding of the Asian area around us. Inevitably, because of our European origins, we judge virtually everything upon values which grow out of our Judeo-Christian origins, the background of Roman law and British common law and, of course, the Westminster system which has given us democracy. Those of us who do so make a fundamental mistake in believing that these are absolute values and that no other systems might be appropriate to other races, other cultures, other religions. That, I think, is our fundamental mistake. We have for too long looked through European eyes at Asian problems.

More than that, I think we have not spent our time looking at the problems of Indonesia itself. Indonesia as a nation is less than 40 years old. Indonesia, by that name, was created out of a struggle for freedom in the post-war years; the struggle for what they call Merdeka, freedom, a natural struggle reflected throughout the colonial areas in the world; a struggle to put off the swaddling clothes, to get independence. Before then, the Dutch occupied what was then the Netherlands East Indies. I was privileged to view that scene. The Dutch were essentially reasonable colonisers but it would be fair to say that there was never there a structure of a public service, of a basic administration, that could endure through changes of war and peace and through cultural changes. The predominant public service was performed by the Dutch themselves and the Eurasians.

When the war occurred and the Japanese invasion occurred, this was all destroyed. The Dutch, and indeed some Eurasians, were imprisoned-many Eurasians were imprisoned-and the Japanese installed a military administration. We make the terrible mistake of believing that, just because we have a public service that has evolved over the centuries, others have indeed been in the same fortunate circumstances. After the Sukarno uprising and the freedom of Indonesia, the Sukarno regime was forced, inevitably in the early stages, to employ the military as a rudimentary public service. This inevitably was inefficient. It contained many difficulties. It tended towards some elements of corruption, but it was what was necessary and available at the time. I do not make excuses for difficulties that could have been avoided, but I have to say that it is no bad journey indeed in 40 years for a country which had no basic public service and public administration to evolve and to build what is today a stable nationhood, a peaceful nationhood, and one which is progressing.

I want to point out the immense difficulties that were faced. Here is a nation that was created by the accident of a papal decision in the early sixteenth century, a decision born of the view that the earth was flat and a decision born of the quarrels between the Portuguese, the Dutch and the Spanish. It was created simply because the Dutch East India Company came round the Cape of Good Hope and explored east to an island which was called Timor-meaning, in Malay, east. Of course, the voyage around Cape Horn by Magellan to the Philippines, his own death and then del Cano, his lieutenant, bringing the good ship Victoria to Timor resulted in the creation of a nation, which became the Netherlands Indies, the Dutch East Indies, and of an island, Timor, with division-Portuguese at one end and the Dutch at the other end. All this occurred in a period 300 years ago, and with the conflicts built in. Here is a nation, not 40 years old, which has inherited literally thousands of islands stretched over several thousand miles of sea. It is a nation totally heterogeneous in races, in religions, in cultures-a nation essentially, primarily, Islamic in Sumatra and Java, with Hindu cultures built into Bali and elsewhere, with Christian cultures in Flores, Ambon and elsewhere and with other religions and cultures in islands such as Timor, Sumba, Sumbawa and Lombok throughout the whole area. It is a nation created, as I say, by the accident of war, a nation which seemed almost impossible to govern and in which to achieve stability. Nevertheless, it is to the credit of the Suharto regime that it has achieved that measure of stability. It has a long way to go. I can only say, having visited Indonesia in the time of the Dutch, in the time of Sukarno and in the various times of Suharto, that I have seen very, very significant progress, and I wish the Indonesians continued progress for the future.

Of course, there are difficulties; of course, there are mistakes; of course, there are errors to be pointed to. I simply stress that here is a country overcoming great obstacles in terms of its size and nature. It is a country too that is integrated with South East Asia in the Association of South East Asian Nations with other countries such as Malaysia and Singapore, a country playing its part in the stabilising of the region and in the peacekeeping of the region.

It is sad when we seek to speculate in some hypothetical way whether at some time or other any one of our northern neighbours might become hostile or create enmities in our region. If those are the kinds of hypotheses, they are best left to the drawing boards. They do no good at a time when, in fact, it is perfectly clear that the Suharto regime is a peaceful regime, a non-communist regime, and one that wants to pursue its economic course.

I want also to basically say that we ought not to continue the East Timor dispute as a basic obstacle between the two countries. Whatever may have been the reasons in the past, it would be disastrous if we continued. I speak with some very considerable sympathy for the East Timorese, having spent some little time of my life there, and with admiration for their bravery in the war years. The fact of the matter is that the Portuguese, who put in only a rudimentary colonial system with very little of the health systems support props or very little basic agriculture, left hastily and the world itself did not face up to what should happen in that regard. The region itself offered no solutions; the United Nations offered no solutions; and there was a takeover. Whether that takeover was the right thing or not is for history to adjudge. Certainly it has happened and certainly one cannot now, with hindsight, put forward other views. It has happened. Timor is there. What we basically need to be sure of is that the Indonesians understand that we have a warm sympathy for the Timorese people. If it is necessary, and if it is in the competence of the Indonesians for us to do so, we would like to move amongst them. We would like, if it is necessary, to bring supporting aid, in terms of medicines and foodstuffs, to them. Basically, the greatest assistance that we could bring to those 500,000 or more East Timorese would be medical assistance-immunisations which could fight against the diseases that the Europeans brought to them, specifically upper respiratory tract diseases, tuberculosis and so on. If we can indeed help them in bodily strength and health, they themselves can subsist on the minimal foodstuffs on the island. I know from some personal experience just how little nutriment one needs to stay alive if one has a healthy body.
