What does this add up to, Madam Acting Deputy President? I rose because I am disturbed that incidents appear to be perpetuating a degeneration. Mature people who are next door neighbours, mature nations which are adjacent to each other, ought to be able to have from time to time arguments or disputes about questions of fact and to ride over those because fundamentally, I repeat, the issues that unite us ought to be so much bigger than the issues that divide us. That must be so. We ought by now, after 40 years, to have a mature relationship. We ought to understand that the peoples of Indonesia have cultures, religions, languages and value judgments different from ours. We ought not, in the arrogance of our own Western ethos, our Westminster ethos, believe that only our values are right. We ought to understand that others have different views and that democracy itself, as we understand it, is not necessarily a universal concept that is more perfect than others. We must ourselves bring tolerance and understanding. There will always be faults on both sides. All I ask is: Let us get the mature relationship and let us journey together to keep a region which is an exciting but dangerous region a stable one for peace and good government in this world.

speech.speaker: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

talk.start.para: â€”I would like, if I might, in the short time I have to make some observations about what might be described as the pending gold tax. Amidst last year's taxation reform debate the Government dragged out the old issue of the taxation of gold. If there is one tax that has been recognised for over 60 years as detrimental to the welfare of the economy as a whole and a disaster to many regional towns in Australia, of course, it is a tax on gold. Should such a tax be introduced by this Government it would be a disaster for the gold mining industry and, as such, it would be a loss to the nation and particularly to the State of Western Australia.

speech.para: Let me examine why the gold mining industry is exempt from taxation now, why it should continue to be so and what will be the consequences if the Government takes the disastrous step of introducing this tax. Let me say, before I go any further, that the Liberal Party has made its position clear; that is, it will not introduce a tax on gold. For my part, I thoroughly endorse that and, in the event that this Government chooses to introduce one, I will use in my modest way whatever methods are available to me in this Parliament or in a legislative form to have it repealed.

The Australian gold mining industry was first exempt from taxation in 1924. This occurred after a long period when the price of gold had been fixed while the costs associated with the mining industry were rising. Inevitably, this resulted in declining profitability in the industry and in 1922 the number of people in the industry fell by 15 per cent, tonnage by 30 per cent and yield by 16 per cent; and dividends also fell by 28 per cent. Gold mining operators moved to mining only high grade ores. Anybody who understands the mining industry will understand the disastrous consequences and effects of that. The long and short of it is that what would normally be economic deposits are left in the ground. In terms of deep mining, underground mining, once the pillars and the stopes are left there, they cannot be knocked out at a later date and the ore recovered. It is ore that is left in the ground-of value but lost forever.

In 1922 the then Government responded to this depressing state of the industry by exempting gold mining and prospecting from taxation. The government of the day clearly recognised the connection between the return which gold miners and prospectors received for their money and efforts and the level of activity in the industry. The then Government, of course, must have also recognised the connection between the level of profit in the industry and the quality of ore which companies would mine. As profits are reduced, the industry, as I say, is forced to mine only the high grades and hence the more profitable ores.

By the early 1930s the gold industry had returned to a healthy state. It was well that it did, for during the Depression, while the remainder of the country was economically stagnant, the gold industry played a major part towards relief of unemployment. Many people migrated to the goldfields both from within Australia and from overseas. Interestingly enough, so much was the migration from Europe that in 1934 rioting occurred generally in the Kalgoorlie area between European emigrants. Many of the traditional animosities, of course, were transplanted by the migrants from their many countries of origin to the goldfields area of Australia. There was an enormous amount of conflict at that time for a range of reasons. Not only did gold generate employment for the people employed in the industry directly during the Depression, but it also alleviated the difficulties of the times for many other associated industries.
In his book Mining in Western Australia, written for the 150th anniversary celebrations in Western Australia, Rex Prider cited a Western Australian research economist, G. B. Snooks, who said:

It is clear that the poor performance of the agricultural and pastoral industries in the 1930s would have been a greater disaster if it had not been for the existence of large deposits of gold bearing ore in Western Australia.

Gold retained its exemption, of course, from taxation until the election of the Whitlam Government. In 1973, the Labor Government announced its intention to remove the exemption for gold mining and for prospecting. Mr Crean, the Treasurer at the time, when announcing that the Labor Government intended to withdraw the tax exemption for prospecting and the profits of gold mining companies, said that the Government believed that the original purpose for the tax concession had all but vanished. Mr Crean, on 28 August 1973, went on to say:
I find it a little hard to believe that the taking away of half the profits of the industry-
that is what the announced tax measure will mean-
will bring the amount of desolation and destitution in that area that some people have suggested.

On 12 September 1973, 30 men were promptly sacked from North Kalgurli Mines Ltd and this was attributed to the plans to introduce a gold tax. The Government wisely later reconsidered its decision to withdraw the exemption from gold mining companies. This proposal was abandoned, but the exemption for prospectors was withdrawn late in 1973. The exemption was reintroduced by the Fraser Government in 1977.

The Hawke Government has again resurrected the proposal to withdraw the exemption from tax for the gold mining industry. It seems to me to make no sense to introduce a tax on gold. The most obvious effect it will have is to reduce the returns which investors and prospectors in the industry will receive for their efforts. In so doing it will frequently mean that they will simply not be making those investments in the future. The simple connection between the potential profit which can be derived from gold mining and the amount of exploration, investment and production which results is something which was recognised as long ago as 1924.

Gold is currently a growing industry which is employing more people each year and which is building towns and opening up the remote areas of Australia. Direct employment in the gold mining industry has grown from 2,691 people in 1980-81 to 3,949 in 1983-84. Employment in the industry is currently estimated to be in excess of 5,000 people. In five years this represents a growth of nearly 100 per cent, or an average of 20 per cent per year; and, of course, the indicators are that the multiplier normally used in respect of the gold mining industry is 4:1. Gold production has increased from 18.2 tonnes in 1980 to 25.8 tonnes in 1983 and it is expected, in the very near future, to reach 100 tonnes annually. Exploration expenditure in the industry has increased from $68m in 1980-81 to $177m in 1984-85. This increase has been in the order of 150 per cent.

What these figures mean can be summed up in one word, and that word, of course, is `growth'. The industry is not only growing at a rate which is faster than for many other Australian industries, but it is expected to be able to continue that growth-in the event that there is no tax on gold. The Australian Gold Mining Council believes that by the end of 1987 an extra 8,000 people could be employed in the industry directly and in supporting industries. The imposition of a tax on gold would effectively reduce the profitability of the industry by half and jeopardise the growth in the industry. To attack the industry in this way would be particularly discriminatory when the assistance which was given to other industries is considered.

The Government estimates that the concession which is given to the gold mining industry is worth $100m per year. This, of course, pales into insignificance when it is compared with the amount of protection that is extended to two other industries. From 1977-78 protection in the clothing industry was increased by 35 per cent until in 1982-83 it had reached a massive $1,434,897,000. In the same period protection for the transport industry was increased by 31 per cent until in 1982-83 it had reached $1,262,847,000. So the Government is obviously prepared to extend increasing levels of protection to other industries to the point where the protection now costs almost $3,000m, or 30 times as much as the concession which it gives to the gold mining industry.

This does not reveal the true absurdity of the present Government's proposal, however. While employment in the gold mining industry is growing, employment in other industries such as the clothing and transport industries has been declining. The Government is, therefore, in the rather unbelievable position that it is prepared to provide increasing assistance to industries which are dying and to reduce assistance to industries which are growing, such as the gold mining industry.

Apart from the fact that to tax the gold mining industry would be to jeopardise its growth, there are other reasons which are peculiar to the industry and which lead to the conclusion that a tax on gold should not be imposed. One of these reasons is the way in which gold mining is financed. This should be compared with the financing of other mining operations such as coal, iron ore, other base metals and minerals. When a coal project, for instance, is started it is usual for a company involved to sign long term contracts to supply coal to an overseas consumer. There are a number of examples one could give in the coal mining industry, the iron ore industry, the bauxite industry, and in fact in most base metal industries, where long term contracts are able to be negotiated with the buyers. These contracts, of course, have fluctuating clauses which allow for renegotiation in the event that the economic circumstances in Australia vary one way or the other so as to impinge upon both the buyer or the seller.

Of course, gold is not sold in that way. Nobody ever signs a 10-year contract to supply gold. Though there is a developing futures market for gold and an increasing use of gold loans, the majority of gold that is sold in Australia is sold on the spot market. This immediately exposes gold producers to the fluctuations in the price of gold, and perhaps I will say more about that shortly if time allows.

Another implication of the industry being financed in this way is that, unlike the coal industry or other base metal industries, the prospective gold producer has no asset with which he can approach vendors and seek to borrow funds. Even the ultimate type of tenure, the type of title that is granted to a gold mining company, is quite separate and quite distinct from that which is granted to base metal and mineral mining companies. In Western Australia, for instance, in the iron ore industry, the State Government, by way of legislation, provides a special title for the iron ore companies so that they have security of tenure over the title and the deposit itself becomes an asset against which money can be borrowed and raised. That is not the case with gold mining companies. There have been a number of examples where gold mining companies, by accident, defaulted under the various State mining Acts and lost their leases. Inevitably this means that there is a high dependence on equity financing in the industry and, as I said earlier, if the investors who contribute the funds to these projects cannot see a sufficient return on their money, they will, of course, not invest.

Despite the high reliance on equity finance in the industry, there is some debt financing. A characteristic of the debt financing for the gold mining industry is that it is typically, naturally, short term. In the absence of an asset, such as a long term contract or a security of tenure, lenders are not prepared to extend long term financing to an industry such as gold. Loans are typically in the order of only three years. To service and repay loans which are over such a short term, gold mining companies must maintain naturally very high cash flows.

What, one might ask, will be the immediate impact of the introduction of a gold tax? Of course, it will be to reduce gold mining companies cash flows. In so doing, it will reduce the ability of the companies to service any debt commitments which they presently might have. What will be the response of the gold mining companies as they try to increase their levels of cash flows so as to meet their debt repayments? They must, of course, opt to mine only the high grade ore bodies and abandon the poorer grade ores even though these ores would otherwise have been profitable. This is an aspect of the introduction of a gold tax which few people outside the industry would consider. While many might recognise that reduced profitability through taxation might cause future investors to invest only in the higher grade mines, few would realise that it will have this impact on existing operations. It will do so as miners struggle to maintain higher cash flows to meet their debt commitments. Had time allowed I should have gone on to give further and better details in respect of this argument. Perhaps at a later time I will do so.

speech.speaker: Parer Sen W.R.

talk.start.para: â€”I wish to speak briefly about compulsory unionism and individual rights. I would like to refer in particular to one case of a Mr Bob Weir who lives in suburban Brisbane. I want to talk about Bob Weir because he is just simply one of thousands who have become caught up in compulsory unionism, in what could be described, in fact, as an illegal type of compulsory unionism, but who have been sent broke simply because of the power of the union movement itself. Mr Bob Weir was a trucker. He had two trucks. He drove one himself and for the other one he employed a driver. He was a member of the Transport Workers Union for 25 years. He is a man with a wife and two or three small children.

speech.para: In 1981 Mr Justice Northrop, in the Federal Court of Australia, ruled, in a case brought on by the Industrial Relations Bureau, that independent contractor owner-drivers were not eligible for membership in the Transport Workers Union of Australia. Justice Northrop gave the TWU three months to alter rule 4 of its membership rules, which it was unable to do. Consequently, Justice Northrop ruled that the owner-drivers were not eligible for membership of the TWU.

In October 1981 Bob Weir resigned from this union and, after attempts by certain factions within the TWU to have his resignation withdrawn, the Federal Council of the TWU ruled that the resignation was valid and must be accepted. Those factions then called on the Australian Council of Trade Unions for support against this-what they called-anti-unionist and his group who were attacking and could destroy the `very democracy of the trade union movement', to use their words. The ACTU agreed to support unions in their fight against these owner-drivers and many other small business personnel who dared to try to set up and conduct their businesses without paying the required protection money. That is all one could call it, because no longer were they supposed to be in the union anyway.

Mr Weir had contracts. One of his contracts was with the Sunday Sun in Brisbane. When he arrived at 2 o'clock one Sunday morning to pick up the newspapers, he was met by an official of the TWU called Hughie Williams, with a bunch of other heavies, who said to him: `Are you or are you not going to rejoin the union?' He said: `No, I am not because of the Northrop decision in the Federal Court. I do not have to; in fact it is illegal if I do'. They said: `Please yourself, but if you do not you are going to lose this contract'. He did not believe that could happen. He believed that we lived in a free country, so he decided he would not rejoin the union, having been a member for 25 years. On the departure of the trade union officials, he was approached by the management of the publishing house of the Sunday Sun. The way he tells it, he pulled up at a loading dock of the publishing house and was told by the management of the Sunday Sun that they could not speak with him within the premises because if they did there was a good possibility that there would be industrial disputation and no papers would be delivered. So he was spoken to in the car park of the premises and he was told in no uncertain terms that, because he would not join a union that Judge Nothrop said he should not join, his five-year contract would be terminated unless he paid his union dues.

He was in a dilemma and he really was not sure what to do. He was encouraged by others to stick to his guns and told that he would get support because he was legally correct in what he was doing. He did stick to his guns. The result is that Bob Weir has lost his business, has gone bankrupt, has lost both his trucks and cannot get a job-unless of course he goes back cap in hand and agrees to pay union dues to a union that he does not in fact need to join. We hear a lot about Amnesty International, which I believe is an excellent organisation. It looks at people that are oppressed in other countries. I suggest that what we need to do in Australia is look in our own back yard, because this is the sort of thing that should never be permitted to occur in Australia. If it does occur, if that sort of coercion, this sort of stand-over tactic, and this sort of blackmail, are allowed to go on without the people responsible for it being punished, there is something sadly wrong in Australia.

Mr Weir has used every legal avenue open to him. He has not stooped to the same sorts of practices that were placed upon him. He has used every legal avenue. Because of the way in which industrial law and so on is set up in Australia, the ordinary little guy like Bob Weir cannot pursue his case because he does not have the money. Unions like the TWU have the money to allow these things to go on for years and years. Either they send the person bankrupt first or his wife and family get so disturbed that he is forced to pay this protection money.

Is Mr Weir legally correct or is he not? Let me quote from an employment practices seminar held by the Trade Union Training Authority on 12 December 1984 in regard to this matter. The speaker was a Mr A. Boulton of the ACTU. A summary of his speech, which was entitled `Legal Implications', was as follows:
Unions lack a National strategy to deal with the growing area of sub-contracting and must have a mechanism available to enrol these areas.
There must be a regulation of rates, that is, a minimum standard which is enforceable by the Trade Union Movement.
The previous Labor Government--
the Whitlam Government-
amended section 132 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act which allowed Unions to enrol non-employees, however, that Legislation was subsequently changed by the Fraser Government.
Unions should pursue, through the ACTU for restoration of the previous provisions of section 132 of the Act.
This is the important statement to determine whether Bob Weir is right or wrong:

It was pointed out that the independent sub-contractors who were recruited into unions despite section 132 could lay open to challenge the result of union ballots if in fact these sub-contractors cast votes in the election.

Quite simply, Mr Weir is correct but what he is subject to is blatant abuse of a monopoly power. Compulsory unionism is a brutal reality in Australia today. It cannot be enforced by law but it is widely practised nonetheless. It is implemented and maintained simply by monopoly power. Although one of the marks of a free society is supposedly the protection of the individual and minority rights, Australian workers and thousands of people like Bob Weir have little protection for their freedom to choose not to join a trade union.

Peter Costello of the Victorian Bar has written an interesting article about this. To summarise his views, he indicates that the right to refuse to join a trade union is no less a basic and fundamental human right than is the right to join one. There are two sides to the coin. In each case the individual should be free to make his decision in exercise of his basic human right of freedom of association. This is a right contained in Article 20 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights adopted by the United Nations, which provides:
Everyone has the right to freedom of peaceful assembly and association. No one may be compelled to belong to an association.

Australian workers, however, have no statutory protection of this basic human right in the work place. When they choose not to join a trade union they are subject to vilification and harassment and in many cases they lose their livelihood as a result, as happened with Bob Weir. The denial of the basic human right of freedom of association is the norm in Australian industry today. In the face of union coercion there are few who are able to exercise what should be their democratic birth right in Australia. Unions do not leave the question of membership to a matter of individual choice. They use the most brutal methods to enforce compulsory membership and thereby guarantee union income through membership fees and the continuance of a monopoly in the labour market which is no different from the monopoly in any other market.

Trade unions run what amounts today to no more than a protection racket in Australian industry. The gentleman to whom I have referred, as I indicated at the beginning of this speech, is simply a symbol of thousands and thousands of people throughout Australia. His experience, which has been carried out in a most illegal and brutal way and for which he has no come-back, is a testimony to this.

speech.speaker: Archer Sen B.R.

talk.start.para: â€”I take the opportunity to raise the alarming state of affairs in the meteorology services. We have been going through a progressive reduction in services and staff, a deterioration of equipment, and a falling behind in the various technologies that go with the provision of these services. There are four particular factors that need to be taken into account in Australia as far as meteorology services are concerned: Firstly, the relative isolation in the world of the continent; secondly, the vast variety of climatic conditions and types that pertain from one end of the continent to the other; thirdly, the use of the services of the Bureau of Meteorology by industry, particularly primary industry; and, fourthly, the use of aerial transport in Australia, which is far higher than in any other country of the world.

speech.para: We used to have a service that was envied in most countries. We had very wide participation by people from all around the nation. That, because of cost, has had to be curtailed; and I accept that that is the case. But it has not been replaced with a system that is as good or as efficient, or is any better. The complaints that have been coming forward and the discussions that have been raised have not been as a result of some high pressure group working within the Bureau. They have not come from a group of public servants looking after their own ends or a union trying to do a bit of head hunting. They have come from a whole variety of areas, not the least of which, of course, is the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones), who is very well aware of the problem but does not seem to be able to muster the support to have anything done about it. In the annual report of the Bureau earlier this year the Director, Dr Zillman, made some very pertinent comments about the problems that he was suffering. In the last few days we have had a report from the Meteorology Policy Committee, which again is not stacked with Bureau officials but which comprises Dr Tegart, the Secretary to the Department of Science; Dr Zillman, the Director; Mr Hollings, the editor-in-chief of the Australian; Dr Smith, Chairman of the Accreditation Board of Advanced Education in Victoria; Mr Stuart of the Mount Newman mining iron ore project; and Mr Yates, Chief Executive of Qantas Airways Ltd. These people have the job of making recommendations as to meteorology policy and they have made some very alarming comments in their report. I believe that it signifies the state of affairs and the very urgent need to ensure that the country is adequately covered. The service is falling back and I think we should all realise that. We should be able to place enough importance on the safety aspects of this to see that we do not get into real trouble.

We have had so many reports. I am not sure how many more we are going to have, but we do not need any more reports to tell us what is wrong. Doing nothing is not one of the options open to us. I know that to provide a service costs money, but I also know that not to supply the service will cost us even more. To have no information or wrong information is very expensive indeed. We only have to look at the report to which I have just referred to see that, on an annual basis, it is estimated that Australia loses $540m through cyclones, severe storms, floods or fires.

The situation is worse than that because the Bureau of Meteorology has now started to issue qualified forecasts. With the services and resources available, it is no longer able to guarantee that the information it gives is correct. I had not really expected that we would ever reach that stage, but the equipment and the staff have been running down over many years. I am not saying that it has just suddenly happened, but we are finding that some of the equipment is now very old, is very run down and is being propped up and patched up in all sorts of ways. I remind the Senate that the Bureau has 64 radar systems, 23 of which are over 20 years old and 40 of which are over 15 years old. Sixteen of the automatic weather stations are now over 18 years old, and four of the satellite receiving stations, which are regarded as up to date equipment, are over 16 years old already.

A program put down has indicated that it needs $33.5m over the next five years to get up to date-$25m for standard re-equipment and $8.5m for the re-equipment of the severe weather forecasting system, that to do with cyclones, particularly in the northern part of the country. The Policy Committee warned that, unless these resources were provided, a major breakdown in the Bureau's fragile infrastructure could occur, with serious implications for life and limb as a real possibility.

I do not think that we have the capacity here to ignore statements such as that from an independent body whose job it is to advise on these matters. When I asked a question of Senator Button yesterday, he said yes, he was aware that the matter had been raised and that it would be viewed in a budgetary context. I believe that it is a matter that should be determined and automatically fitted into a Budget, if it is found that these claims and comments are justified.

We have very severe weather conditions all round Australia. We have fires, floods, cyclones and severe storms and we need to make sure that the people in the areas of Australia where these occur are given a reasonable degree of forecasting and a reasonable opportunity to take the sorts of actions that are necessary. The keeping of records is not as good as it should be, to plan for the future. We need to be able to make sure that, as the need arises, so it can be met. I have had a considerable number of comments from people around Australia and I expect that a lot more would contact us if they realised the state of affairs as they now are. I am not soliciting comments and I do not wish to raise this as a matter of discontent against the Minister in any way because I believe that he is doing what he can, but I do make an appeal to the Government. I urge the Government to realise the absolute importance of upgrading.

So much of the expendables used by the Bureau of Meteorology, of course, are imported. With the falling dollar, the cost of this equipment has already risen 50 per cent in the last three years. This has been met by cuts in staff or failure to replace equipment, and we cannot keep going in that direction. We need to encourage Australian industry to produce some of these expendables so that we do not have to buy them from overseas. The Budget is still quite a long way off when it comes to getting something started. If we are going to wait until the Budget comes down and then start to look at what we are going to do in the next five-year plan, it is going to take a lot longer and become even more expensive. I ask the Government for a statement of commitment, with a financial commitment to match it. I ask that that be proceeded with without delay.
Sitting suspended from 1.48 to 2 p.m.

question.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: â€”I address a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I remind him that yesterday he nominated high interest rates and doubts about the currency as the reasons for the drop in private sector investment. Does he accept that wage costs and the level of expectations about future wage costs can also play an important part in investment decisions by business and industry? I ask him whether he agrees with the Treasurer's senior economic adviser, Dr Barry Hughes, that the gap between Australian and overseas wage outcomes has begun to open and, to quote Dr Hughes:

question.para: If left unchecked, this gradual erosion of our competitive gains will threaten investment at a time when, unsettled by adverse twists of the terms of trade, we need it most.
Will the Government take action to see that the gap narrows by ensuring further discounting of wages in the current wage case and beyond, as necessary?

talk.start.para: â€”I certainly nominated interest rates and the other thing in yesterday's Question Time as being factors which might inhibit investment. I think the factors which lead to investment decisions are basically questions of continuity and predictability-continuity in the sense that when the investment rewards are, hopefully, to be reaped there will be a good inflation rate, good wage outcomes and all those things in the Australia economy. I certainly agree that wage costs are a factor which is relevant to the question of investment. I agree entirely with what Dr Barry Hughes said. Insofar as the last part of the honourable senator's question is concerned, the Government is addressing those issues at present and I really do not feel free to make a statement about them at this stage.

â€”I refer the Minister for Education to the article in today's Canberra Times concerning the Canberra College of Advanced Education. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the current situation concerning accreditation at the college? Is it a fact that the Minister is at loggerheads with the college over accreditation procedures, as expressed in the article?

â€”I am not at loggerheads with the Canberra College of Advanced Education, nor has my Department any disagreement with it, and there is no problem concerning accreditation of courses. Despite the various reports in the Canberra Times to the contrary, everything I have just said is the case. This matter was the subject of some questions yesterday at Question Time and further comments by Senator Teague. In response to Senator Teague, I undertook to have the allegations in the Canberra Times further investigated. I now have for the information of honourable senators a detailed statement on this matter and also a statement from Dr Parfitt, who is the Principal of the Canberra College of Advanced Education. I seek leave to incorporate these statements in Hansard.
â€”Is leave granted?

interject.speaker: Senator Chaney

talk.start.para: â€”The Opposition is happy to grant leave if the documents can be tabled and also made available now because, in light of the fact that there were questions yesterday, we would like to see the statements now rather than in Hansard tomorrow.

interject.para: Leave granted.
The statements read as follows-
Statement by Minister for Education
ACCREDITATION AT THE CCAE
I undertook yesterday to provide a statement on matters relating to the accreditation of courses at the Canberra College of Advanced Education.

Formal accreditation of courses at the CCAE is my responsibility. I am advised in this matter by a part-time Committee, the Commonwealth Institutions Accreditation Committee for Advanced Education. The Committee in turn appoints expert assessment panels to assess individual course accreditation proposals put by the College. The Committee has responsibility, not just for the CCAE but also for advanced education courses at the Australian Maritime College; Signadou College of Education; the Canberra School of Music; the Canberra School of Art; the Australian Film and Television School; the RAN College at Jervis Bay; the RAAF Academy at Point Cook; and HMAS Cerberus. The Committee and its panels are serviced by secretariat staff from my Department. There is a significant degree of interaction between the College, the Committee, panels and staff in the course of the processes.

The accreditation process, which is the vital assurance of the quality of advanced education courses to the College, students, employers and the general community, is a cyclical process. Not only are new courses required to be submitted for accreditation but existing courses that are to be continued are reaccredited every five years. The processes applied in Commonwealth institutions are the same as those applied in State institutions under nationally agreed guidelines laid down by the Australian Council on Tertiary Awards. The only difference with the CCAE, which operates to its advantage in mounting courses, is that the College may begin to offer courses prior to their accreditation. The Committee and the College recognise that the accreditation process, properly and effectively carried out, will take 12 months.

The CCAE has entered a cyclical phase where a very large number of courses are coming due for reaccreditation. The College has advised that 88 of its 115 courses are due for accreditation or reaccreditation before the end of 1987. This imposes a very heavy workload on the College and its staff, the Committee, its panels and its Secretariat.

There have been delays in the accreditation processes; these delays have arisen from any large number of factors including the timeliness of accreditation submissions, the quality of submissions, the consideration of submissions by the Committee, the appointment of panels and arrangement of their visits to the College, the drafting of panel reports, the timing of their consideration by the College and the Committee and the making of recommendations for accreditation. I am advised that courses accredited to date in 1985-86 have taken on average, 15 months.

It was in recognition of the complexity of these processes and the mounting pressure of the number of courses requiring consideration that action has been taken by the College, the Committee and the Department to facilitate the processes.

The College has readjusted its internal handling of accreditation submissions to improve timeliness of submissions and their quality. The Committee has looked to streamlining its processes for the appointment of panels and receipt of their reports and for handling short-term extensions of accreditation. The Department has increased the resources available to the Committee by providing three secretariat staff instead of one as was the case in early 1985 and by seeking increased funding for establishment of panels through the budget processes.

These matters were discussed by the College and the Committee at a meeting on 22 May. I am informed that the discussions were co-operative and fruitful and that agreement was reached on the measures adopted to enable accreditation to be completed within twelve months.

The College, the committee and the Department have worked hard to ensure the successful resolution of accreditation matters and I regret the fact that certain unknown elements have sought to bring the processes into disrepute. This does them no credit, whatever their motives may be. It certainly does not call into question the whole process of accreditation. As I said yesterday, and I reiterate now, accreditation is an important assurance of quality to the College, community, students and employers. It is a nationally accepted process that will be maintained. While the accreditation process will continue, the means by which it is carried through may change. In this context I approved in April this year a revised set of procedures which will enable the College to eventually arrange its own assessment processes should it so wish. Those procedures will be available to the College after they have been considered by the Australian Council on Tertiary Awards at its June 1986 meeting. Again, this move is in line with similar developments in the States.

All courses submitted by the College for accreditation or reaccreditation up to November 1985 have been assessed by panels. All courses received after that date and up till the end of May 1986 will be assessed by panels before the end of this year.
If honourable Senators require further details a senior officer of my Department is available to assist.
Statement by Dr Parfitt
CANBERRA COLLEGE OF ADVANCED EDUCATION ACCREDITATION-REACCREDITATION OF COURSE

In the editions of the Canberra Times of the 4th and 5th June 1986 there have been reports of problems regarding procedures for the accreditation and reaccreditation of courses at the Canberra College of Advanced Education. As far as the College is concerned this is not an issue of substance. There is no controversy between the College and the Department of Education on this issue. We are not at `loggerheads'.

In a valuable discussion with the Minister for Education this afternoon I confirmed comments that I had made earlier. What few problems there were with accreditation procedures have been resolved by constructive discussions between the accrediting agency of the CIACAE, the Department of Education and the College. We are indeed most grateful for the manner in which the Minister's Department has assisted in rendering more effective and efficient the accreditation process.

The accreditation procedure is an important facet of higher education, it helps maintain high and uniform standards across the country. Accreditation guarantees the high standing and quality of the Canberra College of Advanced Education's courses.
I can confirm that no student has been disadvantaged by any delays there may have been in accreditation procedures.
Dr R. T. Parfitt

question.speaker: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is also directed to the Minister for Education. I ask the Minister whether she agrees with the following view expressed by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce:

question.para: Our education and training system has largely abstracted itself from the needs of industry and commerce, leaving much of its output without the necessary basic skills. But more significantly the vast majority leave school with only a mental void concerning industry and business.

Does the Minister share Senator Button's reported concern about the enormous deficiencies in the education system-a system which, as Senator Button implies, fails to address the hard disciplines and has led to environmental studies, peace studies, women's studies and film appreciation being favoured as subjects over maths, English or physics?

answer.speaker: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

talk.start.para: â€”It is certainly true that I, like Senator Button and, I think, all other Ministers in this Government, am very well aware of the need for improvements and changes in education at all levels, not just at the school level, if education is to make a proper contribution to economic growth and development. That is a view which, I think, I first stated at the National Economic Summit shortly after we came into office and it was a view based on the gap between various education systems and the needs of the labour market and industry which was very apparent to us when we took over the administration of this country in 1983. Since that time I have taken a number of initiatives which I believe are starting to overcome that gap, and I have had the co-operation of my colleague Senator Button in these exercises.

answer.para: It would take up a great deal of the time of the Senate if I were to detail all those initiatives, but I point, for example, to a meeting I had with a committee of the Business Council of Australia two days ago at which the committee and I agreed on a number of new steps, such as regular liaison between the education committees of the Business Council of Australia and my Department and commissions, the appointment of more people from industry and more people with business backgrounds to various education committees, committees of review and inquiry, and regular consultation with the Business Council of Australia and other industry groups on major developments in education, such as the current Commonwealth review of tertiary and further education funding and the efficiency and effectiveness review of higher education which is nearing completion. I think these steps demonstrate the seriousness of our intention to bring schools, education institutions and industry closer together. I believe that we will see benefits from that in the near future.

With regard to Senator Button's reported remark about the unpreparedness of many young people on leaving school for the world of work and their lack of knowledge about the world of work, there have been specific responses to that. The Curriculum Development Centre is developing curriculum material around the subject of the world of work and in several of the State systems, particularly in Victoria in response to the Blackburn report, a core subject for senior secondary students on the world of work is being developed. So I think Senator Puplick can be satisfied, as I know Senator Button is satisfied, that steps are being taken at the Commonwealth level but also at the State level to overcome these deficiencies.

With regard to the last part of Senator Puplick's question, I do not think it is useful to get into a slanging match about the choices of subjects that students might take. I think it is perfectly possible, for example, for students to study physics, mathematics and environmental studies, should they wish. I think it is perfectly possible for the study of peace issues to be incorporated into traditional subjects, such as history or economics. I do not think it is useful to suggest that it is an either/or situation, that students must opt either for physics and mathematics and no subjects from the humanities or the reverse. What I would like to see is as broad an education as possible for all students, which would prepare them specifically for the work force and higher education but also to make a constructive contribution to living in a democratic society, to which some of those subjects pertain.

question.speaker: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

talk.start.para: â€”Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Let me put again the central part of my question: I ask the Minister whether she agrees with the following words in the text of Senator Button's statement:

question.para: . . . the vast majority leave school with only a mental void concerning industry and business.

talk.start.para: â€”I do not think I could agree that the vast majority do. I would need a better database than I have available to me to agree with that. Certainly too many students leave school not understanding the world of work and, for that reason, the Commonwealth is undertaking the measures that I have just described.

â€”Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures issued today on savings bank depositors' balances? If so, can he comment on these figures and can he say whether they indicate that the Government's interest rate strategy for home loans is working?

answer.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: â€”The answer to the last part of the question is that certainly on the deposit side of savings banks it is working. The April figures show that savings bank deposits increased in seasonally adjusted terms by a massive $2,157m. Granted, about $400m could be attributed to an interest payment being credited to accounts in April rather than May, as would normally have been done. But at a net figure of, say, $1,700m, and looking back over the figures for the previous 14 or 15 months, in no other month over that period have deposits increased by more than $392m. So there has certainly been a massive increase in savings bank deposits in that month, almost certainly heavily related to the fact that interest rate ceilings for new lendings have been lifted and that savings banks have been able to offer more competitive interest rates to depositors.

answer.para: It is also true-while answering this question I think I should note this-that residential building approvals for the month of April have not yet turned up. That is not surprising because one would always expect a time lag of some duration, probably several months, between changes in the availability of finance and in building approvals.

talk.start.para: â€”I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Health: Did he see comments by Dr John Pierce of Sydney University that a survey had shown that 21 per cent of young people would use the drug cocaine if a friend offered it to them? Has the Government noticed Dr Pierce's comments that cocaine has been glamourised in films and television and that young people believe it is not addictive? Will the Government act immediately to inform the community about the rapid and inevitable addictivity of cocaine; the problems such as very severe depression that accompany withdrawal from the drug and the fact that higher doses can be lethal? Finally, will the Government now include cocaine in its national drugs offensive?

answer.speaker: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Health has given me some information on the article in the survey on which that article was based which I think will assist Senator Mason and other senators. The survey was conducted and commented on by Drs Pierce and Levy in the Medical Journal of Australia in the last week or two. It was funded by the national campaign against drug abuse. It comprised a sample of 1,000 14 to 19-year-olds in Sydney. It confirmed that very few young Australians had ever tried or knew anybody who had tried cocaine. The article focused on the response to one question in which 7.8 per cent of the young people surveyed, rising to 21 per cent of the 19-year-olds, who numbered 123, said they might-I repeat they might, not that they would-try the drug if offered it by a trusted friend. From this survey the article suggests that there exists a potential demand for cocaine which would easily be taken up if increased supply of the drug became available. However, honourable senators should know that this is not the only information which we have from research which was commissioned as part of the national campaign.

answer.para: A survey of 2,800 people on attitudes to drug abuse conducted for the national campaign against drug abuse shows that cocaine is perceived by young people to be nearly as dangerous as heroin and the likelihood that a young person will experiment with it is within two percentage points of the result of Dr Pierce's survey for the likelihood of experimentation with heroin. The national survey showed that only 3 per cent of 14 to 19-year-olds would try cocaine if it were offered to them by a trusted friend. As well, most young people within that survey, some 90 per cent, see cocaine as a very dangerous drug. It should be noted that the 21 per cent figure that has been quoted relates only to 19-year-olds. To infer from the response of one age group that behaviour contrary to the behaviour reported from the whole of a sample would occur is to distort the results of that survey. Over the whole age population surveyed the figure is very much lower and Dr Pierce's survey actually shows that overall a very much smaller number of persons in the 14 to 19-year-old age group might try cocaine if offered it by a trusted friend. This is very similar to the data obtained from the national survey which gave a figure of 3 per cent for this age group.

I am sure there will be continuing academic argument as to whether the results of one small survey in one metropolitan area should be used as a basis for general conclusions on national trends. However, left to the Minister for Health, honourable senators can be assured that the national policy on cocaine, including the use of the media to counter abuse of the drug, is currently being addressed by the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy, the body which has the overall carriage of the whole national campaign, including the drug offensive.

At its meeting on 2 May, the health and law enforcement Ministers from all States, Territories and the Commonwealth put in train measures to enable a national approach to cocaine abuse to be developed and implemented. Agreement was reached that the Commonwealth would be supplied with data from treatment agencies, hospitals and other sources within the States and Territories, no later than July 1986 on the real, not the surveyed, extent of problems of cocaine abuse in Australia.

Statistical surveys like this do show trends and are useful in anticipating what national trends may be in the use of drugs such as cocaine. We do not need national surveys to tell us that cocaine is a dangerous drug; we do not need national surveys to tell us that there are the problems to which Senator Mason has referred such as depression--

talk.start.para: â€”Mr President, I raise a point of order. This answer is much more in the nature of a statement on a matter which is of great public concern. The Minister is well on to his second page of closely-typed material. I suggest that if the Government wishes to make a statement on this matter it should do so in the normal way and allow some opportunity for debate. The very lengthy answer to the question is quite inappropriate for Question Time.

â€”Mr President, on the point of order: I can assure Senator Chaney that I am not on to the second page of closely typewritten pages at all. At the moment I am finishing the answer to the question all on my own without reading anything from the paper. If I had read from the answer that was given to me I would be going on to a third page of closely typewritten material. All I am saying, as Senator Chaney says, is that it is an important question, that the drug does cause the problems that Senator Mason talks about such as depression, and problems with withdrawal that are lethal--
â€”Order! Is the Minister still referring to the point of order?
â€”No. I am ignoring his point of order, Mr President.

â€”I cannot ignore the point of order even though the Minister might want to. There is no point of order. As the Leader of the Opposition would know, the Chair has no discretion as to the time limit on questions or answers. If the Senate wants to impose time limits it should take the matter to the Standing Orders Committee.

â€”Again I am aware of the problems and honourable senators should be aware of the problems associated with cocaine abuse that were alluded to by Senator Mason, including problems that he did not allude to, problems in the nasal area and nasofacial area. The fact that the Federal Minister and the State Ministers are bringing into train that part of the drug offensive to refer to cocaine should give Senator Mason and us all some heart. We have plenty of information, particularly from the United States of America, on the evils and dangers of the use of cocaine. I think cocaine will receive the prominence that Senator Mason wants it to achieve in the drug offensive in this country.

â€”I ask a supplementary question. The Minister in his comprehensive answer, for which I thank him, did leave out one rather important point which I think is very valid. I asked for the Minister's comments on the fact that cocaine has been glamourised in film and television programs shown and telecast regularly in this country, which I personally think is an iniquitous situation.

â€”I am not aware of the programs that Senator Mason knows about; I obviously do not watch enough television. Cocaine should not be glamourised in that way. I would have thought in more recent times the very real dangers of cocaine have also been broadcast on national television in this country. Prominent people such as actors and prominent American sportsmen who have got into difficulties with cocaine have been seen giving their stories. I think that more emphasis should be placed on this. I think that any attempt by the national media to use any material which glamourises cocaine is to be abhorred. I will refer that matter to the Minister for Health and, in fact, to the Minister for Communications.

question.block.title: UNITED STATES WARSHIPS: VISITS TO AUSTRALIA

talk.start.para: â€”My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. I ask: Has the Minister seen recent reports in the Australian newspaper stating on the one hand that United States officials are claiming that the Hawke Government has been discouraging United States warship visits to Australia, and on the other hand the statement by a senior Pentagon official that the United States wants more warship visits to Australia and the South Pacific `if they will accept us'? As I come from Western Australia which gets around two-thirds of United States warship visits to this country, can the Minister say whether we will get fewer warships in the future or whether we are going to accede to the demands from the Pentagon and get more? Finally, may I ask the Minister whether he knows why the United States is increasing its warship activity in the Indian Ocean and wants more port calls to Australia when its own Department of Defense publication entitled Soviet Military Power concedes that the Soviet naval presence in the Indian Ocean actually has decreased in the last few years?

â€”I am aware of the newspaper articles to which Senator Vallentine referred. They were written by Peter Samuel-another right wing ideologue like David Barnett-whose indifference to the truth and willingness actively to perpetuate error, even when the truth is pointed out to him, is in exactly the same class as that gentleman who was entirely appropriately dealt with by my colleague Senator Walsh yesterday.

â€”Mr President, I rise on a point of order. Is there no standing order that will protect members of the public against this kind of attack under privilege? If there is not, is there any standard of good behaviour and reasoned conduct that should stop the Minister from behaving in this way?
â€”Order! The Minister is not offending Standing Orders.

â€”Mr Richard Armitage, the Assistant Secretary for Defense in the United States, has told Australian officials that he said nothing of the sort represented by Peter Samuel in the article. Moreover, he had checked and no one else with any authority--
â€”The failed Attorney-General.
â€”A failing leader and a sanctimonious little wimp to go with it.
â€”Order! I ask the Minister to withdraw that remark.

â€”Mr President, I withdraw and continue the answer. Moreover, Mr Armitage has advised the Australian Government that he had checked and that no one else with any authority to speak on these matters had given Samuel advice of the sort he claimed to have had from the Pentagon.
â€”The failed Attorney-General.

â€”Mr President, I raise a point of order. Quite properly, Mr President, you have drawn the attention of the Senate to my behaviour on a lot of occasions. However, the Leader of the Opposition is continually interjecting. He really should have a better sense of his own responsibility.
â€”Order! I hope that the Chair does not need any assistance in the control of conduct of honourable senators in this place. I ask Senator Chaney to restrict his interjections.

â€”Mr President, the failure of the Standing Orders to cover the incessant bloody rudeness of this Government and its attacks on people who are not protected by the Standing Orders make it very difficult to prevent interjections. I think there has been a most disgraceful use of the Parliament over the last two days.
â€”Order! There is no point of order.

â€”Mr President, I wish to speak on the point of order. I make the point that I well remember the instance of this Parliament when that honourable gentleman and knight of the realm, Senator Sir John Carrick, stood in this place and for 15 minutes or so in Question Time abused Professor Manning Clark. I did not hear Senator Chaney, Senator Peter Baume or any of their colleagues rise to the defence of Professor Manning Clark at that time. I think that demonstrates their double standards and the reasons why you should ignore Senator Chaney's point of order.

â€”Order! I have already ruled that there is no point of order. However, I ask honourable senators on both sides of the chamber to respect the dignity of this place and the decorum that should go with it.

â€”I repeat that Mr Armitage has advised the Australian Government that the Samuel article was incorrect in every particular and misleading. He further said that, as we would know, there had been no request from the Australian side for the reduction of ship visits and nor was any consideration being given to any such reduction. I add further, on behalf of the Minister for Defence, that the pattern and frequency of visits is primarily a function of operational factors. The Australian Government must, of course, individually approve each request for a foreign warship to visit its ports. As Mr Beazley said on 11 October last year, Australia and the United States are examining options for increasing the spread of United States ship visits to Australia-a proposal which the United States supports. The implementation of this proposal will, of course, be influenced by operational factors. There is no increasing trend in the United States of America warship activity in the Indian Ocean.

â€”I ask the Minister for Education whether she supports moves within the Labor Party to extend significantly the areas of accountability to increase greatly the detail required to be provided to the Government by non-government schools? More specifically, will she at next month's Australian Labor Party National Conference be supporting the proposed changes to Party policy which will require, among other things, schools to provide details on employment and exclusion policies, school policy making structures and the value of capital assets?

â€”Most of Senator Newman's question is out of order. It is not in order for her to ask the Minister for Education about Australian Labor Party matters. I certainly do not propose to inform Senator Newman, or any other Opposition senators in this place, about a Party matter. However, on the general point of improved accountability procedures I can say that there have been improved accountability procedures carried out and put in place for this year and for 1987. Those procedures were put in place after extensive consultation by the Commonwealth Schools Commission and the Commonwealth Department of Education with all relevant groups. Just yesterday I had a meeting with the National Council of Independent Schools representatives who said that they were not dissatisfied with the new procedures. After those procedures are in place for two years there will be further consideration given to further recommendations on accountability matters which were made in last year's Commonwealth Schools Commission report. The matter of accountability is a very important one. Our Government takes very seriously its responsibility to account for the use of Commonwealth funds. The area of education is no exception to this. I am pleased that accountability procedures have been strengthened and improved. I believe that they have been done so in a way that will benefit the non-government school sector and not be to its disbenefit in any way. Should there appear any difficulty with the new procedures the matters will be looked at again.

question.speaker: Coleman Sen R.N.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I ask: Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a full page advertisement in this morning's Sun newspaper regarding a protest meeting held in Melbourne at noon today protesting against the fringe benefits tax? In that advertisement it is stated:

question.para: It is outrageous that this new tax is being imposed on business rather than employees.
I ask: Does the Minister care to comment on that statement and its accuracy?

answer.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: â€”I have seen the advertisement in question. It is headed `Tax revolt rally today' and is inserted by the Australian Small Business Association and the Australian Federation of Employers-which, if I remember correctly, is the organisation of which that former Sir Phillip Lynch staffer, Andrew Hay, is the President. Of course, similar calls have come in the last couple of weeks from the Premier of Queensland; the President of the National Farmers Federation, Ian McLachlan; Andrew Hay; Katharine West; and Des Keegan. Indeed, they have been coming from a range of political opinion from the rabid Right to the far Right. Often they have been backed up with calls to defy the law and not pay the tax. The most common and erroneous assertion concerns the question of whether the tax should be levied on the employer or on the employee and the alleged moral and administrative ramifications of that.

answer.para: As well as the rabid to the ratbag right, to which I have already referred, there are other more responsible business groups that have complained about the tax on that ground, completely unaware, obviously, of the fact that to impose the liability on the employee would increase the complexity of the tax because all of the valuation rules and substantiation procedures which are contained in the fringe benefits tax legislation would still be required if the Government had chosen to tax the employee under section 26 (e) of the Income Tax Assessment Act. There would, however, have been additional requirements on the employer to identify fringe benefits for each individual employee and to make PAYE deductions each fortnight, or even each week, rather than simply to pay quarterly as with the fringe benefits tax.

All of that was detailed in the draft White Paper published just over a year ago on pages 88 and 89, if anyone wants to refer to it, but it appears to have been conveniently forgotten by the groups to which I have referred and the Opposition. PAYE is relevant to the general claim that the tax should be levied on the employee rather than the employer. If we taxed the PAYE employee, the employer would still be legally required to calculate, withhold and pay the fringe benefits tax as the employer is currently required to calculate, withhold and pay the income tax due on wages.

Another claim is that the tax burden would be less on the employer if it was taxed through that route and not through the fringe benefits tax. There is probably some truth in that, but not very much. Under either approach, the actual outcome of who finally bears the cost depends very much on the extent to which the burden is shared between the employer and the employee. But it is ludicrous to assume that if the section 26 (e) route had been taken-that is, using the present Income Tax Assessment Act-that outcome would have been substantially different.

In short, the choice between taxing the employee and the employer is not a choice between extremes other than in the very short term in its final distribution and cost. The fringe benefits tax has administrative advantages for all. A final point: It might be noted that it would be highly unlikely, if not impossible, to have been able to exempt charities had the Government chosen to tax the employee for the fringe benefits being received.

interject.speaker: The PRESIDENT

talk.start.para: â€”I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the far gallery on my right of a former Deputy President of the Senate, Mr Ron Maunsell. On behalf of all honourable senators, I extend to Mr Maunsell a warm and hearty welcome upon his return to Canberra.

interject.para: Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

talk.start.para: â€”Will the Minister for Education join with the Association of Classroom Teachers in the Australian Capital Territory in rejecting the call by the Australian Capital Territory Teachers Federation for an end to interest subsidies to non-government schools in the Territory?
â€”The Government has no plans to change funding arrangements for non-government schools in the Australian Capital Territory.

â€”I direct my question to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Has the Minister seen reported comments of Dr Jackson of the Bond Corporation that the import parity pricing formula underprices Australian oil, to the detriment of Australian producers and the future of the Australian exploration industry? Does he agree that there is underpricing and that the formula needs revision?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: â€”Yes, I have seen that report. Indeed, I have had quite a deal of correspondence from Dr Jackson on that subject. The situation is this: Since the cessation of spot trading of Arab light crude oil early this year, a proxy formula, based on the movement in spot prices for a basket of four Middle East crudes, namely Muscat, Oman, Dubai and Qatar, has been adopted for determining the import parity price for indigenous Australian crude oil. The most recent adjustment has been from 1 June. The Bass Strait IPP is currently $A20.04 per barrel, which is based on a price of that proxy for Arab light of $US12.45 per barrel.

answer.para: There have been various recent reports, including one from the International Energy Agency, that netback prices for Arab light crude oil were in the range of $US15 to $US16 per barrel. However, what has to be understood and what has been overlooked by people such as Dr Jackson who relied on this $US15 to $US16 figure that is in wide circulation is that netback prices cannot be calculated with any great degree of certainty owing to very wide fluctuations in product prices on which they are based and the variety of calculations which come into account. A particularly relevant consideration is that netback prices for a typical Saudi Arabian netback transaction involve a lag of 50 days in the date of lifting to product price assessments on which final payments are based. Some delay from the date of receipt of the data to publication is also common. So the actual prices quoted in early to mid-April for Saudi netback transactions therefore almost certainly refer to liftings which were made right back at the end of January or early February. A relevant comparison is between spot crude oil prices in January-February and netback prices quoted in April.

What all of that means is that the relevant spot prices have, in fact, been above, or at least similar to, netback prices. It simply cannot be claimed that the import parity price, based on the basket of spot prices, is in any way undervaluing Australian crude oil. I wrote to Dr Jackson and some other producer representatives in these terms a few days ago, and I hope that this situation does not continue to be misunderstood, understandable though that misunderstanding, I acknowledge, is.

talk.start.para: â€”I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In view of the ludicrous proposal to take from the business sector some $400m-that is the Government's figure-as a result of the fringe benefits tax and $10m from the capital gains tax, can the Minister inform the Senate what is the anticipated amount the Government now intends to give back to the business sector under the subsidised interest rates for loans proposal which, according to a report in the Sydney Morning Herald, is designed to encourage business to invest and which was agreed to by the Prime Minister and business?

â€”The Government has made no decision on the question of subsidised interest rates for anybody other than the heavy engineering industry, in respect of which a package of assistance has been agreed. As to the $400m which Senator Walters refers to as a gain from the fringe benefits tax, a wide range of benefits have been conferred on the business sector in alterations of taxation regimes which certainly equal that amount and probably exceed it. I refer, for example, to the cost of imputation which will be introduced, to the very substantial tax cuts which will be introduced for people in the higher income brackets and, more particularly, to the 150 per cent tax concession for research and development, which will be an expensive cost to revenue, just as the vastly improved depreciation regime is a--
â€”It is ineffectual for small business.

â€”No, it is not ineffectual for small business. The honourable senator should not be so silly if she can help it. That will be of great cost to the revenue over a period. I must in all fairness say to the honourable senator that the Fraser Government proposed to introduce such a depreciation regime in its last year of office for the very same reasons as we have done so. If honourable senators ask me questions, I would find them more challenging if they were better informed.

question.block.title: STATE RAIL AUTHORITY OF NEW SOUTH WALES

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Veterans' Affairs will be aware of a recent change of policy in the State Rail Authority of New South Wales, which now has withdrawn credit facilities from the Commonwealth and refuses to accept Commonwealth travel warrants for travel in New South Wales. Will the Minister outline his reaction to this situation? Have alternative arrangements been negotiated which do not disadvantage veterans who normally travel on SRA services?

â€”It is true that the State Rail Authority of New South Wales has changed the system under which veterans with entitlements to visit repatriation hospitals or the Grace Building for the purpose of medical examinations and so on have been able to travel with the provision of a warrant by the Commonwealth Government through the Department of Veterans' Affairs. That system has been changed by the State Rail Authority and there have been a few hiccups in the implementation of the new system. I can advise Senator Richardson that the Department has now brought into force a new procedure whereby the veteran will be issued with a cheque by the Department made out to the State Rail Authority. The State Rail Authority has agreed to accept that arrangement for travel by rail or air, depending on the circumstances of each of the travel arrangements. The State Rail Authority has introduced this new system in an attempt to contain administrative costs and we can applaud that. We apologise to the people who have been affected by the new arrangements. However, I am sure that the new system will work to the advantage of veterans.

â€”I address my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is the Minister considering an Industries Assistance Commission inquiry into the problems of the mining and metals processing sector arising from government regulation and taxes? If so, will the reference to the IAC be a policy prescriptive one, similar to the IAC inquiry currently taking place on petroleum products, and thereby seek possible options to eliminate impediments to the competitiveness of the sector? Has the Minister or anyone else consulted with the mining and metal industries on the proposed inquiry? Is there anything holding up giving the reference?

â€”The Government is considering a reference on the mining industry to the Industries Assistance Commission. This has been the subject of consultation between myself, senior officers of the Department of Resources and Energy, for which Senator Evans has responsibility, and the Industries Assistance Commission. It is not intended that it be a policy reference. It is essentially a reference which will establish a better information base in relation to the mining industry and the effects of particular policies on the mining industry. It is essentially in that term an information reference. That is the way the IAC would prefer to conduct such a reference. The honourable senator asked whether anyone has consulted with the mining industry. The answer to that question is, I believe, yes.
â€”I ask a supplementary question. Is anything holding up the reference? If so, when is the reference likely to be given?

â€”I do not know what the honourable senator means by `holding up'. There are a few administrative procedures to be gone through between the decision to hold the reference and the ultimate referral of the matter to the IAC. That is happening at the present time. But I do not quite understand the expression `holding up'; I just do not understand that. I suppose it has been held up for about 50 years. But now that the decision has been made, it is not being held up.

â€”Has the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation seen reports to the effect that foreshadowed changes in the system of flight navigation charges will penalise regional air travellers relative to their capital city counterparts? Is there any substance to these charges?

answer.speaker: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Aviation has supplied me with Press cuttings which indicate that some representatives of the Queensland National Party have been exaggerating the problems and difficulties that have resulted from the Government's continuing policy of reducing the cost of maintaining the aviation industry. Those distortions obviously are designed to alarm people who use commuter services in Queensland. The Minister advises me that the Government has taken into account some of the difficulties that may flow from the recent decisions to apply the cost recovery program. I remind the Senate that the airline industry cost recovery policy has enjoyed bipartisan support for quite a considerable number of years. The policy is based on the proper concept that we should not rely upon the taxpayers in this country generally to subsidise an industry that now is capable of standing on its own feet. Honourable senators would be aware that approximately half of our national income comes from pay as you earn taxpayers-that is, wage and salary earners. It is costing the Commonwealth something like half a million dollars a day to subsidise the airline industry. Past governments have accepted the principle that that amount should be reduced each year until such time as the subsidisation can be phased out. To that extent, the Government has taken steps to provide that the airline industry shall pay for the maintenance of runways, air traffic control, airports, safety facilities and all of the other factors associated with the industry.

answer.para: Having regard to the specific problems faced by commuter industry passengers, the Government has agreed, at least in the first year of operation, to subsidise commuter airlines to the tune of $2m in order to ensure that there is some alleviation of the costs faced by airlines that use small and regional airports. If National Party members believe that these charges should not be imposed, one would suggest that the Queensland Government ought to accept some responsibility in this area and perhaps join with the Commonwealth and subsidise this industry on a dollar for dollar basis so that the difficulties that have been raised can be reduced even further.

I would remind Senator Black that the problems associated with the airline industry are creating pressures on the Budget. As I have indicated, taxpayers of this country are subsidising commuter travellers to the tune of about half a million dollars a day or $180m a year. The Government is moving down exactly the same track as that followed by the previous Government to make the industry stand on its own feet.

interject.speaker: The PRESIDENT

talk.start.para: â€”I call Senator Alston.

interject.para: Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

talk.start.para: â€”Thank you, Mr President. My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a report in today's Australian suggesting that wide differences have emerged between Australia and Papua New Guinea over the future of aid arrangements? The report suggests that Australian officials are more interested in supplying Australian aid for big high profile projects such as bridges and roads rather than meeting Papua New Guinea's request for widespread technical assistance. Is this the Government's real position? Does the Government acknowledge that village-based agricultural development, primary health care schemes and technical training assistance are more necessary and desirable than grandstanding infrastructure programs which are likely to exacerbate the chronic urbanisation problems already besetting Port Moresby and Lae?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I congratulate Senator Alston on his maiden question and admire his interest, which I know has been a long-standing personal interest, in aid and related foreign affairs matters. There is no fundamental difference of opinion between Australia and Papua New Guinea on the present aid arrangements. I can speak with, I suppose, some personal insight on that matter since I was up there for 10 days just a couple of weeks ago. There are some teething problems associated with the transitional phase we are in with the Australian aid budget, this year being the first year in which a substantial slice of Australian aid moneys is to be made available on a tied basis rather than being by way of general revenue support.
