That means that there must be some quite extended discussions about the most efficient way in which such tied aid can be delivered and the most appropriate specific projects for the allocation of such aid. The focus has been on technical assistance and infrastructure support of a kind that can be effectively utilised to build more effective institutional and working arrangements in that country for the future, rather than just one-off projects which might have their own utility but will not operate in any more constructive or larger term sense.

answer.para: I will seek further information on the specifics of Senator Alston's question and see whether the Minister for Foreign Affairs wants to add anything to my answer. Basically, the position is that there is no particular difficulty in the present stage of the aid negotiations. It is just a matter of both sides agreeing to an acceptable set of projects which will meet the kinds of longer term aspirations to which I have referred.

talk.start.para: â€”Did the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation see the report in the Australian of 2 June entitled `FAA orders probe into safety exits'? In that report United States authorities ordered an end to the unsafe practice of blocking wing exits on United States registered Boeing 747 jets. I ask: Firstly, are the wing exits on Qantas Airways Ltd 747 aircraft blocked in the manner described? Secondly, what can authorities do to encourage other airlines and airlines that use Australian airports to stop this unsafe practice?

answer.speaker: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

talk.start.para: â€”The Senate acknowledges, I am sure, that Australia enjoys the highest reputation for air safety in the world. It is the Government's intention to continue that objective. Consequently, it is always in the forefront of endeavours to make sure that the safety of passengers is ensured in every way. I did see the article in Monday's Australian and therefore am aware of the problem raised by Senator Foreman. The Minister has advised me that the basic Boeing 747 aircraft is fitted with 11 emergency exits to cater for up to 550 passengers. However, the situation is different in the United States, where certification of the configuration of 747s for international use-requiring the aircraft to carry only 440 passengers-permits a minimum of nine emergency exits. So our requirements provide for a different standard to that which applies in the United States.

answer.para: Having regard to this fact and our Government's determination to have the highest pos- sible standard, Boeing has offered a configuration whereby two over-wing exits are de-activated. Some airlines-British Airways, Thai Airways International, Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd and Qantas-have taken up that offer. The Federal Aviation Agency in the United States has asked United States airlines to retain additional emergency exits in their current Boeing 747 aircraft model and has extended this request to prevent the sale of the latest model which is yet to be produced unless there is an increase in the number of exits on the main deck. We are doing everything possible to have a uniform exit arrangement in respect of our Boeing aircraft. We hope that, with the co-operation of the manufacturer, a standardised approach will be taken to this matter throughout the international airline industry.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. What costs have been incurred by the Commonwealth in supporting the activities of the party political rural task force appointed by the Prime Minister and made up entirely of Australian Labor Party parliamentarians, whose report has blamed farmers and the organisations-in other words, the victims-for the disastrous consequences of the Government's anti-rural tax and other measures that have served to worsen the rural recession? What travel, sustenance, wages or other costs have been incurred by the Commonwealth on behalf of members of the so-called rural task force or any ministerial--
â€”Less than Neil Brown's car bill.
â€”Or other staff, including the National Media Liaison Service, assisting the committee in its round Australia political jaunts?

â€”I am not able to answer all of the details of the question. I am assured by the Minister for Finance that the cost of that committee's total activities is less than the car bill of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. But with regard to the details, I think the question appropriately should be placed on notice.

â€”My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Has the Minister noted an accusation from the so-called `dole crusader', Peter Sawyer, that the Department of Social Security is reluctant to examine his allegations of huge rip-offs from the welfare system, and what also appears to be his disappointment that there is no sign of his own prosecution, following admissions that he had personally defrauded the system-this having been reported in the Western Australian Daily News of 3 June? Does the Department, in Mr Sawyer's words, `want it to be kept out of sight and forgotten'?

answer.speaker: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Social Security has seen the allegations made by Mr Sawyer that the Minister and the Department are trying to throw a smokescreen over his claims of huge rip-offs from the welfare system. That is not true. Although the Minister for Social Security has pointed out that some of the claims made by Mr Sawyer are outrageous, what Mr Sawyer is doing-quite understandably, I suppose-is trying to drum up publicity for his book. When his credibility is questioned by the Minister for Social Security or by any of his ex-colleagues in the Department of Social Security, he gets rather annoyed.

answer.para: The Government does not approve, nor does the Department approve, of people ripping off the social security system. Since this Government came to power its actions have ensured that the amount of money that has been recovered from people who receive overpayments and who rip off the system has doubled. The Minister for Social Security and his Department, through the introduction of the new social security computer system, through new administrative methods, through the targeting of groups which are likely to be rorting the system, and through vigorous action in the courts, are acting against those who act illegally in the system. What the Department and the Government will not do is return to the days when the Department was requested by the previous Government to use blitzkrieg methods which picked up large numbers of people who were utterly innocent and which resulted in the ridiculous situation of some people losing the unemployment benefit, and 85 to 90 per cent of them having their benefits returned to them on appeal.

Mr Sawyer will continue to make allegations of the type he is making in order to gain money out of the sale of his book. He wrote the book using knowledge and information which he received while working as an officer of the Department of Social Security. Whether or not that has been properly used, I suppose, is a matter of judgment. The case of Mr Sawyer himself ripping off the system is being investigated by the Department and by the Director of Public Prosecutions. Whether or not a prosecution will occur depends on the Director of Public Prosecutions, not on the Government, not on Mr Howe and not on the Department of Social Security. Mr Sawyer knows that. His present claims are merely an extension of the publicity campaign that he has been conducting for some time.

question.speaker: Parer Sen W.R.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the Minister to the Treasurer's Budget speech of last year in which he said:

question.para: We-
that is, the Government-
have turned the economy around from deep recession to a rate of growth which is one of the fastest in the Western World. We have reduced inflation to levels not seen for a decade.

talk.start.para: â€”Who said that?

â€”The Treasurer. In the light of all recent economic statistics which show, among other similar figures, negative growth for the last two quarters and an inflation rate several times higher than those of our trading partners, how does the Minister now rate the performance of his Government in achieving its primary stated aim of non-inflationary growth?
â€”Senator Parer is, as usual, lumbering behind the rest of the world in his understanding of the current situation. It must have been said a hundred times by Government spokesmen--
â€”Things are crook.
â€”No, no.
â€”You are saying they are not crook?

â€”Let me start again. There is nothing that the Treasurer said in the Budget statement last year and which Senator Parer quoted which is not correct. There is nothing there which is not correct. It is perfectly true that since the Budget was given last year the Government has sought to slow the rate of growth in the economy quite deliberately and many people have been getting very excited about that. The rate of growth has slowed to almost the average of the last seven years of Liberal Government.
â€”This is deliberate recession? Is that what you are saying?

â€”Yes, that is true. Senator Baume seems to be surprised that we have a deliberate recession. When the Opposition was in government it certainly blundered into a recession, it did not know what it was doing and that was the biggest recession since the Depression of 1930-31. The Opposition blundered into that. This Government has quite deliberately-this has been said by the Treasurer and other spokesmen-sought to slow the rate of growth in the Australian economy. We have done so because of the decline in the terms of trade. If Opposition senators want to rejoice in the fact that the terms of trade have turned against this country, that the price of coal sold on export markets has gone down by 23 per cent in the past year and by 14 per cent in the year before, that is up to them. But I would not rejoice in that if I were them because it is not a matter which has suddenly emerged in the last year or two. It is a result of silly policies put in place by conservative governments in 26 years of the past 30 during which this country has been going bad in relation to its terms of trade. Senator Parer must know that. He should ask Senator Boswell who sits in front of him. I wonder what Senator Boswell says about Jack McEwen now. Is he still a schoolboy fan of his?
â€”Order! I would like you, Senator Button, to answer questions, not ask them.
â€”I am sorry, Mr President, I should not ask Senator Boswell what he thinks because to start with he does not.

â€”On a point of order, Mr President: The Leader of the Government in the Senate challenged me on what I thought, then he made derogatory remarks about me. He has not given me a chance to respond to his challenge. I want to know when I will have the opportunity to answer him.
â€”Order! The honourable senator may seek the leave of the Senate any time he wishes.

â€”If I may return to the topic, we do not in any way retreat from the fact that there has been a further depreciation of the Australian dollar since the last Budget. There has been a turn in the terms of the trade against this country. We do not retreat from that. All we say is that we now have to grapple with the consequences of it. We will do that much better than the Opposition did in all its years in government.

question.speaker: Parer Sen W.R.

talk.start.para: â€”I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I ask how the Minister reconciles that reply with the remarks made by the Prime Minister at the time of the Budget when he said:

question.para: There will be no unexpected recessions under this Government; there will not be an expected one either. Labor stands on its record, we can deliver on these things.

talk.start.para: â€”I do not seek to reconcile anything I said with what the Prime Minister said in the context of the last Budget. A lot of things have happened since then. I would not use expressions like `recession'. There has been a substantial slowing of growth in the economy, but I would not start cooking up recessions. I do not think that that is a profitable occupation for any of us.

answer.speaker: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

talk.start.para: â€”Yesterday at Question Time Senator Macklin raised matters concerning Malaysian students and their access to tertiary institutions. I have additional information for Senator Macklin and I seek leave to have it incorporated.

answer.para: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
In November 1985 some students in Malaysia were advised by the Overseas Student Office (OSO) that their tertiary applications were not successful.

This decision was based on examination results already provided to OSO and was part of the pre-selection process to ensure that country quotas were adhered to. As Senator Macklin may be aware, the number of Malaysian students wishing to study in Australia is far greater than the quota places available.
The students involved included a large proportion who had recently sat the South Australian Matriculation Examination (SAME) for which results were not yet available.

The intention to pre-select students was included in information material sent overseas. Nevertheless, because of some doubt that students sitting the SAME had understood this procedure and because of concern expressed about this decision it was reviewed by the OSO.

As a result, in December 1985 the High Commission in Malaysia issued a press release announcing that the earlier decision had been reviewed and that all Malaysian students, including those who had sat for the SAME, who had submitted applications to OSO and passed the requisite English test would have their applications considered by the relevant tertiary institutions. It was also made clear by the AHC that institutions would take account of the results of the SAME. It was however, emphasised by the AHC that demand by Malaysian students for subsidised places at Australian tertiary institutions far exceeded the number of places available and that, in these circumstances, it would be inevitable that there would be students who passed the requisite English tests and who satisfied Matriculation standards of an Australian tertiary institution who would not be offered places by the OSO.
There was never any doubt that local Malaysian examinations would also be accepted by tertiary institutions and I reiterated that to the Malaysian Minister for Education when I was in KL in January.
I trust this explanation clarifies Senator Macklin's question.

answer.speaker: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

talk.start.para: â€”Yesterday in Question Time Senator Reynolds asked me what sort of assurances Mr Holding, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, had had from Mr Katter, the Queensland Minister for Northern Development and Aboriginal and Island Affairs concerning the extent of land at Yarrabah which will go under Aboriginal title. Mr Holding informs me that technically speaking Mr Katter has not provided him with written confirmation that no lands will be excised beyond those which would be normally acceptable for public purposes. Nevertheless, Mr Katter confirmed this orally at a meeting with Mr Holding on 24 February this year in respect of Yarrabah and reaffirmed this to the Yarrabah community at a public meeting on 4 March 1986. In addition, on 4 September 1985 Mr Katter in response to a question from Mr Paul Braddy MLA, in the Queensland Parliament said:

answer.para: It is the Government's policy to transfer the existing reserve areas to the Council of that Reserve. That is the recommendation I have put to my colleague, the Minister for Lands, Police and Forestry.

Yarrabah is not the only community that has cause for concern, as mentioned in the Reverend Brennan's article. The Queensland Government seems also to be reneging on promises made to Woorabinda Aboriginal Council at various public meetings on 17 April 1984, 3 July 1984, 11 November 1984, 17 December 1985 and in discussions with Council on 11 March 1986. As recently as 22 May 1986 Mr Katter wrote to Mr Holding reaffirming his position in relation to Woorabinda. In summary, the record demonstrates that if Mr Katter can be taken at his word there can be no doubt that councils, communities and the Commonwealth had no reason to doubt that the integrity of reserve boundaries would be preserved and secure tenure provided by way of deed of grant in trust.

speech.speaker: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

talk.start.para: â€”Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented and I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: â€”During Question Time Senator Button challenged me about what I thought about Mr McEwen, the former Leader of the National Party of Australia or the Country Party, as it was in those days, and whether his policies had worked. I would like to refer to some of the benefits that Australia received when Mr McEwen was deputy leader of the Government--

â€”Order! The honourable senator is out of order. He has received leave of the Senate to make a personal explanation, not an explanation in respect of any matter that happened some time ago. I suggest that he might seek leave to make a statement rather than a personal explanation.
â€”I seek leave to make a short statement.

speech.para: Leave not granted.

talk.start.para: â€”Order! On 11 March and again on 13 March this year I informed the Senate of an industrial dispute within the Parliamentary Catering Service. This dispute has been settled and on Tuesday of this week the final formal steps were taken to incorporate into an award of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission a simplified designation structure involving the concept of multi-skilling and new pay rates for catering staff in accordance with a judgment handed down on 30 April 1986 by the Commission. The date of effect of the new pay rates is 1 May 1986. As well as the new classification structure and pay rates, negotiations with the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees' Union on this matter have led to agreement to revise certain working conditions and long-standing working arrangements. These changes will enable the Parliamentary Catering Service to operate more cost-effectively and will provide an improved working environment for staff. The multi-skilling concept and other new working arrangements are being introduced progressively. The union has indicated to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission its intention to pursue a further salary claim in conjunction with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, based on the wage fixing principles dealing with anomalies and inequities.

talker.name: Senator BUTTON
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

talk.start.para: â€”On 15 April 1986 the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) informed the House of Representatives that he would table statements of private interests made to him by Ministers in 1985. For the information of honourable senators I now table those documents. The statements have been retyped for the purposes of tabling, but the only alterations made from the original documents relate to the deletion of private addresses which are not readily available to the public and money amounts of assets and liabilities which have not been made public.

speech.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the paper.

As I read the agreement between the Government of Australia and the Government of the Swiss Confederation Concerning the Peaceful Uses of Nuclear Energy, it appears to be in line with the agreements that were developed under the Fraser Government and strictly in line with the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. If there are any differences I would be grateful if the Government would point them out in due course. The Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty has set very stringent rules for the peaceful use of nuclear materials. What does concern me is the statement of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) that was tabled with the agreement. I shall read from a paragraph in which the Minister said:

The decision to conclude this Agreement is consistent with the belief of the Government, stated in the context of its response to the ASTEC report, that Australia can make the most responsible possible contribution to the reduction of the risks and hazards associated with the use of nuclear materials and technologies by continuing to permit in a strictly regulated manner the mining and export of uranium subject to the most stringent nuclear non-proliferation conditions.

There is no doubt in the world that that statement outlines precisely the recommendations of the Australian Science and Technology Council in its report on Australia's Role in the Nuclear Fuel Cycle. I hold a copy of that report in my hand. There is no doubt that it is totally at odds with what the Government is doing. I take the first main recommendation in the ASTEC report, which states:

ASTEC recommends: That exports of Australian uranium should not be limited as a matter of principle but should be permitted subject to stringent conditions of supply designed to strengthen the non-proliferation regime.

The world knows that the policy of the Government and of the Labor Party is not only to limit the mining and export of uranium as a whole but to limit it to a couple of mines and to phase it out ultimately. The Minister's statement that the Government policy was in line with what ASTEC said could not be more out of line. ASTEC went on to say:

. . . Australian participation in stages of the nuclear fuel cycle in addition to uranium mining and milling should be permitted, where such participation promotes and strengthens the non-proliferation regime.

That is absolutely contrary to Labor Party policy. So the Minister misrepresented the situation when he indicated in his tabling statement that he and his Government were continuing to permit in a strictly regulated manner the mining and export of uranium. The fact is that, under the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, it is an obligation of all signatory states to provide to other signatories uranium products upon demand and under the strictest safeguards. Although Australia is a signatory to that Treaty, this Government has broken that Treaty, because it has not complied with it. It will not do so. It is being compelled by its left wing to phase out uranium mining. The Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, which some 130 nations of this world have signed and ratified, insists that the best way to stop proliferation of nuclear weapons is for member nations to observe precisely the terms of the Treaty and that if those nations have peacetime nuclear materials they should supply them under the Treaty restrictions so that people do not get those materials from other quarters.

This Government pretends that it wants to enforce nuclear non-proliferation, but by breaching the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and through the misrepresentation in the tabling statement, it is doing the reverse. I regret very much indeed that the Minister for Foreign Affairs made a statement in his tabling statement which does not conform with the facts. I regret that we are not fully conforming with the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. Nothing is more important for Australia than to ensure throughout this world that there will be no proliferation of fissile materials to create nuclear weapons. This Government is not observing those rules.

speech.speaker: Crowley Sen R.A.

talk.start.para: â€”While I was tempted to let this paper-the Agreement between the Government of Australia and the Government of the Swiss Confederation Concerning the Peaceful Uses of Nuclear Energy-pass, after Senator Sir John Carrick's words, I simply cannot. I find it fairly abhorrent that Senator Sir John Carrick should use the tabling statement of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) accompanying this agreement to suggest that the Minister has misled this Parliament. The honourable senator's comments were very stern. I inform Senator Sir John Carrick, through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that I will draw his remarks to the attention of the Foreign Minister so that he will have the opportunity to refute what I think was a mischievous assertion and claim by the honourable senator. I must say it was a matter of some disappointment to me.
â€”Ha, ha.

â€”Senator Sir John Carrick may laugh but I wish to say again for the record, although it would be quite beyond Senator Walters's comprehension, that Senator Sir John Carrick's claims of misrepresentation are a matter of disappointment to me. We are talking about the Agreement between the Government of Australia and the Government of the Swiss Confederation Concerning the Peaceful Uses of Nuclear Energy. This agreement has been tabled in the Senate so that honourable senators have the opportunity to look at it and appreciate what is contained in it. I think it goes very much to the heart of the Government's policy in the whole area of opposition to the non-peaceful use of nuclear energy. It is commendable that we have the opportunity to see such an agreement. It certainly is true that agreements such as this are not what could be called sexy. They are matters to struggle with so that we can understand what exactly is meant by the words contained in them. It is not easy to sell to the Australian population the importance of these agreements or a detailed understanding of them, but they go very much to the preferred way this Government has chosen to act in the whole area of nuclear non-proliferation.

speech.para: The agreement and the details contained therein are very much in line with a paper tabled yesterday, `A Report of the Australian Delegation to the 1985 Session of the Conference on Disarmament' which was held in Geneva from 5 February to 30 August 1985. Again I quote from Mr Hayden's accompanying paper. Mr Hayden reported:
. . . Australia was disappointed with the lack of progress in a number of key areas, particularly in the failure to agree on the mandate of an ad hoc committee to consider the nuclear test ban item.

As a result, no substantive work could be done on the test ban. I comment that it is very hard to convey to the citizens of Australia how much work goes into even getting to a point where agreement about establishing a committee can be reached. When all the work is done but no agreement is reached, no committee is formed and no progress seemingly is made, there seems to be no measure of success. It is very difficult to explain to people that our representatives in Geneva-in particular, Ambassador Richard Butler-work very extensively on behalf of the Australian Government and its policies in this area. It is very difficult to report on these matters because there seem to be so few gains. That is why I take great heart from the agreement tabled today. We now have a bit of paper, a document, that we can take to members of the community and say; `This agreement has been reached. It is in line with the Australian Government's proposals for the peaceful use of nuclear and fissionable material'. I urge Senator Sir John Carrick to re-read the Minister's speech. When I read these words I did not come to the conclusion that Senator Sir John Carrick has. I express again my disappointment that Senator Sir John Carrick should come to the conclusion that he did and refer publicly in a negative way to the Minister. I will certainly pass his comments on to Mr Hayden.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

speech.speaker: Hamer Sen D.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is a most disappointing document. The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation is in deep trouble, with the United States of America, Britain and Singapore having withdrawn from it for what seem to me to be very good reasons. The most serious defect of UNESCO is a strong and malignant anti-Western bias. This bias received most publicity in the field of communications because of UNESCO's efforts to create a new world communications and information order which, in fact, would have meant control of information by governments. UNESCO is also a highly inefficient organisation with 70 per cent of its Budget being spent in Paris. The activities of the more than 2,000 bureaucrats in Paris are described by the British newspaper The Guardian-scarcely a right wing or pro-Thatcher newspaper-in the following words:

[In Paris] the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation looks like one of the world's least necessary institutions. Diplomatic and bureaucratic fat cats may be observed floating in ostentatious limousines from one incestuous cocktail party to the next. Delegates from brutal regimes in impoverished countries plough a fur-lined furrow from luxury Parisian apartments to the Place de Fontenoy to make windy speeches about the iniquities of western capitalist imperialism, a burden they seem ready enough to share in their free time. They rail against western `monopolisation' of world news media and communications, secure in the knowledge that their living conditions will never be reported back home.

The centre of the problem seems to be the Secretary-General of UNESCO, Mr M'Bow from Senegal. He has been described by someone who knows him well as being arrogant, biased, inefficient and confrontationist, so it is perhaps not surprising that our Ambassador to UNESCO, Mr Gough Whitlam, has a high regard for him. But these personal quirks of Mr Whitlam should not be allowed to colour our attitude to UNESCO. In the report there is a section-I suspect written by Mr Whitlam-which contains a scurrilous attack on the motives of the United States and Britain in withdrawing from UNESCO.

What do we do about UNESCO? Looked at in purely selfish terms, it is probable that Australia gets more benefit, in terms of useful programs, than we pay for in our contribution of 1.64 per cent of the budget-a little over $6m. But we have wider responsibilities than that. What is wrong with UNESCO is that the executive board of more than 50 members is far too large to run the organisation, with the result that Mr M'Bow and his secretariat effectively run the organisation and manipulate it unscrupulously. A good example was the recent sacking of the British Auditor-General as UNESCO's external auditor, apparently because he was asking too many awkward questions. UNESCO rules state that only the general conference, that is, all member nations, can dismiss the auditor. Mr M'Bow and his secretariat wanted to get rid of him right away. The executive board bowed to the Secretary-General's wishes, out went the auditor and the rules were disregarded.

What is badly needed is a major structural change in UNESCO to bring its governing board down to a manageable number of, say, 12 members who could take control of the organisation and make the Secretary-General work efficiently within proper controls. It was to be hoped that Mr M'Bow would be replaced at the end of his second six-year term in 1987 but the grim news is that he looks likely, if he wants it, to be elected for a third six-year term. There was apparently a move to set a two-term limit on all heads of United Nations agencies, but this would have had little chance of success for it would have meant depriving the United Nations of several efficient agency heads merely to get rid of Mr M'Bow. So it looks as though UNESCO will be stuck with Mr M'Bow and the present structure until 1993. One would like to think that the Australian delegation would have been working effectively with those who want to reform UNESCO from within rather than blackguarding countries such as the United States and Britain which have decided that they have had enough. I think this delegation's report is a very regrettable document.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
