proctext.para: Message received from the House of Representatives intimating that it had agreed to the amendments made by the Senate to this Bill.

debate.title:
INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT (CAPITAL GAINS) BILL 1986
INCOME TAX (RATES) AMENDMENT (CAPITAL GAINS) BILL 1986

proctext.para: Debate resumed.

speech.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: â€”The Senate is debating the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill and the Income Tax (Rates) Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill which aim to introduce a capital gains tax. In so doing the Government is making a major breach of an election promise to the people of Australia. It is important to understand that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said in unequivocal terms that there would be no capital gains tax.

speech.para: Regrettably this legislation, which will affect the poor and a lot of unemployed people, will become law. It will become law because even though the Government knows that this was a breach of an election promise and even though the Australian Democrats' spurious plank was to keep the illegitimates honest they are going to make this legislation law. If taking part in a breach of an election promise is keeping the hybrids amongst us honest, language has no meaning. One can expect a Labor Party, socialist to its back teeth, to bring in a capital gains tax. I hope that everybody who is subjected to it in the future understands that the real reason that this will become law is that seven members of the Australian Democrats will decide by their weight of minority numbers that it becomes law.

It is important to look at how this legislation will affect the community and the environment behind it. Only last week the people of Australia were told something that was very serious indeed: They were told that investment in manufacturing industry had declined. That is very bad news for those who are seeking jobs, but doubly so if there is to be any attempt to resist the flow of imports into Australia and to do some import replacement manufacturing. Indeed, it is one of the most serious factors. Honourable senators should bear in mind that the whole basis of this is that Australia is facing a serious crisis because there is a decline in investment.

Yesterday the Prime Minister and others met with employers. If the papers are right, the Prime Minister is putting forward a suggestion. Of all the Alice in Wonderland suggestions I have ever heard, it must be the most remarkable. The suggestion is that the Government is considering subsidising interest rates. It will lower them so that they will be acceptable to manufacturers so that there will be investment. I want to put this in context because this Government, by its own deliberate action, has forced up interest rates in order to keep an absolutely unstable dollar slightly more stable. It has created the monster and it now has to reap the rewards. The fall in investment is clearly, on one account, because of high interest rates. But that is not the only reason. Why would a manufacturer be seduced by this kind of statement by a government: `Look, by an act of God, or by an act of mismanagement by the Hawke Government, we have given you another 30 per cent protection by devaluation. Hop in alongside it and manufacture because the costs of imports will have gone up by 30 per cent. Get in. Of course, you will have to borrow money'? Why would anybody do that when nobody can tell tomorrow, next week or the week after what the level of devaluation will be? There is the most terrible paradox that if a government is doing its job-God forbid that I should suggest this-the dollar will evaluate, so the very confidence trick that is being played on the manufacturing sector will be exposed. The Government will lift the protection. Why would any investor undertake this task?

Against the summits and non-summits that we are either having or not going to have, the Government is bringing in a capital gains tax. What will a capital gains tax do? It will take away people's free investment capital. Yesterday we had the Government's pantomime to employers and to the people of Australia that the salvation of Australia will be to get more investment into manufacturing industry. I could not agree more that the manufacturing industry needs to be lifted up. Sadly, the major tragedy of the Hawke Government has been that over its years in office-this applies also to the Whitlam years-manufacturing industry declined. In one period of 18 months in the Whitlam years 110,000 people went out of manufacturing industry, and they have never been recovered. In that period wages were forced up 37 per cent.

The monstrous paradox of what is being put before us must be demonstrated this way. The Government is saying: `We are frightened because our manufacturing industry is collapsing. We want more investment'. By this legislation the Government is going to take away free capital by taxing private industry and private people. Will it be invested in manufacturing industry? Not one little bit. In other words, the capital funds will be sterilised. There could not be a sillier concept than the Government on the one hand pleading for money for investment and on the other actually withdrawing the money out of industry and sterilising it.

Today we have the ugliest unemployment rate in many years. Juvenile unemployment is running between a fifth and a quarter of all juveniles. The average unemployment period for a person who has been on the dole is more than a year and is increasing monthly. We know that over a period manufacturing, which used to be the major employer in Australia, is shedding labour. Against that situation this legislation is brought in.

At Question Time the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) was confronted with the fact that two quarters of the year have both shown negative growth. He said that that was not recession. I repeat and I will continue to repeat it-it is abundantly in Hansard-that the Labor Party when in opposition said the measure and test of recession is two quarters of negative growth. The Government cannot have it both ways; it cannot say it and now try to deny it. The country is going backwards and the Leader of the Government is trying to make some kind of a virtue from the fact that Australia is going in reverse gear. He says: `It happened because we slowed it down'.

Institutes of economics are now predicting that for the next year, not the next month or so, growth will be, at the very best, one per cent. Is the Government going to take credit for that slowing down? Are all the young people looking for jobs going to look to the Government? Against this we have a decline in investment and an adverse trade balance. A confidence trick is being played.

Every time we talk about this situation the Government Leader and others say: `You know what has caused it, don't you? It is because there has been a fall in commodity prices, a fall in wheat, meat and grains and indeed there is prospectively a fall in coal and iron ore'. They forget to say that that is true but the volume of output has increased a great deal not totally offsetting it. They forget to say also that a 30 per cent devaluation has added 30 per cent to export earnings. But what they are silent on is the fundamental situation.

There are two sides to the balance sheet on trade balances. The main side is that we are importing far more goods and services than we earn in exports. Why are we doing that? It is because the manufacturing industry in Australia cannot manufacture and compete against the world even though with the 30 per cent protection from devaluation and the protection it had in the past, its costs are higher. Why are they higher? We have got a 9.2 per cent inflation rate, three times as much as most of our trading partners. In fact, the inflation rate of some of those countries has now moved to zero. We now have the greatest overseas debt that we have ever had. We have enormously high interest rates-higher than that of our trading partners. All of that is handicapping the creation of manufacturing and the getting of jobs. What happens? Against that background along comes the Government and says on the one hand `We want you to invest' and then on the other hand says: `We will bring in legislation which will remove free investment capital from you'. What will that do? That is a stupidity in itself. I cannot think of a time in Australia's history when to do those kinds of things would do more damage.

In the last week or two here we have had the introduction of the fringe benefits tax legislation. We have demonstrated that a fringe benefits tax will not hurt the affluent, the businessman with the Mercedes-Benz car and the lunches. He can bargain with his employer and the employer will pay his extra tax. What the fringe benefits tax will do is hurt the fellow who will be sacked because the employer cannot carry on. In fact, it will hurt all those people, including pensioners, who find that costs have been passed on by employers. None of the big people of this world will be hurt. This is a Government which pretends to help the little people against the big people. However it has brought in a fringe benefits tax which, in an ugly way, will do exactly the reverse of that. It will do a terrible harm in that it will put up costs and destroy employment.

Why is the Government doing this? It knows what is right; however, it is doing what is wrong. The Government set up what it called the National Taxation Summit. I have to say that it, like all the summit meetings that the Government sets up, is a device to enable the Government to pretend that it is consulting with the community and getting a consensus. However, it enables secret deals to be undertaken behind the high chair in the other place-or is it in a motel bedroom? It is a secret deal made by the Government with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and in confrontation with the rest.

There is no consensus by this Government at all. Indeed, if one looks at the paper prepared by Mr Charles Fitzgibbon-a very respected labour leader in his day-and sent to the Economic Planning Advisory Council one sees that he points out that the accord is an accord between two, the Government of the day and the ACTU, and that it has nothing at all to do with the community. He sees detriment in that. His whole message throughout his paper to EPAC is that the only way the Government will get us out of this situation is to increase productivity and the Government will do that in the first place by full co-operation between employer and employee, with the Government off its back with freer wage systems. That is the man who was the General Secretary of the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia and the Vice-President of the ACTU. He is now able to talk freely.

But this was a fix and a fiddle. It was an ugly thing. The same can be said of the first National Taxation Summit. The now bruised and battered employers understand this. The Taxation Summit was yet another gross deceit on the Australian people. Option C was to be the thing. The Treasurer (Mr Keating)-now is it not the best Treasurer in the Third World or, to use his own words, a banana republic-was putting forward a particular pattern which I think Treasury also put forward. What happened? The ACTU would not wear a bar of it. Where did consensus go? Where did accord go? The Prime Minister went back to a motel room without telling his Treasurer and without consulting in any way. He made a bargain in a motel room with the ACTU. He came back and forced that on a tax summit and on the Treasurer. The Treasurer must now be the greatest all-time loser that this country has ever seen.

These are the kinds of things that are being forced on us. The ACTU has said to the Government: `You will not do anything at all that will spread this load. What you will do is impose things that will punish the boss'. That is the kind of ugly class conflict which this Government lives and breathes. It is the kind of class conflict that Mr Charles Fitzgibbon says is crippling and killing this country. It is the kind of class conflict that, while I have breath in my body, I will try to rid this country of.

What are we doing? We are bringing in a package which we are pretending will hit the boss. All the way through it will hit the worker. The Government does not care whether it hits the boss or the worker. The Government wants one thing and one thing only-more money for itself. It is prepared to take investment capital out of the community. This is capital that would be invested in manufacturing, in growth and in creating jobs. The Government will put that money into its silly-season socialist ventures which, of course, create nothing and which destroy. That is the background.

How can we have a situation with a country which is facing a crisis-that is true, on any definition by the Labor Party-and which above everything at this moment needs no extra burden of costs? What it needs is encouragement for private investment. However, the attack is on private investment. What is the Government's test in regard to this? Again, like the fringe benefits tax, the Government says: `Listen, you people the electors, go along with us because we want to tell you that we will hit the big fellow-the tax dodger. Isn't that good fun and good sport?' It would be if it were true; however, it is not true. What will the capital gains tax do? Let us not measure it in terms of the present scale because this is a toe in the door. If this Government were left to go on and on the capital gains tax would go up. Let us look at it in terms of principle. What is the Government aiming to do? If somebody makes a capital gain which can be measured above the increase in the consumer price index, that capital gain, or a substantial amount of it, should be taken away from that person. In the eyes of the Government making a profit is an evil thing. The truth of the matter is that no business can succeed unless it can make a profit because out of profit comes investment capital. Out of investment capital comes expansion and jobs. This is the thesis.

I would never have believed that in the 1980s I would have had to face a Labor Party which; like some people in the late nineteenth century, talked about profit being an evil and which grasped profit into its own hands. Let me give a demonstration of this. I saw a report in a newspaper today that it is said that in the Victorian Parliament the Government will have to do something to disengage itself from rent subsidies because the capital gains tax will put up rents. Who pays rents? Do the rich pay rents or do the poor pay rents? If the rich have money, they buy houses. Who pays rent? The little people pay rents. How will such a thing happen? It is a very simple situation. Everybody knows that in almost every case today there is no day to day profit in buying a home and leasing it. In fact, the return on capital is perhaps five or six per cent whereas one can go out and get 15, 16 or 17 per cent from other investments. Of course, nobody invests in purchasing a house and renting it out as a landlord for the sake of the rental return. The only hope such people have got is that if they sit it out and take their low earnings now they will get a capital gain in the future. This is just as, for example, people sat it out on the shares such as Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and others. Over a period they were prepared to take a low yield in order to get a capital gain. That was regarded as a virtue. However, it has now become a vice and an ugly thing. What we are going to do is to pass all this cost on to the little people. What will the landlord do? Either he will not invest any more and therefore there will be a scarcity of rental housing and rents will go up or he will put a true economic rent on his dwelling. That means he will include in his rent the amount that he will be taxed in the long run. So little people will pay all along the line.

Clearly, the capital gains tax is a tax on incentive. It is a wicked tax on incentive. It is really an indirect death tax. What a horrible thing it is that I am able to say that in the case of bequests the estate of the deceased will have to pay capital gains tax on gifts to churches and charities. This will draw on the other assets of the estate. That is a pretty ugly kind of thing to have to say, is it not? The Government is picking on the churches and charities. What will happen is that, just as the fringe benefits tax hits charities, people will give less to churches and charities.

The Government has said that this tax is good because it will be hard to avoid. I say to the Government that there can be no simpler method of tax avoidance than this because all that has to happen is for a person or persons not to realise the capital-that is the simple situation. They will just hang on to their assets. We will have a freezing of assets in the community. The Government is laughing and saying that these people are rich. The Government, in fact, is destroying the money which becomes the investment capital which becomes the jobs. All it is doing is destroying job-making in the community. What an ugly thing to do. The main thing this tax does is what the socialists take glee in, that is transfer capital from the private sector to the public sector, to government. It takes away the main flow of investment capital which people might freely have used.

Because time is short, I simply say that the Government cannot have it both ways. It is telling us now by all the indices that we are completely out of competition with the rest of the world, that we have a terrible adverse trade balance, that we have an awful overseas debt, that we have had two quarters of negative growth, and that investment in industry is declining and therefore we have a likelihood of increased unemployment. The Government is saying that we need to put more money into manufacturing in order to stop this, but at the same time it is raiding the till. The fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and all the other things are raiding the till. This is utterly destructive.

We must, wherever we can, put aside the horrible concept that has been put before the people of Australia in the past by socialist governments when they say: `Put us in office and we will get our hands on the big fellow. We hate profits. We want to destroy profits. We want to take the money from them'. They do not give it to the people; they take it for themselves. They say: `The big fellow has got it and he is getting his way, but we will sort it out and give it to you'. Exactly the reverse is happening. Under the fringe benefit tax legislation, the employer pays the big fellow's benefits and so he escapes. He goes on tax dodging and the little person pays. The little person will pay for this, whether it is through a charity or a business which needs investment for employment.

The Australian Democrats cannot escape blame for this situation. They, like the limpet fish which swims alongside the shark, are now the pale shadow of the Labor Party. They pretend they are not, but virtually everything they do reflects the left wing of the Labor Party. An extraordinary thing has happened to the Democrats which people must understand. They took some virtue in saying: `We got some benefit improvement out of this fringe benefits tax; we have had some minor gain in the car industry'. Some newspapers have reported that the Democrats said that they will support the Government in deferring income tax cuts from September to December. What a quaint sort of situation we have. They are saying: `We will try to get some very minor bargain for a few people and we will then make sure that for three months all the taxpaying employees of Australia do not get their tax cuts'.

If this Government fails on 1 September to deliver the tax cuts to the ordinary people, it will be failing in ordinary natural justice, in wage justice. It cannot on the one hand say that it wants to help the ordinary families of Australia because inflation is beating them, and then say on the other hand that it will not give them the tax cuts for three months. Nothing has happened to remove the volume of money which was in the Budget and earmarked for tax cuts. Nothing has changed at all except that there has been some kind of bargain which looks metaphysical to those of us looking on. If the Government wants to say to the ordinary employed people `We will ask you to be responsible in matters such as deferring superannuation and deferring productivity gains and to come along with us in the discounting of wages for the devaluation', the Government has to show first that it will act in good faith by saying: `On 1 September we will give the full tax cuts which we promised and we will go on doing that in the future'.

I have been watching in recent days a return to the ugly false propaganda of the late nineteenth century and early twentieth century, the stirring up of the ugly class consciousness, the pretence that the big fellow is being hit when in fact the little fellow is being hit. Everything the Government does under its range of taxation measures will compound the problems of ordinary families, ordinary people. It will destroy jobs, it will destroy incentive and, indeed, it will put this Government out and the Australian Democrats out. It is only because of the Democrats that this tax legislation will be carried.

speech.speaker: Walters Sen M.S.

talk.start.para: â€”Today we are debating the capital gains tax legislation which the Hawke Government has foisted upon this community. I begin my speech by quoting the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his policy speech on capital gains tax. He said:

speech.para: And here let me make one point so that even our opponents can understand it; and let me make it beyond all their powers of misrepresentation and distortion. There will be no capital gains tax.

So much for that broken promise. The young people in the gallery today should take full notice of what is being debated here because it will not affect us older people so much as we have already been able to acquire some assets and the tax does not apply to those who have held assets before 19 September last year, but it applies to all those people who acquire assets after that date. It applies to all you young people in the gallery.

talk.start.para: â€”Senator Walters, you should address your remarks to the Chair, not to the gallery.
â€”Through you, Mr Deputy President, I say that it applies to all the young people in the gallery who are starting out in life, trying to gather unto themselves a few assets.

speech.para: The promise which the Prime Minister made was made before the big summit was held in this Parliament. This tax resulted from a meeting which he held with the unions in a motel room without the Treasurer (Mr Keating) knowing. The unions said to him: `We have got to have a capital gains tax'. Mr Hawke threw out the window the promise which he made to the electorate and gave in to the unions. He made a deliberate decision to do away with the promise which he made in his election policy speech, and he gave in to the unions.

talk.start.para: â€”You are telling ter- rible fibs. You will get struck down by a bolt of lightning if you keep this up.

â€”Let Senator Gareth Evans tell me that the Prime Minister had not made that promise, and I know who will be struck down by lightning. It certainly will not be me. Let us look at the present situation. I am quite sure that the young people in the gallery will be very interested in our present situation. At the moment Australia has the highest inflation rate of any of our major trading partners. It is 9.2 per cent in Australia. It is 1.1 per cent in Japan, 2.3 per cent in the United States of America, 0.1 per cent in West Germany and 4.2 per cent in the United Kingdom.

speech.para: Also, we have the highest interest rates of all those countries. According to the April figures of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development-the most recent figures available-Australia's rate is 18.5 per cent, Japan has 6.4 per cent, the United States has 8.8 per cent and West Germany has 8.7 per cent. Remember that Australia's rate was 18.5 per cent.

Australia has enormous labour costs. Our labour costs are so great that we cannot compete on overseas markets. We have an horrific corporate tax rate. In addition, as honourable senators have heard, the balance of payments figures are so disastrous that the Treasurer says that we are turning into a banana republic. Because of all these factors, we cannot compete on overseas markets. At a time when this country is in such a difficult situation, the bright lot on the other side of the chamber have decided to introduce a capital gains tax and a fringe benefits tax on business. We are told that only $10m will be collected in the second year of the operation of the capital gains tax. This is because it will apply only to assets that have been gained after 19 September 1985. The amount of capital gains tax collected will be much greater than that when the children who are sitting in the public gallery at the moment are gathering their assets. The Governments FBT is imposing a tax on the extra benefits that an employer pays to his employee. This tax will be met by the employer. The tax will be levied in respect of a farm employee who has the use of a rent free cottage on the property on which he works. That tax will not be paid by the employee but by the farmer. This lot on the other side of the chamber have put two extra taxes on the business community at a time when Australia needs business to expand.

This might seem to be an extraordinary situation; it certainly is to us. I believe that the Government belatedly is beginning to realise what it has done. This morning's Sydney Morning Herald reports that Mr Hawke met with business representatives yesterday, that he understands the problems that he has created and that he is now offering to subsidise interest rates on business loans. The Government is proposing to collect $400m through the fringe benefits tax and further revenue through the capital gains tax. The Prime Minister has now decided to give some of that money back to business by subsidising their interest rates. Has anyone ever heard anything so ludicrous as that?

talk.start.para: â€”I take a point of order. Mr Deputy President, we are experiencing a show of amateur theatrics in which eyes are cast to the gallery and your earlier ruling that the honourable senator must address her remarks through the Chair is being ignored. Perhaps she is being profoundly insulting in referring to you as being ignorant of all of these matters. However, I do not think she is referring to you; I think she is referring to the people in the gallery.
â€”There is no point of order. I have been listening to Senator Walters. Her remarks are compatible with being addressed to me.

â€”Of course there is no point of order. Mr Deputy President, as you know only too well, the honourable senator who raised the point of order always resorts to that ruse. He knows it reduces my speaking time. He is also trying to take attention away from what I am saying. Mr Deputy President, the Government still tries to tell us that it is in control, that it knows just what it is doing. A little earlier in my speech I told the Senate that the Government is trying to increase investment by lending money at a lower rate of interest. However, today at Question Time Senator Button told us that the Government had deliberately slowed down growth and investment. He said that all this was a very deliberate move on the part of the Government. It was so deliberate that the Prime Minister had a meeting yesterday and told business: `Please invest, and if you do, I will subsidise interest rates for you'. So that is the sort of shemozzle the Government is in.

speech.para: We all remember the trilogy. Honourable senators opposite might remember that the Government promised three things. Mr Hawke said that the overall level of taxation as a proportion of gross domestic product will not be increased; that the Government's deficit-that is what the Government owes-will not be increased as a proportion of gross domestic product; and that the Government's spending would not increase. When the Prime Minister was asked whether he would like to qualify what he had said about the tax, he said: `No, I do not want to put any qualification on that'. He also said:
There will be no unexpected recessions under this Government. There won't be an expected one either . . .

He said: `We will not have any deliberate slowing down; we will not have any unexpected ones either'. Yet, we had Senator Button tell us in the chamber today that the Government had deliberately slowed it down. Mr Hawke also said:
. . . I have deliberately avoided resort to extravagant claims about Australia's future . . . I have been very careful not to make any claims about which I cannot be absolutely certain.

He said that there will be no recession. Well, we are in the middle of a recession brought about by deliberate policies of this Government. I do not believe that the Government has any credibility. I do not believe that anyone in the public gallery could possibly believe that the Government has any credibility after hearing me explain what sort of schemozzle this Government has got us into. However, not everybody believes that the Government is wrong. I would like to read a letter printed in today's Sydney Morning Herald that was written by a person who deals with liquidation and bankruptcy matters. The letter states:
Dear Mr Keating,
I hope you take heart from this letter and press on with your sweeping tax reforms.

People don't seem to realise that many new jobs will be created in the Public Service to police these taxes, and just think of the extra leisure time that small-business owners will now have! Many of these business owners have previously only dreamt of an early retirement. Your new taxes will make this a reality for them.
In other words, Mr Keating is making these businessmen go broke and forcing them to retire. The advertisement continues:
Yes, Mr Keating, I'm on your side.
I expect my own business to actually increase by at least 50 per cent over the next financial year!
Yours sincerely
John H. Mann

This person, who handles bankruptcies, knows that his business will increase and that he will handle many more bankruptcies as a result of this Government's tax measures. It is not just the Government that should take the blame because we have to understand that the Government does not have the numbers in this place to put this legislation through. It must have the support of the Democrats, who are not even interested enough to have one of their members present at the moment. Seven of them have joined with the Government to ensure that this legislation is passed. Therefore, they must take full responsibility, along with the Government, for this legislation being passed. Members of the Opposition are the only ones who are voting against it.
Let me also read to the Senate a letter which appeared in the Australian today. It is pretty good, too. It is a further open letter to Senator Chipp. It reads:
Sir,
I must apologise-
by the way, this bloke wrote Senate Chipp a letter a little earlier in the week-
for not writing to you again sooner as I have been extremely busy answering the flood of mail from those electors offering both moral, as well as financial, support.

Since my last letter, interviewers both on radio and television, as well as the print media, have asked me why I am attacking the Democrats and not the Labor Party who after all, introduced the Fringe Benefits Tax Bill.
Well, Senator . . .
Firstly, it is no use me writing to `the world's best Treasurer'.

Do honourable senators remember when everyone said that Mr Keating was the best Treasurer in the whole wide world? At least that is what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said. But look what he has done to Australia now. The letter continues:
Firstly, it is no use me writing to `the world's best Treasurer'. Why should he take any notice of me when he doesn't even take any notice of his own Prime Minister!!
Secondly, as you have seen fit to do a deal with the Government-
that is just what the Democrats have done; they have done a deal with the Government-
on just a small section of the proposed legislation without due regard for the massive administration costs to both the Public and the Private sectors . . .
You said in the Sunday Telegraph, 1/6/86, quote:
`Now is the time to do unpopular things because the Australian memory is such that by the end of 1987, when the next election will be held, people will forget this.
Senator Chipp certainly said: `Do the unpopular things now because by the next election, the Australian people will have forgotten all about it and they will vote for us'. The letter continues:

Well, now that's a coincidence. You see, I have already allowed for that . . . I have planned to place a full page advertisement in the National Press every quarter, when the employers are filling out their quarterly Fringe Benefits Tax forms . . . These advertisements will list the names of Companies and individual Businesses who have had to lay off employees--
he is referring to employees who have had to be sacked during that last quarter-
. . . as well as the number of employees dismissed.

The letter then states that all of those companies that have gone broke because of this legislation that the Government and the Democrats will pass will also be listed. The fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax will kill all incentive. There is no doubt about it: The capital gains tax will create tremendous problems for the youth of today. They will find that when they try to acquire some assets so that they will be able to have a productive life in Australia, the capital gains tax will mean that the incentive will be lost, particularly to that generation.

speech.speaker: Lewis Sen A.W.R

talk.start.para: â€”The Senate is debating two Bills-the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986 and the Income Tax (Rates) Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986-which introduce a capital gains tax for Australia, which, as has been pointed out repeatedly in this place, breaks a solemn undertaking which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) gave to the people of Australia. The economy of Australia at present is in serious trouble. This year we will be spending about $13,000m more than we will be earning from our imports. As Government Ministers keep repeating during Question Time and at every opportunity, about $3,000m of that deficit has been made up by weak export prices. The deficit for the year will be $13,000m, so about $10,000m has not been made up by weak export prices, but by mismanagement of the economy by this Government. Australia would still have a deficit in excess of $9,000m, about $10,000m, even if the overseas prices of our grain and mineral exports recovered-which at this stage seems to be most unlikely. Our total foreign debt would still be more than $75,000m. There is every indication that that total debt will fairly soon reach a figure of about $100,000m.

speech.para: Mr Hawke and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) have tried to con the people of Australia that the internal economy is quite okay; the only problem is the external prices problem, and that is beyond their control. That, of course, is absolute nonsense, as I have made clear. The external prices problem is a problem of about $3,000m. I have interjected repeatedly during Question Time: What about the other $9,000m or $10,000m? Ministers have ignored those interjections. The Ministers continue to answer questions as if the only cause of the deficit is the external prices problem. That is rather like the old man saying to mum, `I can afford to buy this new motor car on hire purchase', and subsequently she discovers there was a very large Bankcard debt that he had not bothered to tell her about.

I will extend that story. If that couple were to borrow, say, $50,000 this year, no doubt they could extend the house and put in new floor coverings and curtains. If they were to borrow another $50,000 the next year, they could buy a new motor car and perhaps even a new boat. The following year, if they borrowed another $50,000, they might be able to put in a swimming pool and no doubt by then they would have new clothes and all the neighbours would be saying: `That couple is doing extremely well'. They would be able to employ a gardener and housekeeper. The neighbours would remark on how well they are doing. As honourable senators know, they would have to meet the interest payments on their debt. Of course, in a domestic situation they might ultimately have to meet the capital, but let us forget about the capital for the moment. They have to meet the interest payments on the debt. The moment that their income starts to fall-if, for example, the mother got pregnant and could not continue to work, so that the family's income started to fall-the amount of money that they had borrowed would become a millstone around their necks. Is that not exactly what has happened to Australia under this Government? This Government has increased Australia's debt in the three years that it has been in government by $40,000m. Unfortunately, at the same time--

talk.start.para: â€”You know that is not the truth. You know that the bulk of that has been by the private sector. Now tell the truth.

â€”Senator Gietzelt is quite a nice bloke in his own way, but unfortunately he does not really understand the economy of this nation. The nation is spending this amount of money and it does not matter whether it comes from the private or the public sector; the trouble is the country cannot pay its debts. This Government has increased the national debt by $40,000m; that is the way it has been allowed to go. That is the economic situation.
â€”Are you suggesting--

â€”Certainly I understand what Senator Gietzelt is trying to interject; that it has not been all public borrowing. I acknowledged that, but the Government has mismanaged the economy in such a way that the international debt has increased by $40,000m. At the same time our income has fallen and our ability to pay the interest on this debt has fallen dramatically because of the fall in prices of our overseas products and our lack of international competitiveness. We are unable to meet our commitments and on top of that, as a result of the Government's mismanagement the value of the Australian dollar has fallen so that the interest payments have become a millstone around the neck of this nation.

speech.para: This Government has been boasting of having created 600,000 new jobs. The truth is that it is now clear that those 600,000 new jobs have been created not because of any economic recovery but by way of borrowing $40,000m overseas. Except insofar as there was a partial recovery brought about by the Fraser Government's wage freeze and the breaking of the drought, there has been no economic recovery under the Hawke Government. It is clear that those so-called new jobs have been brought by this Government putting the nation into hock. The simple fact is that the 600,000 jobs have been bought with phoney money. Total unemployment continues at 600,000 people and that is after having seen rises in four of the past five months. The people of Australia will pay a very heavy penalty for the dubious pleasure of having another three years of an Australian Labor Party Government.

It has been estimated that all of us should take a 10 per cent cut in our living standards in order to cope with this problem, but of course that will not happen. Not all of us will suffer a 10 per cent cut in our living standards because some people have the ability to avoid that cut. In particular, two-income families with security of tenure will be able to avoid that cut. A family, for instance, where one person is employed in the Federal Public Service and the other person is employed as a teacher may be able to avoid that cut, but the rest of us will have to suffer. There will not be across the board equality in the cut, so the problem will really affect those who are at the lower end of the economic scale. I wish that some of the members of the Australian Labor Party would recognise that people in a two-income family with security of tenure have become the wealthy people in this community, not the small businessmen who the ALP seems to think are some bottomless well from which it can permanently draw taxes.

What is needed from this Government is leadership and an immediate and sustained cut in spending. The Government should be looking at a significant, indeed a substantial cut in all expenditure right across the board. This would be the first step in demonstrating to the world that Australia will not become a banana republic. We need then to free up the business world so that entrepreneurs are given an opportunity to establish successful businesses. Australians still have the talents, but those talents are being stifled by disincentives. As soon as the Government can after that, it needs to reduce taxes fairly and without causing high interest rates. Instead of this sort of leadership that I have suggested, we have total disarray on the part of the Government; confusion, public disagreement among Government Ministers and between Government Ministers and the minders of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke).

This Prime Minister was chosen by the ALP to win elections, not to run the country, but his minders have decided that he should have a high profile in leadership, so now he will take over the reins of management. We all know that he is quite incapable of taking over the reins of management. Look at what he did to ACTU-Solo Enterprises Pty Ltd, that very competent little petrol company. He took over the reins of that and destroyed it. He took over Bourkes store, a very competent business in Melbourne, when he was the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and destroyed that store. If the Ministers allow him to take over the reins of government we will be in even worse trouble. The world should recognise that Mr Hawke was selected by the ALP as its leader to win elections and to continue to win elections, not to run the Government.

talk.start.para: â€”I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President. I draw your attention to the fact that not once has Senator Lewis referred to the legislation we are supposed to be debating. We are not debating the economy; we are debating income tax legislation. I do not think that he has mentioned the words `capital gains' once in his contribution. I draw his attention to the matter before the Chair.
â€”Order! There is no point of order. Senator Lewis is entitled to paint an economic background, but he will have to bring his remarks around in due course to the capital gains tax.
â€”Just give us what you have been saying for the last 10 minutes again.

â€”Senator Crichton-Browne wants me to give that serve again. If the Ministers allow Mr Hawke to take over the running of the country, they are quite cranky, because it is quite obvious that he has no ability to run anything, but he has an ability to communicate. I understand that when he goes out and smiles at young people and tells them the sorts of things they might want to hear, they might think he is great, but the truth of the matter is that as a Prime Minister he is a disaster. The bailiff is knocking at the door of this Government, but meanwhile what do we have? We have Cabinet Ministers hurling personal abuse and vilification all around the place. They keep blaming all and sundry and seem to be waiting and hoping that the problem will go away. In this chamber in particular Ministers have increasingly resorted to personal abuse and invective in answers to questions and in debates as they seek to cover up their ineptitudes, instead of facing reality and entering rational debate on ways of overcoming the present crisis.

speech.para: I refer in particular to Senator Button, the Leader of the Government in the Senate. He appears to be on the verge of some sort of breakdown as his utterances become increasingly irrational and he resorts more and more to personal abuse. Yesterday he extended that abuse to cover the Public Service and the teaching profession. I might say that I find that very disappointing in Senator Button. I have always thought that he had more in him, but it is a clear indication of what is happening inside the Cabinet as he comes under pressure. We know as we sit in this chamber that we can expect abuse from Senator Grimes, Senator Walsh and Senator Gareth Evans who sits alongside Senator Gietzelt. I specifically exclude Senator Gietzelt from this because we do not get personal abuse from Senator Gietzelt, but we do from Senator Grimes, Senator Walsh and Senator Evans. Until now Senator Button has managed to keep his very strong silver tongue in check, but he is under such pressure now that he keeps personally vilifying people on this side of the chamber in personal attacks on them-not attacks on our policies or what we might say, but attacks on our intelligence, size, shape or something personal about us.

talk.start.para: â€”Order! Senator Lewis, when I ruled on Senator Gietzelt's point of order earlier, I did say that you should bring your remarks around to the Bills before the Senate.

â€”I am coming to that. I am merely pointing out that under the pressure of introducing this legislation-a capital gains tax and a fringe benefits tax to try to raise the revenue to meet the expenditure of this Government-Senator Button is cracking up. In fact, all the Ministers are cracking up. Senator Grimes has a philosophy. He has told us repeatedly: `If you can't stand the heat, get out of the kitchen'. Senator Grimes cannot stand the heat any longer because, as honourable senators will see, the headline on the front page of the Launceston Examiner for Tuesday, 3 June, is `Senator may quit'. Clearly, Senator Grimes cannot stand the heat in the kitchen any longer and he is looking for a quick exit.

â€”On a point of order, Mr Deputy President: Senator Lewis is ranging very wide in relation to the subject that is before the Senate. I think he is being a bit personal in attacking Senator Grimes rather than confining his remarks to the Bill.
â€”I have already ruled on that point of order, as raised by Senator Gietzelt. Senator Lewis is bringing his remarks around to the Bill before the Senate, I hope.

â€”Of course I am. Today Maximilian Walsh made it clear in the Sydney Morning Herald that the Treasurer, Mr Keating, may be looking for an exit too. I can see Senator Gietzelt saying that he will not be offered a job, that is for sure, so he will be stuck in this chamber arguing from the Opposition benches against me in the fairly near future. He will have lost Senator Grimes and perhaps he will lose Mr Keating because as Maximilian Walsh points out:

speech.para: For a man now at home with the antique dealers of Europe, the US and the UK, Canberra must be increasingly a sentence.
It is clear that those two Ministers will benefit from three years of Australian Labor Party government. They will get some sort of job and shoot through.

In a climate like this Australia needs a capital gains tax like it needs a hole in the head. What this country needs is an incentive. A capital gains tax will force people to ask: `What is the good of working to make a profit in our business? What is the point of pouring stock back into our business and trying to increase our turnover? What is the point of trying to employ more people in order to make a little extra money?' Why would anybody do that when this Government introduces a fringe benefits tax and a capital gains tax? These taxes are a total disincentive to any sort of business activity. As I said, we need a capital gains tax like we need a hole in the head. What we need--

talk.start.para: â€”Why do they have it in the United States?

â€”Senator Gietzelt asks why there is a capital gains tax in the United States. That is a very naive question. There is a capital gains tax in the United States because the rate of taxation there is 19 per cent, not 49 per cent as it is here. If the Government dropped our tax rate to 19 per cent, we would welcome a capital gains tax-of course we would. In the United States in addition to personal income tax at 19 per cent there is a tax on the cost of goods sold. This ranges from about 7 per cent in some States to as much as 10 per cent in others. But that is a broad tax and the Government is not talking about a broad tax. It is talking about introducing a fringe benefits tax and a capital gains tax on top of the highest personal taxes in the world. The Government cannot keep ripping it out of the people; there must be an opportunity for people to make a quid. If people do not have the opportunity to make a quid, they will stop making it and find some other way of pocketing the money.
â€”Quids went out with elastic-sided boots. We have dollars now.

â€”Quids are what I am interested in. Don't you worry about dollars; I would rather be interested in quids. I am about to bring my remarks to a close, so poor old Senator Gietzelt can relax. What we need is a climate which will produce an incentive for businessmen and the work force to get together to produce Australian goods at internationally competitive prices. If we were to deregulate a number of the areas of the community business people in Australia would be able to get together with their work force and produce goods which would be internationally competitive. Even Senator Gietzelt knows this is true because there is a company called Lincoln Electric Co. (Aust) Pty Ltd in his State which has done it and there is a company in South Australia, Mitsubishi Australia Ltd, which has also done it. There are other companies around Australia which have shown that Australians have the initiative to enter into arrangements with their work forces to produce goods at internationally competitive prices. We need those incentives. These taxes are disincentives. Taxes such as the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax are disincentives to that sort of initiative. We need to say to the work force and the business people of Australia: `Get together and make the product; there are profits in it for all'. I know that `profit' is an ugly word to members of the Australian Labor Party but profits are what it is all about. A capital gains tax is simply another millstone around the necks of Australians. It is just like the married couple who borrow beyond their ability to pay-their repayments are simply millstones. Time is running out; the Australian Labor Party left us this sort of mess in 1975 and we had to fix it up. It looks as if we will have to fix it up again.

speech.speaker: Newman Sen J.M.

talk.start.para: â€”After those stirring tones I rise to support previous Opposition speakers in dealing with this dreadful tax which is only one in a huge package of taxation measures which will drive this country further and further into the mire. In the second reading speech, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) claimed that this tax legislation would make the tax system much more efficient by encouraging investment that would generate growth and jobs. Few would quibble with the need to have an efficient but fair tax system. If that were the situation here I would not be opposing the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill and the Income Tax (Rates) Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill. The fact is that these Bills are not fair and are not efficient. As is the case in so many situations where government intervenes, these Bills will distort the market-place and discourage investment, growth and jobs-and all for little revenue gain. The Minister displayed his terrible prejudice towards the free enterprise system when he complained that decisions to invest had been determined not only by the overall yield of a project, but also by the composition of that yield as between tax free capital gains and assessable income. He claimed that this had produced an inappropriate pattern of investment, preventing Australia from achieving the best possible economic growth rates. What rubbish!

speech.para: This Government made such a fanfare of its intention to improve the Australian taxation system that the nation waited with bated breath. Yet what transpired? A backroom deal with the new generation of faceless men in a motel room while the back of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was turned. What has been the end result? We have added to the 1,100 pages of taxation legislation prior to 19 September last year another 625 pages with this new tax package. That is an increase of 57 per cent in volume of tax legislation in less than a year. So much for a reform of the system. The Minister would claim that this is all to catch the tax cheats, the artful dodgers. If the Minister were really successful I would be very happy. If he thinks he has done it with the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax, he is very much mistaken. Option C might have achieved that, but we know that the Treasurer-the world's greatest Treasurer-was rolled and that option was unacceptable to our masters in the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

The people who will be caught and burdened by this taxation are much more numerous than the Minister would care to admit. Again, it is the mass of small businessmen and small farmers who will be especially hurt. The so-called landed gentry, who always seem to bring out Senator Walsh's shoulder chip so clearly, are less likely to be bothered by this tax than the small farmer. It is much more likely that the big properties are in the hands of family companies and therefore are less vulnerable to a capital gains tax as they are unlikely to be sold as the generations change. On the small family farms where partnerships are so much more common, the sons presently farming with their fathers will be caught by the capital gains tax if they want to sell the property either to divide the proceeds among the family or to upgrade their holdings by transfer to a bigger property after their father's death.

As the Government should know, if it cared at all about small farmers, there are two main reasons for these farms being sold. First of all, they are sold on the death of a farmer so that distribution can be made to the family or, secondly, on the retirement of the farmer so that his capital investment can be turned into a more substantial income to see him through his aging years. With this tax the Government is stealthily reintroducing death duties and I say: Shame on it. In addition, it is penalising again the men and women who have worked so long and so hard on their farms, frequently for poor or variable returns, and who have looked to their retirement to reap the reward for their hard work to keep them in some degree of comfort in their old age.

One must also draw attention to the fact that the Government has sneakily introduced an element of retrospectivity by providing that, even though a property is purchased prior to 19 September of last year, if it is sold after the death of the taxpayer, capital gains tax will be payable. This will catch most farms in time. As the cities have grown and expanded to the country, farms have been increasingly forced to the sale room due to high council rates based on sub-divisional potential. These farms are not owned by farmers who plan to make a quick buck; yet the capital gains they make will attract the tax.

The Minister for Finance expressed concern at the misallocation of capital. I draw his attention to a phenomenon which is already occurring as a direct result of his announcement of a capital gains tax. In the big cities of Australia wealthy people are already putting huge sums of money into luxurious homes which they will be able to buy and sell with relative freedom from a capital gains tax. So much for the Minister's opinion that `the lack of a capital gains tax has also distorted investment choices towards less productive uses'. If anything has distorted investment choices towards less productive uses, it is this legislation.

If this legislation also causes farm prices to fall, we must fear for those farmers who are already in difficulties with low commodity prices and high interest rates. Their equities will be reduced by that drop in values. Surely this is no way to encourage the best use of capital in the nation. It is interesting to remember that on 23 October 1984 the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) told a farmers meeting at Horsham that he would oppose any new capital gains tax and death duties in the strongest terms.

talk.start.para: â€”That is what they say. What do they do?

â€”That is what the Government says but what does it do? One has to read the fine print to see what it does. It is long on promises. On 9 April 1984 the Minister for Primary Industry was quoted in the Australian as saying:

speech.para: My objection to a capital gains tax is the same as probate in that it has the effect of rendering the rural sector in the long term less viable. The family has to sell part of the property to pay probate or capital gains tax.

In April this year the Minister told the Parliament that capital gains tax was in the farmers' long term interests. Big Brother knows best! What rubbish and what a conversion. Saul on the road to Damascus has nothing on Minister Kerin. The Government claimed that its tax would have negligible impact on primary producers as it would be paid only on real gains and would be subject to notional averaging over five years. However, figures produced by the Valuer-General's Department of New South Wales tend to indicate otherwise. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a table which compares indexed price movements of the consumer price index with the movements in four categories of farms in New South Wales between the years 1976 and 1984.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows-
The following table compares indexed price movements of the CPI with the movements in four categories of farms in NSW between the years 1976 and 1984.
CPI...
Grazing Properties
(a) Western lands...
(b) Other...
Wheat/Sheep Farms...
Dairy Farms...

Although these figures only apply to NSW farm price movements between 1976 and 1984, and that price movements will no doubt vary in intensity from State to State, this is a clear indication that adjusting the cost base of a capital asset for farmers by CPI is not as appropriate as it may be for other holders of capital assets.

talk.start.para: â€”I thank the Senate. Clearly, the use of the CPI for assessing real gains for farmers is unreliable. The seasonal fluctuations of drought, floods, changes to export market prices and growth of cities all distort the values of farm properties.

speech.para: Before passing on to other difficulties posed by the Bill on small businesses in Australia, I draw attention to the sneaky method by which the one per cent Medicare levy will be assessed, not just on income as at present but also on the capital gains included in the taxable income. Of course, it is clear that the cost of Medicare has long ago grown beyond the range of the one per cent levy, but the Government has been unwilling to reveal its real cost. Now it suddenly has a heaven sent opportunity to bring in more money under the one per cent levy rather than having to raise the rate of the levy. That is disgraceful.

Another group of small businesses that stands to suffer under this legislation are the small tourist enterprises. The proprietors of these enterprises work a 70- to 80-hour week, with their sleeves rolled up, dealing with the whims of the travelling public. I declare my interest. As one who has rolled up her sleeves while working in that industry, I know how those people put in heavy hours and put up with the disadvantages of their job, with the incentive of building up a business so that they can sell the freehold for capital gain and sell the goodwill that they have worked so hard to achieve. If the impact on their industry is similar to what happened to the home rental market after the negative gearing announcement, the probable effect on values of motels will be a reduction in the number of motel units being built and an increase in tariffs. This is an industry that we are trying to encourage to compete on an international market.

talk.start.para: â€”They have already had the fringe benefits tax put on them.

â€”They have already had the burden of the fringe benefits put on them. They will bend under this measure as well. They are typical of people involved in small business everywhere. We know that the achievement at the end makes it all worthwhile for them. This Government is treating them as tax cheats and fat cats who, because they own property, should be denied the full results of their labour. The hours they work, if costed at union rates, with overtime and penalty rates entitlements, would prevent them from making their business viable in the long term. Through their hard work and the long hours they spend ploughing in their wages they try to build a business which, with luck, will get into the black and give them a chance for profit-that filthy word. They can eventually decide to sell up, pay off the bank and take their reward-a reward for their risk and for their enterprise. It is that risk-taking and that enterprise that the Government is taxing with the introduction of this legislation.

speech.para: These are the sorts of people who have built this country. The goodwill which they have built from nothing in their businesses will contain an inflationary element over time. Where there is no base to commence with, how can one index the base? In the case of tour operators the goodwill is practically all they have to sell. Mr Tony Stolarek, a tax partner with Arthur Andersen and Co., was quoted in the Australian Financial Review of 30 May as saying that the legislation was a record-keeping nightmare. The article stated:
``Everyone down to the smallest taxpayer will have to keep detailed accounts of their affairs'', he said.

``The complexities are enormous and affect so many transactions that before doing anything financial, virtually everyone will have to stop and think if there are any capital gains consequences'', he said.
The national director of taxes for the accountants Ernst and Whinney, Mr Ian Phillips, also drew attention recently to the important issues of record-keeping requirements. He said:
The revenue yields cannot possibly match the cost of properly administering the legislation, a cost which, like the fringe benefits provisions, falls primarily upon the business community.

I remind the Senate that the Minister claimed in his second reading speech that this legislation would make the tax system much more efficient by encouraging investment that would generate growth and jobs. The Institute of Chartered Accountants in Australia, which we would have thought would have had a vested interest in a confused tax system, has criticised the tax, saying that, even allowing for the indexation of tax thresholds, the tax would seriously hamper development and limit growth. The Institute urged the Government to work towards a fundamental reform of the tax system rather than continue on the course of further piecemeal amendments to current legislation. I join the Institute in its plea. I say to the Government: For goodness sake, cut government expenditure and leave the real wealth creators of this nation alone. Without them this country will not just find itself in a recession; it will be doomed.

speech.speaker: Townley Sen M.

talk.start.para: â€”The Senate is debating the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986 and the Income Tax (Rates) Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986. At the outset I wish to read a quote that, most probably, all honourable sen- ators have heard before. It was attributed to Abraham Lincoln over a century ago. He said:

speech.para: You cannot bring about prosperity by discouraging thrift,
You cannot strengthen the weak by weakening the strong,
You cannot help the wage earner by pulling down the wage payer,
You cannot further the brotherhood of man by encouraging class hatred,
You cannot establish sound security on borrowed money alone,
You cannot build character and courage by taking away man's initiative and independence,
You cannot help man permanently by doing for him that which he can, and should do for himself.

I think this Government is doing just about everything it can contrary to what Abraham Lincoln said in those few lines. Once again we see this Government in its anti-business role bringing in an anti-business tax. Those people who have managed to work during their lives and do a little better than average are to be taxed once again. We have just heard an excellent speech from Senator Newman about some of the people who will be hit by this tax. We see this Government bringing in another tax-at a time when taxes should be coming down. The United States of America has managed to promote its economy by reducing taxes and that is what this country should be doing. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has been shown to have broken another promise. He is always asking the people of this country to trust him. I would not trust him with my pencil and certainly not my fountain pen. He promised the elderly that there would be no assets test on their pensions. What happened there? He broke his word. He promised that there would be no capital gains tax. What do we have before us this afternoon? We just cannot trust that man to tell the truth. I believe that eventually the people of Australia will realise how they are being conned and take no notice of anything that he says. His political promises are certainly ones that go in one year and out the next.

What should be happening in this country? I believe that we should be trying to increase investment. In a week when the Australian dollar is again on the slide the Government is pushing through the fringe benefits tax which we know will affect so many industries. It will not affect government organisation one iota but it certainly will affect the private sector-the businesses that employ most of the people around this country. Now we see this capital gains tax being pushed through. I repeat that that is again something that the Prime Minister said would not happen. What we need in this country is people to take economic risks. With risks in investment come jobs, and increased employment helps our young people in particular who are most damaged at the moment by having such a big percentage out of work. With investment and risk there will be a chance that they will find it easier to get a job.

Of course, at the moment we have extremely high interest rates. They are there to try to prop up the dollar although it has not been working too well lately. I believe that the prime rate in Australia is somewhere around 18 per cent, in Japan around 7 per cent, in West Germany about 9 per cent, in France 10 1/2 per cent, in the United Kingdom 12 1/2 per cent and in the United States of America somewhere around 9 1/2 per cent. In most other countries interest rates are coming down. The overspending of this Labor Government has resulted in high interest rates to try to prop up the dollar by encouraging people outside this country to invest their money in Australia. Another reason why I believe people will not invest is that the interest rates that they have to pay to borrow money for investment are simply too high. Of course, no new investment simply means that there will be no new jobs.

Part 3 of the economic report in the Age of Monday 2 June pointed out that our inflation rate is way in excess of the inflation rate of a lot of other countries. This year, our inflation rate is nearly 8 per cent, in the United States it is somewhat less than 3 per cent, in the United Kingdom 4 per cent, in West Germany zero per cent, in France nearly 3 per cent, in Japan 0.5 per cent and in Canada 3.5 per cent. Australia is winning in the inflation stakes right down the road. It is just not good enough. This country is going down the economic slide to becoming a banana republic.

Let us look at the indebtedness of this country. I have just received a new list of selected countries. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) is always telling me that we are not very much in debt. The list I have, which was prepared by the Parliamentary Library, is headed `Per Capita Net External Debt of Selected Countries'. This list shows the per capita figures for 1984 which are the latest figures available for most countries. The most indebted country per capita is Canada with an external debt of nearly $7,000. The next is Norway with $6,500, followed by Denmark with $5,800, New Zealand with $3,666, Finland with $3,200 and Australia, which is seventh on the list, with an external debt of $2,600. I have said before that that is way in excess of countries such as Argentina, Mexico and Brazil. Argentina's net external debt per capita is only $1,600, Mexico $1,280 and Brazil $800-which is about one-third of the indebtedness of Australia. I advise the Senate that this list shows the 1985 per capita figures for Australia as $3,200, which is up from $2,600 the previous year. That is a very serious situation. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard that table.
Leave granted.
