talk.start.para: â€”I thank the Senate. Honourable senators can see what a mess this country is in. Of course, everybody has pointed out just how much a capital gains tax will stop people from building things such as rental homes. Of course, if there are no homes we will have a rental shortage. If we have a shortage up will go the prices and the rents, and that will affect all those people whom this dishonest Government purports to assist. As Senator Sir John Carrick said earlier, a capital gains tax will not stop the bosses from having a house but it will stop the people at the lower end of the economic scale renting at a reasonable price. A capital gains tax will stop people from buying or investing in farms. Our main export earner-our farmers-will be locked into their present assets. As Senator Newman said a moment ago, even the farmers will be attacked when they die. As I see it, this capital gains tax definitely has an element of retrospectivity. We need to be increasing and improving our exports both in the farm sector and in industry otherwise our borrowing requirements, which are already horrendous, as I pointed out a moment ago, will continue to increase. This Government will keep interest rates high; it needs to in order to keep the dollar up. That will have all the side effects that everybody in this country knows about. I refer to farmers, small businesses, home owners and home renters.

speech.para: Senator Watson was right when he said that this was just the thin edge of the wedge. I agree entirely with that. The home is now exempt from a capital gains tax but, on the performance of this Government over the last few years, I believe that eventually the home will be included as a capital gain. If Labor stays in office I believe that, after the next election or at some time for some reason, it will dream up an excuse to impose a capital gains tax on the family home. If the Government ever gets full control of this Senate I do not think for a minute that this capital gains tax will be dated from the day this legislation comes into effect; it will be made retrospective as far back as this Government can make it. This Government has shown its attitude to things like that before, and I believe that it will do so again.
We have seen so much waste recently which is costing this country hundreds of millions of dollars yet the Prime Minister, in his 1983 policy speech, said that Labor was committed to:
. . . cutting away extravagance and self indulgence in Public office.

What are we seeing this Government do? I do not have time to detail all of the areas of waste, but let me give a few examples. Let us look at government advertising. Prior to the 1984 election, Labor had engaged in massive public advertising campaigns, including promotions for the prices and incomes accord. In August 1984 it advertised about the Sex Discrimination Act and Medicare was advertised to May 1984. These are not small amounts. The advertising bill for the prices and incomes accord was $750,000. The cost regarding the Sex Discrimination Act was just over $250,000 and for Medicare it was nearly $3m. The cost of electoral enrolment to September 1984 was over $2m and the community employment program to September 1985 cost $560,000. These are not peanuts. The Government spends money like a drunken sailor. I have always reckoned that the people who do not have to earn money, and have never had to earn it, could not run a fair. These are the people who spend their money most rapidly. This Government is a perfect example of that.

In October 1985 the claim was made that of the Government's $57m advertising budget more than $6m was spent on politically-motivated projects to enhance the support of the Labor Party. That claim was made in the Australian on 11 October 1985. One of those programs was Priority One. I do not know whether any honourable senators have seen any of those advertisements. I have been associated with advertising for a reasonable length of time and I could not understand what they were getting at. It was a pathetic program. Senator Amanda Vanstone made a very good speech about that in the Senate to which people could refer. Included in these costs were the production costs of the Prime Minister's speech of $54,000. I do not know who is getting all this money. I can assure the Senate that there was not this wastage when the Liberal-National Party coalition Government was in power.

talk.start.para: â€”There is plenty of room for cuts.

â€”There is a stack of room for cuts. Altogether, if honourable senators went through all the things that have been done they will see that it comes to some hundreds of millions of dollars. I have just enumerated these costs from the first page of this document; it goes for nine pages. Pamphlets were printed for things such as the Australia Card, fringe benefits and capital gains tax. The booklet that the Government sent out on fringe benefits tax was not even accurate. I do not know what the exact figure is but that, in itself, would have been some hundreds of thousands of dollars.
â€”They don't know either.

â€”I think we will find out in the Estimates, but that will be a little further down the track. We should be looking at where to cut spending and waste. Honourable senators should remember that this tax will bring in only $5m in the first year and $10m in the second. Let us see what it costs for overseas trips. To June 1985 the Hawke Ministry has taken a total of 125 overseas trips at a total cost of $6.1m. That is more than it is going to get from capital gains tax in the first year. I will not go into the details of the people who travelled most. I do not want to do that. That is available to anybody who wants to look up the records. The Hawke Government enlarged the Parliament. At the last election the Parliament was enlarged to 220 members and senators. The Budget allocation was $18m. The elections cost $30m and public funding, yet another Labor initiative, cost $7.8m. These are just a few examples of the way this Government is wasting money and putting this country in debt. The Government, to try to fund its waste, is trying to scrape from people's piggy banks what they have saved all their lives. We all know about the waste that is going on in bodies such as the Australian Bicentennial Authority, the Human Rights Commission and the Pipeline Authority. Some people say that the Australia Card will make money, but I do not believe it will. It is easy to see that this Government has not fulfilled its promises to have a scandal-free administration or to cut away extravagance and self-indulgence. If 125 overseas trips by Ministers of this Government are not extravagance and self-indulgence, I do not know what is.

speech.para: A new tax is coming in. I am sure that a lot of the money that is collected will be wasted in the way that the previous dollars that have been collected by other new taxes by this Government have been wasted. The Government always calls them initiatives. Why is a new tax an initiative? I think it is a penalty. It is just one of those clever little words that the Labor Party tries to use. In no way should tax be called an initiative. Any tax, particularly this new tax is a penalty on the workers of this country who try to save a little in their lives.

This tax will stop investment and, therefore, attacks the young. It attacks the poor by lowering the amount of rental ability and yet it is promoted as attacking the wealthy. But in reality it hits the little bloke; it hits the battler. I believe the Government does not really care, it is just trying to disguise what in fact does happen. Incentive to invest will decrease with this tax; the incentive to work will decrease; the incentive to work hard, to save and provide for oneself and one's family will be removed. I am sure that a lot of the left wingers and the socialists of the Government will be extremely happy. In economic terms, the Government will get peanuts from this tax-only $5m in the first year and $10m in the second.

talk.start.para: â€”Hear, hear!

â€”I am glad that Senator McIntosh said `Hear, hear!' when I said that the socialists will be happy that the incentive to work hard and provide for oneself and one's family will go. He said `Hear, hear!' when I said that the socialists and left wingers would be happy. I am glad he said that. I believe that really does indicate just what this Government is about. The reasons for this tax were outlined by Peter Costigan in an article in the Melbourne Herald of 23 May this year. He said:

speech.para: The real reasons for the new tax are threefold.
The unions wanted it as part of their agreement to go along with the now shaky accord mark 2.

The bureaucracy wanted it because few bureaucrats acquire capital outside their homes and their tax-payer funded superannuation scheme, both of which escape scot free from this and all other current tax changes.

Perhaps the bureaucrats who come and live in Canberra, buy a house here and have to pay tax on the capital gain will not be too happy. I can see why most of the bureaucrats around the country will be happy. The article continues:
Mr Keating wanted to placate those in the Labor Party, especially the left who are ideologically convinced that accumulated capital is evil unless controlled by governments.

I believe the Government should be promoting an environment where people look after themselves. It needs to encourage enterprise and self-reliance. This tax does entirely the opposite. We all know that under this Government Australians' living standards are falling. I believe they will fall a lot further yet. In part, in an article in the Age of 2 June headed `We really are living beyond our means'-there is an emphasis on the word `are'-Terry McCrann states:

Four months ago I wrote that Australia was on the brink of its gravest economic crisis since the 1930s Depression at a time when the Government was still selling the line that all was rosy in the garden.
That propaganda has only recently been shelved. Mr Keating's `banana republic' comment of three weeks ago marked the symbolic turning point.
Despite the fact that we are heading for a banana republic there is no encouragement. We still have new taxes such as this capital gains tax. Further on in the article Mr McCrann states:
. . . our total debt is heading inexorably towards $100,000 million, and points higher.

In short-and the cliche has never been more appropriate-we as a country are living beyond our means. We are taking more from the rest of the world than we are selling to it. And this has only been possible because the rest of the world has been prepared to lend us the money to do so.

I expect that any day soon we are going to lose our triple A rating around the world. I think members of the International Monetary Fund will have to tell this country how to manage its affairs within a few years. In the case of New Zealand we saw that once the amount of interest it had to pay on borrowings to finance its deficit rose to 11 per cent it lost its triple A rating in international financial circles. That is one of the dangers that we face not so far down the track. A little further on in the McCrann article it is stated:
But increasingly, in recent times it was the combination of our fallen dollar and increasingly high interest rates.
He means that this is stopping investment in this country. Further on Mr McCrann said:
The Government has two choices: it can impose the very harsh medicine required-broadly again, that requires as I wrote--
meaning Mr McCrann--

four months ago something like a 10 per cent cut in the living standards of every Australian-or it can ride the economy and the country over the cataract and hope something turns up before we hit the rocks below.
I do not believe that a 10 per cent cut in living standards for us is enough now. I believe that it would be more than that. Mr McCrann continued:

Projections of private investment, also released last week, showed that business has not increased its spending plans for the coming 1986-87 financial year over the past three months. Again, the only other time this has happened in the last 10 or so years was in 1982-83.

Whether the Government likes it or not, it-we-is now going to pay a very heavy price for the past three years of phoney prosperity, that `growth' which did nothing to build our manufacturing base to replace imports or to generate the export earnings of the future.
Mr McCrann continued:
What then is the solution?

We have to promote the private investment that will create the industries that will (1) compete with imports (2) earn export income to pay for them, and service the existing debt, and (3) of course create jobs and keep the economy moving ahead.
How do we get private investment?
We dismantle or modify all the things that have been built up over the past 20 years as a disincentive-trade unions and their restrictive job practices-
Senator Newman, being in the tourist industry, would know all about the high penalty rates during weekends and things of that type-
business regulation, punitive taxes such as the proposed capital gains and fringe benefits taxes, costs imposed by government (including interest rates) etc, etc.

In short: provide some confidence that an investor could (a) get a plant built, (b) operate it efficiently and market its output without union bully-boys pulling the plug and (c) be able to earn a fair and reasonable profit on the investment and its risks.

Surely, that is what those on this side of the House have been saying over the last few hours of this debate. I am only sorry that we are debating this legislation towards the end of the session. No doubt some people will say that we are filibustering on this legislation. However, it is a very important matter. As Senator Watson said earlier, the legislation will have a long term profound effect on investment. It will have the effect of making it more difficult for a lot of the poor, the less well off in the community, the battlers, to get places to live at a reasonable price. As Mr McCrann concluded:

Time is not on our side and we really do not have a choice. We take the hard decisions or we learn to live with inflation and unemployment in the high teens (in a good year), grinding poverty across much of the community-and Third World-style obscene pockets of stupendous wealth-and consequent social and political upheaval.

That is what a lot of the people away from the ivory towers of Canberra realise is happening in this country. We are heading in a very dangerous direction. As was stated in the Australian newspaper of 3 June in the editorial headed `New directions are essential':

Those who would seek to play down the crisis in our balance of payments, in which the terms of trade have turned against us so dramatically, are wrong to do so. The drop in Australia's income and the consequent squeeze on our economy and living standards makes it imperative that we examine how we can make Australia more competitive and successful.
Further on the editorial stated:

But for a business in difficulties higher costs, for whatever reason, may add up to a terminal situation. It is the timing of the reform measures that is critical. Changes in negative gearing, along with capital gains taxes, are not only making rental accommodation expensive but also scarce, and are contributing to higher inflation . .
Overall reform of the tax system to restore incentive to work and to earn is vital . . . we must look seriously at what incentive there is for an employer to stay in business.

I am sure that there are lots of people around this country who are getting sick of all the imposts that the Government is putting on them. No doubt, that would please a lot of the socialists and left wingers of this Government. They are recent statements that I have just quoted. However, we have been warned over the last year or so by many people. John Leard and other writers have pointed to the dangerous situation that this country is in. In my opinion we have to become more pro-business. Of course, fringe benefits and capital gains taxes are diametrically opposed to that. We have to become pro-family. We need to stop financing alternative lifestyles. We need to become pro-youth. With 20 to 25 per cent of our youth not working, we need policies that will help in that area. We need to be pro-self-help. This world does not owe Australia a living. Australians should not rely on the mad socialist policies which have been proven elsewhere in the world not to work. It has been proven that eventually they damage the people that they are said to aim to help-the battlers in the community. We should not rely on those policies. I believe that this tax should be abandoned. I am pleased to belong to the Party that says that it would repeal such a tax. I would even go so far as to say that I would make that repeal retrospective, as much as I am against retrospective tax.

talk.start.para: â€”Give us all a refund.

â€”Exactly. I would almost be prepared, if I were leading the Liberal Party, to say that we would give back the money that this dishonest Government proposes to take from the hard workers of this country.

speech.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: â€”After 12 years in politics one should become accustomed to cant and humbug but I do think that we have had some spectacular examples tonight of cant and humbug in the speeches of the last two honourable senators who have spoken in this debate, who both represent the mendicant state of Tasmania, which pulls about $250m more out of the Commonwealth Government than it would get on the basis of a per capita distribution. Those honourable senators have been saying how easy it is to cut expenditure. I think that is a particularly striking example of cant and humbug.

speech.para: There have been, I think, 18 Opposition speakers in this debate on the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986 and the Income Tax (Rates) Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986. However, there have not been 18 speeches; one speech has been repeated 17 times. A theme common to those speeches is the mutually exclusive proposition that a capital gains tax will raise negligible amounts of money but will bankrupt business. That proposition is supported by a number of false assertions, chief amongst which is the assertion that this is the highest capital gains tax in the world. It is true that in the United Kingdom the taxation base is indexed, as it will be in Australia, and a flat rate of tax-I think of something like 20 per cent-will be levied. However, the indexation introduced by the Thatcher Government is a very recent proposition. I have not noticed any particular improvements in the economy of Great Britain because of that. With unemployment above 13 per cent and rising, the Thatcher Government is presiding over Great Britain's decline to Third World country status.

Also, in the United States there is a flat rate of taxation which is not indexed. Of course, that makes it a relatively easy matter for the effective marginal rate of tax to be in excess of 100 per cent compared to the Australian system because in our system the tax base will be indexed and in the United States it will not. In the majority of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries the base is non-indexed and the marginal rate is applied usually without any provision for averaging. So compared to the tax which is levied in most of the OECD countries this is highly concessional. Incidentally, capital gains taxes are not an attribute of banana republics; indeed capital gains taxes are rare in banana republics. They are found in virtually every OECD country-I think I could go further than that and say in every OECD country-the performance of which has put ours to shame over many decades.

Australia has had no general capital gains tax before. For many years it had no inheritance tax. During the last 30 years or so-nearly all of those years under Liberal-Country Party governments; incompetent and cowardly tory government-we have seen Australia slide steadily behind not only the rest of the OECD countries but behind the rest of the world. There are many reasons for that. I am not saying that this is the only one, but one of the reasons for that is that in Australia for far too long the ethos of capitalism has been a comprador ethos, effortlessly skimming off the cream without making any serious attempt to do the hard work which is required for true economic growth. The fervent attachment to a capital tax-free system is one of the powerful symptoms of that comprador ethos.

We have heard the usual nonsense about how this will kill off the cockies. I have been trying to tell the galahs opposite for a long time now that the major reason that many Australian farmers are currently in financial trouble is that they paid too much for land in the early 1980s. A major reason they paid too much for land was the absence of a capital gains tax and the expectation, at some time in the future, of untaxed capital gains. Of course, the capital gains appeared to be there-illusory though they turned out to be-because the price of land was steadily rising. The reason the price of land was steadily rising, supplementing the expectation of untaxed capital gain, was the speculatory feedback. We saw it happen with Poseidon shares and we saw it happen with land in Melbourne in particular in the late 1880s and early 1890s. When we have that type of speculative boom going we can sustain increases in prices for a period. In the end, there is always a crash as there must be. We cannot entirely eliminate that tendency for speculation which is always in the background of markets for assets. But at least if we tax the capital gains, we will hose it down to some extent. Far from being damaged by a capital gains tax, if there had been a decent capital gains tax such as this in Australia for decades, many of the farmers who are currently insolvent would not be insolvent because they would either not have bought the overpriced land at all or they would not have bought it at such excessive prices.

We got the customary refrain from most of the speakers that we should not be taxing, that we should be cutting spending. The Opposition has yet to nominate one substantial expenditure cut. I have invited it to on numerous occasions. Various Opposition front benchers say that spending should be cut by $4 billion, $5 billion-name your own figure-but they have yet to nominate one substantial area where expenditure should be cut. The Waste Watch Committee produces a list of trivia, half of which, one finds out on closer investigation, relates to the Fraser years and not to the years of this Government at all. The other half adds up probably to less than Neil Brown's annual car bill. Moreover, not only has the Opposition failed to nominate one substantial expenditure cut but it has also run around the country promising to add $2 billion to expenditure while failing to nominate one significant cut.

I guess there are two possible reasons for the fervent objection from Opposition members to this tax. The first and the more charitable one is that they do not really understand it, and they cannot accurately assess the effects it will have. That is the charitable interpretation. The less charitable one is that there are a huge number of people in the Liberal Party who are notorious tax evaders. Half of the former members of the Western Australian Liberal Party Finance Committee are now on trial. Probably the other half should be. The reason this tax must be applied at the marginal rate to be effective--

talk.start.para: â€”I raise a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. We have the situation where one of the Labor Ministers was in one of the bottom of the harbour schemes. I do not think that Senator Walsh has any justification at all in saying anything about Liberal Party members. He has absolutely no factual knowledge.
â€”There is no point of order.

â€”It is a fact that one Ronald Woss of the Liberal Party Finance Committee in Western Australia in 1979 is currently on trial. It is a fact that half of the members of the Liberal Party Finance Committee at that time have been named in various official reports as having been directors who arranged the sale of companies to Brian Maher or his agents, who then sunk them to the bottom of the harbour. In a less spectacular way there is a wide-spread affinity for tax avoidance or evasion. In most instances, except in the pedantic legalistic sense-I do not believe that there is any real point in distinguishing between the two-Liberals have a propensity to get involved in that sort of activity. At the bottom of most tax avoidance-evasion schemes has been the conversion of what would have been taxable as income into a gain as capital which was not in the past taxable.

speech.para: I know that there are some people in the Opposition who argue-and some of them probably even believe it-that part 4A amendments passed in the autumn of 1981 have removed the possibility of that sort of thing happening. I am not sure that that actually stands up and that that can be asserted with absolute confidence, even with the present High Court of Australia. Who can guarantee that some High Court in the future might not adopt the permissive attitude to tax evasion which the Barwick court adopted throughout the 1970s. One thing of which we can be sure is that if a real capital gain-which is the tax base for this legislation-is taxed at the marginal income tax rate, people will not be able to get away with tax avoidance or evasion in the traditional way.

I have not been here for the whole debate, but I understand that there have been a number of assertions that no deduction will be allowed for capital losses. That is not correct; losses are deductible against capital gains in the current year and may be carried forward indefinitely to set against future gains. It was also said that bequests to charities would be subject to the capital gains tax. Bequests to charities are usually paid in cash, so the question would not arise. Perhaps, very rarely, substantial assets are donated to charities, but this practice is so rare that it is hardly significant. Certainly, none of us is sidetracked or diverted by the red herring the Liberal Party throws in about pretending to be concerned about what happens to charities. What the Liberal Party is really concerned about is that when this tax comes in there will be no opportunity for tax avoidance and evasion of the type which was so popular and so destructive in Australia in the 1970s and the early 1980s.
Question put:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

speech.para: Bills read a second time.

proctext.para: The Bills.

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I would like to refer to a few matters that require answering in light of what the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) said when replying to the second reading debate. First of all I would like to return to the nine principles laid down by the Hawke--
â€”Are we having a second reading debate in the Committee stage?

â€”No. I will draw the Minister's attention to several detailed matters. Firstly, I refer to three of the nine principles which were laid down by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at last year's Tax Summit. The first of the three principles that are of relevance to this matter is that any reform must simplify the system. Clearly, this very complex piece of legislation does not do that. I doubt whether Labor members have actually read the legislation. Had they done so, I am sure that they would have been horrified by the language that is used. Clearly, it is not a simple piece of legislation.

speech.para: The second principle is that any reform must provide the best possible climate for investment, growth and employment. Quite clearly, this new tax is going to destroy employment, it is going to restrict investment and it is going to be a major disincentive for industry to develop. The third principle is that any part of the reform package must have widespread community support. Clearly, the capital gains tax does not have widespread community support. In fact, there is widespread opposition to it and to the very concept of it. The Government has totally ignored its own set of principles, as it has done in regard to every other piece of legislation that we have debated over the last week.

The Minister and members of the Australian Labor Party generally have always sought to confuse the two issues associated with capital gains. They make the point that capital gains taxes are about restricting speculative activity upon which tax is charged. That is a lie. It is quite clear that there are two separate and distinct classes of capital gains. Certainly, there are those speculative gains which are earned, say, on the stock market or in some real estate deal or whatever, that bring relatively short term gains to the operator. But there are others which are, of course, associated with investment and the legitimate long term development of industry and business in the country.

The Minister would have us believe that somehow we need to have the capital gains tax in order to tax those speculative gains, in order to stop the rorts in speculative gains. Nothing could be further from the truth. in fact, short term speculative gains are already taxable under the present income tax law. Section 25a, for instance, catches all those kinds of profit-making schemes and deals which are perpetrated by some people in this community. Even shorter term gains, such as those made within a 12- month period, are caught under section 26aaa of the income tax law. Again, speculative gains are caught in that way. It is not necessary to have a separate capital gains tax to catch them.

What is the purpose of the capital gains tax? One can only draw conclusions based on the assumption that the Government basically is about some kind of ideological witch hunt, that its commitment to the trade union movement is part and parcel of its needing to keep face with it and to keep the accord in place. That can be the only conclusion which we have in mind. I think the Government in its quieter moments would admit to itself that that is the only reason for implementing it, because when one tries to find the logic in what it is doing, one cannot understand what is happening. Firstly, the situation is that the economy is running down and we are seeking to impose a tax at a time when we need more investment. This tax will mean that there will be less investment. Secondly, a vast amount of confusion is about to be created in the public's mind as to what are the Government's real intentions in the area of investment. Clearly, that will restrict the development of the economy generally.

Let us look at one or two of the real problems that are associated with the detailed operation of this legislation. First and foremost, there is the question of goodwill. There can be no activity that is closer to the heart of what Australia is all about than that of small businessmen setting up their own little businesses, working hard to build up a reputation so that finally they can sell the business and receive a capital sum on the basis of that goodwill. Let me reiterate the case that has been mentioned previously of a corner delicatessen which builds up goodwill over 20 or 30 years. Now, that amount of capital that has been built up over that time will be taxed in one year, subject only to one factor; that is, the discounting of 20 per cent which will be regarded as exempt.

The Minister has just told us that this capital gains tax is not among the highest rated capital gains taxes in the world. I ask the Minister to tell me what country imposes a capital gains tax at the highest possible marginal rate-at the moment, 61 per cent-on capital gains made through the gain associated with goodwill. Of course, it is the highest rated tax in the world, and it is imposed on those who can least afford to pay it and on those who are striving through their own labour and effort to build up a nest egg for the future. It is absolutely incongruous that the Government should see it in the light in which it does, and for it to impose a tax in that way.

Let us take another case-the case of a business which employs a person for a long period. That person builds up a particular level of skill and becomes an important part of that business's operation. When that person reaches retirement age and goes out on his superannuation, but then receives an extra amount to recognise the value of his skill to the firm over a long period of years, he is asked to sign a covenant which restricts his future business activity and the use of that skill in some other business. When that person retires, that whole capital sum is subject to taxation. Not only will capitalists be taxed in the way that I have just described in relation to goodwill; these ordinary employees who enter into restrictive covenants when they retire from the employment of firms will also find themselves paying tax at the highest possible rate. In both of those cases indexation, of course, will not apply because there is no cost base from which to work. One cannot apply an index factor of nil. One would not get any result other than nil. So no reduction of the value of the goodwill or of the restrictive covenant will be taken into account. This is the way in which little people will be affected by this capital gains tax.

On top of that, of course, numerous matters have not been brought to the attention of the people before the legislation was introduced in this place about 10 days ago. Those matters were not contained in the original statement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in September last year. For instance, the grant of an option to purchase an asset which was held prior to 20 September 1985 in consideration of an option fee would not in normal circumstances produce a capital gain in the hands of the granter of the option. But for the purposes of this legislation, apparently that will now be taxable. The grant of a lease of an asset which was held prior to 20 September last year in consideration of a premium would not in normal circumstances have been thought to have given rise to a taxable gain, but now it will be caught. The forfeiture of a deposit received in connection with the prospective sale of an asset held prior to 20 September, which does not proceed, would not in the normal way produce a taxable capital gain in the hands of the recipient, but apparently it will be caught. There are numerous other points, such as the one which the Minister mentioned regarding charities, and the gifts being made to charities being now subject to tax. Clearly, that will restrict people's intentions to assist charities by making bequests of assets to them in their wills.

For these reasons the Opposition will maintain its position of opposition to this tax. We believe that not only is it basically wrong in principle, for all the reasons we have outlined during the second reading debate, but also we are very concerned about some of the detailed measures, some of which I have just mentioned. Indeed, some cases and circumstances will be caught by this tax, which perhaps was not the intention of the Government. Nevertheless, the Government intends to proceed with it. For those reasons we will continue to oppose the Bill during the Committee stage.

speech.speaker: Haines Sen J.

talk.start.para: â€”The Australian Democrats, as Senator Siddons would have indicated in his speech during the second reading debate, certainly applaud the actions of this Government in finally introducing a capital gains tax and bringing us, as the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) indicated, into step with most countries of the Western world. This fact makes it all the more surprising, of course, that the Opposition in the Senate and in another place is attempting to frighten people generally about a capital gains tax, which is so mild that it will raise only about $5m in the first year and $10m in the second year. Yet, if one listens to the Opposition, it will be the end of the Western world as we know it.

speech.para: The absence of a capital gains tax has been one of the greatest causes of tax avoidance in this country. I suspect that it is because the capital gains tax strikes at the entrenched interests of the wealthy and powerful, who are supported by the Opposition parties, that the Opposition parties are mounting this campaign in the hysterical manner they are. Most tax avoidance measures-including the infamous bottom of the harbour schemes, which the previous Liberal Government took some 10 years to do something about and which caused the average Australian taxpayer to make up the difference by paying higher taxes-relied on converting income to capital in order to reduce the tax payable.

It would appear from listening to Liberal senators' speeches in the chamber today that the only people who are supposed to pay taxes are those who earn their income by working for a wage or salary. Speculators, so-called risk takers, gamblers and people who make windfall gains are all supposed to be exempt from paying tax on the profit they generate from those activities. People who sell their labour or capacity to work, as far as the Opposition is concerned, must pay tax on their income, but people who sell assets are tax exempt, even if those assets are in the form of real estate and in the process of making a capital gain by speculating, gambling or risk taking, as some senators would have it, the cost of real estate generally is pushed up for those people on wages and salaries who pay tax. If this is stopped, presumably more people will be in a position to own their own homes and buy their own land, because the prices will not be pushed up by speculators. Senator Townley's concern for those people who cannot get hold of rental property in the private rental market will not be necessary any more because more of those people will be able to own their own homes.

Why should someone who works hard for an income of, say, $20,000 be expected to pay tax on that, while a person who makes a $20,000 gain from the sale of a piece of real estate, having done nothing in the process, be exempt, as he or she currently is, if the land, house or whatever is held for more than 12 months? The Democrats believe that, on the grounds of tax equity alone, there should be a general capital gains tax. People who derive their income from capital gains should not be exempt from tax when the average pay as you earn taxpayers cannot avoid paying tax on their salaries.

The fact of the matter is that everybody in this chamber, and I would imagine everybody in Australia, believes that this country needs more productive private investment. Exempting capital gains for tax simply distorts investment decision by encouraging investment in assets offering tax free returns in the form of capital gains, even when this is not necessarily the most productive form of investment. We have seen some of that recently in attempts by people to take over other companies. They have been borrowing the money from overseas, paying the interest out of this country, deducting that interest from their Australian tax return and expecting that if they sell the company they have taken over-if it has not been a particularly productive take- over-for a profit, they will not need to pay any form of capital gains tax on it at all. People are using the tax system as it stands in order to have a bit each way. A capital gains tax will encourage productive investment and reduce a lot of the speculative investment in land, shares and takeovers; the sort of speculation with which Senator Michael Baume is quite familiar.

The Australian Democrats have, and have had since our inception, a policy which supports a capital gains tax. The fact that the Hawke machine at some stage during an election campaign promised that it would not introduce a capital gains tax is irrelevant as far as our policy decisions are concerned. Since 1977, on the grounds of tax equity, the Democrats' taxation policy has argued for a capital gains tax. For that reason, if for no other, we will certainly be supporting the legislation. In doing so we have ensured that only realised gains are to be taxed; capital losses are to be deductible against gains; the family home is exempt; capital gains are indexed for inflation, so that only real gains are taxed; the tax is not applied retrospectively; death is not deemed to be realisation of an asset; and we have included, for small business in particular, some generous five-year averaging provisions.

Finally, there is an exemption of 20 per cent of the goodwill component from capital gains for businesses worth less than $1m. The legislation provides, however, for the exemption of 20 per cent of any taxable capital gain on the goodwill component of the proceeds of the sale of a business, provided the net business interests of a taxpayer are less than $1m and that the business sold is an original or new business. The amendment that has been circulated in the name of the Australian Democrats will delete the latter condition, so that all taxable capital gains in respect of goodwill, where the taxpayer has net business assets of less than $1m, will be subject to a 20 per cent exemption, giving those people effectively a lump sum superannuation payment as a consequence of the work they have put in.

Goodwill generally arises where an enterprise establishes a good name or some other advantage for the identifiable products or services it offers for sale. When this amendment is carried, any business which has net assets below $1m will be able to have exempted 20 per cent of the tax payable on the goodwill component of the value of the sale. This will extend across the board and will include any person-primary producer or otherwise-where there is a goodwill component in the valuation of the assets; for example, in areas where a reputation for quality is involved, and that includes a number of areas in the primary sector. I seek leave to move together the two amendments circulated in my name.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

speech.para: (1) Page 96, clause 19, proposed new paragraphs 160zzr (1) (d) and (e), lines 10 to 27, leave out the proposed new paragrahs.
(2) Page 97, clause 19, proposed new sub-sections 160zzr (3) and (4), lines 7 to 17, leave out the proposed new sub-sections.
I repeat that the amendments will extend the goodwill provision across the board to all businesses, not just to original or new businesses, as is inserted in the Bill before us.

talk.start.para: â€”Until I heard Senator Haines just now, I had thought that the Australian Democrats' position in support of the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill and the Income Tax (Rates) Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill was taken simply because they had done some kind of dishonourable deal with the Government in exchange for something else. Having listened to Senator Haines, it is now evident that, in addition to that proposition, she simply does not understand what on earth this is all about.
â€”Like you understand share trading?

â€”It was an incredible speech. Apart from her endeavour to insult me by saying that I know more about something than she does, I suggest she might extend that over a great range of activities and she would be equally accurate. Just listen to some of the comments Senator Haines made. She said that according to the Opposition speculative risk takers are all supposed to be exempt from tax.

â€”Order! The debate should be confined to the matter that is before the Chair at the moment-that is, the Australian Democrats' amendments to clause 19. When we have dealt with those we can return to the debate on the Bill.
â€”Thank you, Mr Chairman, I will reserve my remarks until then.
â€”I just wish to indicate that the Government will not oppose the amendments.

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”This debate has thrown some new light on the matter. Naturally enough the Opposition has been drawing attention to the problem of goodwill and we are very interested in the point that has been raised by Senator Haines in her amendments. However, we believe that this matter requires a little more thought. Therefore we will seek to have the Committee report progress at this stage so that we can examine the matter further. We would like to take it to our party room so that we can consider it in detail. Therefore I move:

speech.para: That the Chairman of Committees report progress and ask for leave to sit again.

talk.start.para: â€”I understood that whether or not the Opposition understood or accepted the amendments, the Government would still accept them anyway. Therefore I do not see that there is any need for us to report progress.
â€”Order! The question to report progress is not open to debate.

â€”I am sorry, Mr Chairman, I was distracted by the toing and froing immediately preceding this discussion. I checked with the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and I understood him as saying he would not support these amendments. Is he now saying something else? If he is, I think we should take time to look at the amendments and consider them appropriately.
â€”That is hardly the point. The Democrats have said that it doesn't really matter--
â€”On a point of order, Mr Chairman: Is the motion to report progress before the Committee or not?

interject.speaker: The CHAIRMAN

talk.start.para: â€”That is what I am trying to clear up. If the motion to report progress is before the Committee it means there can be no debate on it. I must put the question without debate. I was only trying to clarify whether Senator Messner wished to pursue the motion. If he does I will put the question.

interject.para: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Messner's) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

interject.speaker: The CHAIRMAN

talk.start.para: â€”The question is:

interject.para: That Senator Haines's amendments to clause 19 of the Income Tax Assessment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986 be agreed to.

talk.start.para: â€”During the division Senator Haines did me the courtesy of apologising for not providing us with a copy of the amendments that she proposed at the last moment. I thank her for that. Nevertheless, I believe we must draw attention to the fact that these issues need to be properly considered and discussed by the Opposition when it raises such severe principles as those raised by these amendments. The Opposition will not oppose these amendments, notwithstanding that in principle we object wholeheartedly to the tax. In light of the fact that we cannot stop the progress of the Committee stage of the debate on the Bill in order to give full consideration to the matter, we will have to accept the amendments. Given that relief will be provided to taxpayers through a most iniquitous and unfair tax such as the capital gains tax, ours was a reasonable proposition, and our opposition to the Bill in principle stands. Nevertheless, let me make it quite clear that the Opposition will not oppose the Australian Democrats' amendments.

â€”I thank Senator Messner for expressing the Opposition's support for the amendments. I again apologise to him for what was in fact an oversight. My colleague Senator Siddons, who would normally have been dealing with this legislation, whizzed off to a board meeting of his own company and overlooked the small matter of circulating the amendments. I accept Senator Messner's support and I am most pleased that I have not upset him for all time because of that oversight.

speech.speaker: Walters Sen M.S.

talk.start.para: â€”I was rather surprised and horrified to hear Senator Haines tell us that what we thought did not really matter as long as the Government and she were in agreement. I can assure Senator Haines that, despite the fact that she, siding with the Government, or the Government siding with the Australian Democrats, may have views on this subject, our views matter very much to our Party. For Senator Haines to tell us so arrogantly that our views are neither here nor there because she happens to have the numbers on this issue is quite reprehensible, and she should apologise to us on that account.

speech.para: Amendments agreed to.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: â€”I mentioned that Senator Haines appeared to have some difficulty understanding what this legislation is all about. I must say, however, by way of concession, that it was she who, in moving the amendments to which we have just agreed, explained to the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) what the word `goodwill' means. I congratulate her because the Minister had no idea of the meaning of that word. Naturally, one would expect that. So to that extent, I congratulate Senator Haines, if indeed it was her effort. It may well have been that of Senator Siddons who has left to attend to something he obviously considers much more important; that is, looking after his company and settling its affairs before it gets hit with this tax.

speech.para: The matter I particularly wanted to raise with regard to Senator Haines was her comment that, according to the Opposition, speculative risk takers are all supposed to be exempt from tax. That is just arrant nonsense. There is a tax on capital gain of a speculative nature. It has existed for many years. It exists now. That tax, which is at the marginal rate and which is probably the highest tax on speculative capital gains in the world, is not being changed in any way by this Government. For Senator Haines to pretend that the Opposition, in opposing this capital gains tax, is opposing the concept of tax on speculative gains is deceptive nonsense. It is a pity that Senator Haines was not prepared to stay in the chamber and receive a modest amount of instruction on a matter about which she clearly knows absolutely nothing.

Senator Haines made the point that if what she called this rip-off of speculative gains were stopped, more people would be able to buy their own homes because the price of homes would fall. She forgets that under this package, the number of homes being built will diminish enormously because it will simply not be worth while for investors to build homes. Senator Haines cannot grasp the concept that in order for one to buy or sell a home, that home has to be built at some stage. The impact of this tax package will be to diminish significantly the incentives for people to build new homes.

In general Senator Haines attacked the Opposition in such a ludicrous way that it is hardly worth while continuing to point out examples. One of the things that she said was that people who derived their income from capital gains should pay tax. Of course they do, because they are professionals in this area. Under the rules that exist now, people who make their income from this kind of gain are deemed by the Commissioner of Taxation to be traders, and as a result, they pay income tax at the income tax rate on that kind of gain.

talk.start.para: â€”It does not have to be shares. It could be hotels. It could be shops or it could be businesses.

â€”As the honourable senator says, it could be any asset. It could be a house. It could be any capital gain. Perhaps Senator Haines did not understand that point when she made the ludicrous allegation that people who derive their income from capital gains should pay tax and that we are somehow objecting to it. If she does not know what the tax law is, for heavens sake, I plead with the Australian Democrats not to allow her to come into the chamber and lead for her Party on this matter and try to lecture us in a nonsensical way.

speech.para: I wish to move very quickly to a couple of comments that Senator Walsh made. I noticed that when he was busily saying `wrong, wrong, wrong' to the various points that had been raised, he carefully avoided responding to any interjection which related to a matter of fact. I remind the honourable senator that our complaint with regard to losses related to their not being indexed. It is good enough to index gains, but the loss which is carried forward is carried forward unindexed, so it diminishes as inflation rises. Under this Government inflation is now at a record level relative to the rest of the world. As it continues to rise, under this Government and under this unreasonable proposition the value of that loss will diminish. Let the Minister address his responses to the points which we actually make in opposition instead of inventing them and blowing over aunt sallys.

Finally, I wish to say this: Senator Walsh, in talking about the Waste Watch Committee, repeated a totally incorrect piece of nonsense which he has been perpetuating ever since he became desperate to find some reason for denigrating the efforts of the Waste Watch Committee. I understand why he has done that. I have already explained to Senator Walsh that I understand that he regrets the fact that he cannot say and do the same things to his colleagues that he has seen the Waste Watch Committee do, because his interests are exactly those of the Waste Watch Committee, and he knows it. It is just his frustration and his incompetence within this Government that prevent him from doing so, just as his incompetence and that of his Department prevented the Australian Broadcasting Corporation from saving $12m on foreign exchange dealings. Senator Walsh repeated a deliberate untruth about the Waste Watch Committee when he said that half of what the Waste Watch Committee has exposed relates to what happened under Fraser. That is total nonsense. The Minister knows it is total nonsense, but he is only too happy to repeat it. The Minister has this kind of intellect--

talk.start.para: â€”Order! Senator Baume, your remarks are very wide of what is allowed in the Committee stage of the debate on this Bill. I ask you to relate your remarks to the Bill.
â€”I am responding, Mr Chairman, to--
â€”I take a point of order, Mr Chairman. What clause of the Bill is Senator Baume addressing?
â€”I am dealing with that matter at the moment. The honourable senator must be relevant to either of the Bills before the Committee.
â€”This relates to the generality of the legislation in the Committee stage. The alternative to this legislation, which is what the Minister raised, is a cutting of government expenditure.
â€”Order! I cannot let the honourable senator speak about cutting government expenditure in this debate. He has to be relevant to the Bills before us in the Committee stage.

â€”All I can say then is that, in the present tax crisis, of which this legislation is one of the instruments, it has certainly been asserted that this kind of law-we have the specific instances here-could well be replaced by this saving of government money. It will have exactly the same impact. This tax is aimed at raising $5m, that is all, in the next year. It would be very easy indeed-in fact, the Waste Watch Committee has established this very clearly-for the Government to save the $5m which is to be raised in the specific clauses in this legislation. That is a self-evident truth. The point clearly is that we have established the manner in which the kind of money that is to be raised in these specific areas-$5m this year-can be raised by the savings that have been pointed out by the Waste Watch Committee, not one of which relates to anything that was done by the previous Government.
â€”Order! The honourable senator must remain relevant to this debate.

â€”I wish to ask the Minister two very quick questions. I think I am on record as saying what I think about this tax and how it will knock incentive out of the community; so I do not think I will go on any further about it. It appears that the capital gains tax could apply to plant and machinery which are subject to depreciation. Under existing legislation, where the selling price exceeds the cost, the difference is not liable to tax, so obviously plant registers will have to be kept. Would that be a correct assumption? My other question is in regard to leases. When machinery is leased and that lease is paid out, is the capital gains tax paid on the difference between the residual and the realised price on the resale of that asset or not? Could I have that on record?

â€”I am getting a note on the second question. In regard to the first question, under the existing income tax law, if the plant is depreciated and then sold for an amount greater than the depreciated balance, the difference between the two is taxable as income already, unless it exceeds 100 per cent, which would have to be seen as a perversity, I would have thought, in the law. Under the capital gains tax, in the event of plant being depreciated over several years and then sold for a price in excess of 100 per cent of the original price, indexed to the consumer price index, any figure in excess of that will be taxable.
â€”Indexed from when?
â€”From the date of purchase.
â€”That is the day on which the lease is paid out?

â€”No. I said I was getting a note on the second question. This just relates to a purchase. It is highly unlikely, of course. Indeed, I cannot imagine it ever happening. If ever anyone were lucky enough to have that happen that person should be happy to pay 50 per cent of it in tax. I am getting a note on the second question.

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I seek leave to have the two Bills before the Committee treated separately.
â€”That is, put to a vote separately?
â€”Put to a vote separately.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: â€”What will happen is that we will debate both Bills concurrently and, at the end of the debate, I will put the two Bills separately to be voted on by the Committee, if that is what is required.
â€”Apparently the answer to Senator Brownhill's second question is a bit complicated; so I will supply it to the honourable senator in writing later.
â€”I ask that it be incorporated in Hansard at that stage.

â€”I wish to ask the Minister a question in respect of Division 18. I am sure that this is clear to the Minister and to his advisers but it is not thoroughly clear to me. The definition of `principal residence' refers to somebody required to depart temporarily from his residence for a period not greater than four years being able to claim the residence as the principal residence providing he provides instructions and information to the Commissioner of Taxation in writing. Notwithstanding the fact that that person might want to rent it out--
â€”What page is that on?

â€”It is on page 87, at line 40. There is an exemption for a temporary absence from a residence which, by definition, is normally held to be the principal or sole residence. It seems to me, on a quick reading of the legislation, that it refers to the residence being able to be claimed as the principal residence for a period of absence not exceeding four years. I am asking what would normally happen if a diplomat, a civil servant or a bank officer is required to be away from that residence for a period greater than four years? In the meantime that person is required to rent that property. He does not purchase another but he has to rent another for his own purposes. Does it still remain the principal private residence for a period greater than four years?
â€”I will have to seek some advice.
â€”Mr Chairman, I am quite happy for the reply to my question to be given later in the evening, as long as it can be incorporated in Hansard.
â€”I will be suspending the sitting of the Senate in about two minutes; so I doubt whether business will be completed on these two Bills. Perhaps the answer could be given after 8 o'clock.

â€”I hope that I have this right. I think the interpretation given to me is what Senator Crichton-Browne thought has been confirmed. If a person is away from that principal residence for more than four years, it will be deemed to be no longer the principal residence.
â€”That is notwithstanding the fact that he may not purchase another one but he is just required, because of his duties, to be away.
â€”As I understand it, it is irrespective of whether that person purchases another residence in that time.

â€”I am sorry, it looks as though we will not be able to complete the business by 6.30. Where a property is held and the fourth year runs out and that property continues to be held but, obviously, after that date is not designated a principal residence, what is the value of the house for the purposes of any future capital gains tax that would be incurred in respect of that residence? Will it run from the date of the original purchase or will it run from the date at which the four years run out?

â€”As for other assets, in the event of a subsequent sale, it having been deemed at some point no longer to be the principal residence, the taxable proportion of any real gain will be determined by the total period between 19 September and the day of sale, less whatever portion of that time it was the principal residence of the taxpayer.
â€”So you just apportion it?
â€”Yes, it is the general portionment provision.

â€”As I understand it, if one has a family farm, which is a good example, which is passed on as an estate from parents to sons and grandsons, as long as it is passed on as such it does not attract a capital gains tax. But at the time it is ultimately sold the base for determining the capital gains and the sale price is the price at which it was sold to the last person-or is it the first person? If the property is sold for $1m--

interject.speaker: The CHAIRMAN

talk.start.para: â€”I think the honourable senator will have to ask this question after dinner and the Minister will have a chance to reply then.

interject.para: Sitting suspended from 6.31 to 8 p.m.

talk.start.para: â€”Before the suspension of the sitting the Minister for Finance was going to answer a question that I asked earlier regarding leasing.
â€”I am advised on plant leasing that whatever is paid for the residual value of the plant is the cost of the asset for capital gains tax purposes.

â€”The residual value of a harvester may be $30,000 or something like that. When that harvester is traded-in on a new harvester the trade-in value could be $120,000. Does that mean that the capital gains tax will be for the sum of approximately $90,0000?

â€”Yes. Senator Brownhill asked a question about deceased estates. The answer is that the asset can be passed down from one deceased person to another without attracting tax. It can be passed down more than once.

â€”I was not listening carefully to the question or answer, but I think the Minister answered in part the question that I was going to ask regarding the family farm which was the example I was giving before the suspension of the sitting. It might well pass from generation to generation. There might be five generations over which the farm does not attract a capital gains tax, but one might find that in 70 or 80 years time, because there are no further sons, the farm is sold. Is the cost base for the calculation of the capital gains tax the cost base at the time of the purchase immediately following the first purchase after 20 September last year?
â€”That is correct, with the addition that the figure, whatever it is, would be indexed for the consumer price index from the same time.

â€”I seek clarification on the question I asked about leasing arrangements. The Minister just said yes in answer to that question. That would mean a quite horrific capital gains tax for people who have leased machinery after 19 September last year.

â€”A more complete and comprehensive explanation is that where the lessee acquired the asset after 19 September 1985 the capital gains tax will apply. In the case of the sale of appreciable assets, whether acquired by a lessee at the end of the lease or otherwise, the capital gains tax will apply on a residual basis, taxing any excess of the sale value over its purchase cost, with indexation applying to the purchase cost. Where profits on trade-ins are not taxed under existing income tax provisions the capital gains tax will apply. I think this gets back to the question I answered a while ago-I regard it as an anomaly, but that is a value judgment, I suppose-that if plant which has been partially written off for tax purposes is sold for more than its original price it is taxed and the gain is taxed only up to the original price. With the capital gains tax it may be taxed beyond that but with the important addition again that the original price would be indexed. As I said before, the chances of it happening are extremely remote.

â€”I do not mean to be nit picking, but I want to get it absolutely clear. Does the point about the purchase cost which the Minister mentioned refer to the residual cost in the case of a lease? We are not talking about the original purchase, are we?

â€”I am advised that the existing law requires that if an arrangement is to be accepted as a lease for income tax purposes the lessee can have no right, express or implied, to purchase the leased asset. In other words, it cannot be bought while it is still being leased. When the lease has expired a person may buy it.
â€”So, that is the purchase cost, the residual value?
â€”Yes.

â€”I am certain the Minister for Finance answered a previous question because he said there were no qualifications in respect of a home which has not been occupied for a period in excess of four years. As I say, I think there are no exemptions. In other words, if one or both of a married couple are required to live in a frail aged home for a period greater than four years, the home which has been a family home for very many years would therefore lose that status, would it?

â€”I will give the example of a person who buys a house and lives in it for six years and is then absent from it for more than four years-say, four years and a day. Regardless of what happens thereafter it is deemed to be not the principal private residence. Let us assume that it is sold 20 years after the original purchase. The gain would then be apportioned according to the total time that it was the principal residence of the owner and that would be six-twentieths; six-twentieths of it would be exempt.

â€”In the event that an executor is instructed by the terms of an estate to dispose of the estate before distribution, a capital gains tax will apply. Very often that does happen because in many families there is a fight over various parts of the assets. I am not necessarily talking about private assets because they are excluded under the Act, but that is the general reason that the executor is instructed to dispose of the assets before distribution. In the event that the deceased, prior to dying, so arranges his affairs as to apportion the estate intact amongst the beneficiaries, would a capital gains tax apply at that time?

â€”I am not sure that I understood the question and I am not certain that my answer will be correct. This will be subject to confirmation. Let us assume it was a farm which had been purchased some time after 19 September 1985 and the owner died and instructed the executor to sell the property before distribution. If there were a real gain on that property that real gain would be taxable-unless it were a private residence.

â€”Perhaps the example of a farm is a bad one. For instance, let us say that the estate contains a block of flats and a small factory. Let us say that the deceased distributes the block of flats to one son and the small factory to another son. In that case would they attract capital gains tax?
â€”That is correct.

â€”I wish to make just one final point. I understand that in the event of a marital breakdown a capital gains tax would not be applied to the transfer of assets? Firstly, is that correct? The second question that flows from that is: What would occur with the apportionment of capital gains tax against different kinds of assets, for example, where there is one exempt asset and one non-exempt asset? I instance the case of a marital breakdown where a house and a block of flats are part of the total property of the partners. One of those assets, the house, would be exempt while the other asset, the block of flats, would not be exempt. I refer to a capital gains tax being charged in respect of the eventual transfer of that block of flats to one of the partners. Will there be any apportionment of that tax back to the other partner who was part of the marital breakdown?

â€”In relation to the first question, by a roll-over is allowed. I do not know the answer to the second question. Essentially what the honourable senator is interested in knowing is whether some of the tax liability, assuming that there is a tax liability, will be transferred back to the original owner?
â€”Yes.
â€”I will have to get some advice on that.
â€”Can we expect an answer now or later?

â€”I am advised-I hope I have this right-that there is no way that any tax liability, if there were one, could be passed back to the person from whom the property was rolled over. However, under some circumstances, providing all the other conditions were met, that could attract a tax liability to the person to whom the property was rolled over.
â€”In relation to proposed new section 160zyf I am a little unclear how the profits on the sale of bonus shares will be taxed. In other words, what cost will be attributed to the bonus shares?
â€”The same as for income tax purposes.
â€”Would that be the base value of the share at the time of the bonus issue?

speech.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: â€”Again, I hope I have this right, but the price of bonus shares is determined by watering down the market price of the original shares. If it is a one for two bonus issue then two-thirds of whatever was the value of the two shares previously existing will be deemed to be the value of the bonus shares.
â€”That is the market value?
â€”It is what was paid for the two original shares in that example.
â€”Even if it were before 19 September 1985?
â€”If the original shares were owned before 19 September 1985, the bonus shares will not be affected.
â€”Would it be different after 19 September?

â€”After 19 September it would be treated in the way that I have explained-the purchase price would be diluted by whatever proportion the original shares had been watered down by the issue of the bonus.

That the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986, as amended, be agreed to.

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”On this day of national disgrace we have observed the jackbooted approach not only of the Government but also of the Australian Democrats who have passed capital gains tax legislation against the will of the Australian people. The Opposition has stood for fairness and equity in taxation.

speech.para: Honourable senators interjecting-

talk.start.para: â€”Order! Honourable senators will please remain silent.

â€”I guarantee that the people on the other side of the chamber who have witnessed this day of national disgrace have not read any of the legislation that has been put before them. Over the last four or five days four Government senators and 19 Opposition senators have spoken on the fringe benefits taxation legislation. In the case of the capital gains tax legislation, two Government senators have been prepared to stand up and defend their Government's decision while we in Opposition have put forward 15 speakers. That shows the depth of feeling of the Australian people on this matter and the lack of interest on the part of the Government in this most important piece of legislation.

speech.para: Honourable senators interjecting-

talk.start.para: â€”Order! I ask honourable senators to observe dignity and decorum. I ask that Senator Messner be heard in silence.

â€”The Government, having pushed this measure through against the will of the people, clearly is in breach of the sacred commandments which, immediately preceding the Taxation Summit last year, the Government itself declared as the criteria for taxation reform. The Government said that we would have simple legislation, that the legislation would have widespread support in the community and that the legislation would introduce a new wave in respect of of anti-tax avoidance. On all of those grounds all of the legislation that we have discussed up until now has failed. I note that Government senators cannot take the heat and are leaving the chamber. They know they are wrong and they know that they should not have supported this legislation.

speech.para: It is clear that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) is not going to change his mind about anything at this late stage. However, I want to make the point that the passage of this package of legislation will produce enormous changes in the Australian economy. They will not be the favourable ones which this Government has predicted. In fact, the reverse will be the case. We await with interest the outcome of the next few months as the real effects of what the Government has done here in the last few days come to pass. We do not oppose the passage of this Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.

speech.speaker: Foreman Sen D.J.

talk.start.para: â€”by leave-In accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act, I present the report relating to the construction of the State Mail Centre, 501 Williamstown Road, Port Melbourne.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: â€”by leave-The two buildings currently occupied by the State Mail Centre are more than 60 years old, have numerous operational deficiencies and do not meet the requirements of new mail handling techniques. The Committee accepts that 501 Williamstown Road, Port Melbourne, is the only site available for Australia Post's purposes within the criteria determining its activities. speech.para: The Committee is satisfied that the design of the new building adequately fulfils the requirements of new mail handling techniques and provides sufficient space to cater for forecast needs to the year 2005. The Committee recommends construction of the work in the reference.
