Debate resumed from 14 March, on motion by Senator Gietzelt:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Archer Sen B.R.

talk.start.para: â€”This is a most disappointing piece of legislation for both the Australian Federal Police and Australia generally. It is an absolute nothing Bill at a time when Australian Federal Police legislation needs a lot of stiffening. The Australian Federal Police is the Commonwealth's front line to attack major crime. It has the job of being involved in problems in a whole range of things such as drugs, money laundering, illegal immigration, bookmaking, tax evasion, gambling, social security fraud, race fixing, murder, extortion and video piracy. That is the sort of job that we expect them to do. But at present they are absolutely hamstrung because they are stifled by a complete shortage of manpower, a lack of facilities and, above all, a lack of government support. They are getting plenty of promises-there is no shortage in that regard-but no real support of any sort. Inquiries are still being conducted and reports written. The recommendations from all those inquiries and reports happen to be much the same, as is the action, or lack of it, as the case may be.

speech.para: The Special Minister of State, Mr Young, in the other place, proudly parroted the achievements of the Government with regard to the Federal Police. But when one looks at them, they simply do not add up. Of most concern is the fact that the Minister in his second reading speech promised $17.2m for law enforcement which was to go to the Federal Police. An amount of $10m was for staffing and $7.2m for computing. Of course, when we looked at it, we saw that it was the same $17.2m that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promised a little later at the time of the so-called drug offensive. It was the same $17.2m that was promised after the AFP resources report was issued on 14 November 1985 and which was again promised by the Minister at that stage. It was the same $17.2m promised in May last year at the Drug Summit. Of course, it was the same $17.2m that was promised in 1983 in the run-up to the election. As yet, of course, with all the promises, we have only just started to see the tiniest tip of the corner of that allocation. I guarantee that we will find that that amount is promised several times more before the money is actually allocated.

Ten million dollars of that amount was for manpower. As Mr Young said early on, as the Prime Minister said before the 1984 election and as Mr Young again said in February this year, the amount was to cover the three-year period 1984-87. That covers, of course, the years 1984-85, 1985-86, and 1986-87. That was the promise that we had. But when we came to check on it during the Estimates committee hearings in April we found that we had slipped a year already. We now find it is being stretched out until 1988. Was it meant to cover a three-year term or a four-year term? Was the funding supposed to start, as both the Prime Minister and the Minister said, in 1983-84, or was it due to go on until 1987-88? One thing was promised, but maybe something else will be delivered.

What is the Government's attitude towards crime in general and what is it endeavouring to do? These amendments, of course, will do nothing in the pursuit of real crime. I ask again: When will we see some amendments to the legislation that could really make an impact on real crime? I am not talking about the pickpockets, the little cheque cashers, the petty swindlers, and so on. I am talking about real crooks. Why are we prevented from seeing legislation that is in line with the recommendations given by strings of reports, advisers and inquiries? Let us have a crack at the big crooks. I do not know why we should be protecting them any more.

I think that the personnel of the AFP are tremendous. They operate under these sorts of circumstances and they exhibit great skill, diligence and dedication. They are deserving of more practical support. I have visited many divisions of the AFP and have seen officers of that force and other forces around Australia. They expect the Parliament to give them support. Let us look at some of the information that is available. I guess that the best place to start is with the 1985 annual report. The comments made in that report by Commissioner Grey say a lot, in themselves. On the first page of the report he states:

In my view, drug trafficking and organised crime emerge as the areas most needing more resources. In addition to the need for more investigative staff, improved supporting capabilities and intelligence gathering, surveillance, technical (particularly electronic) support, witness protection are absolutely critical to the achievement of A.F.P. objectives.
On the next page he states:

I believe that the criminal elements within society must be controlled, and therefore without question essential `Special-to-task' resources must be provided to all law enforcement organisations. A reshuffling of the same particular resources of the A.F.P. between organisations is not the answer.

In that case he was referring particularly to the fact that the Federal Police have had to make available staff for various other organisations that have been set up. One cannot use the same person in more than one place at the one time. As a result of these reports we have had a considerable amount of abuse from both Government senators and Ministers, I regret, in regard to the value judgment of such people as Judge Moffitt and Judge Webster. From the Minister's inquiry into AFP resources, which reported on 14 November last year, his assessment of the very real problems concluded:
The Group was presented with cases of serious criminal activities which are not being investigated because of staff shortages.
A bit later, the report states:
As for the smaller criminal activities such as many DSS (Social Security) cheque frauds, most of these are unable to be investigated . . .

That was because of a lack of staff. We have still heard nothing of consequence. The Government has had plenty of advice and plenty of time, but precious little has come forward. That report produced 28 recommendations. At an Estimates committee hearing a month or so ago, I asked what action had been taken in respect of those 28 recommendations. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a copy of the responses to those 28 recommendations.
Leave granted.
The responses read as follows-
Recommendation
1. Immediate action be taken to prepare a resource deployment program for the next five years (p. 103).
Action
Program at present being completed by AFP.
Recommendation

2. Recruitment of new members to the AFP be raised from its current level of 200-250 per annum to 350-400 per annum over the next three years and the necessary infrastructure be provided, with requisite AOSL cover for recruits, following which there should be a further review of AFP resources.
Action

Implementation dependent on Government consideration for increased staff numbers. Development of infrastructure, including required training accommodation, proceeding in accordance with Joint Management Review recommendations.
Recommendation
3. Two hundred public service staff be recruited to the OAFP over the next three financial years.
Action
Implementation dependent on Government consideration of increased staff numbers.
Recommendation
4. Terms and conditions be set at a level sufficient to attract and retain good quality recruits and to ensure the AFP is not at a recruitment disadvantage compared with State police forces.
Action
Recommendations of the 1985 Review of AFP Terms and Conditions of Service partially implemented. A review of AFP Arbitral Tribunal determination to go before Mr Justice Coldham in May 1986.
Recommendation

5. The principal recruiting staff be trained detectives and recruitment techniques be introduced in order to select recruits on the basis of assessed potential for detective work rather than uniform work.
Action
Implemented in accordance with 1984 Joint Management Review recommendations.
Recommendation
6. Cost savings resulting from the transfer of functions to other agencies be retained by the AFP in the form of AOSL cover.
Action
Recommendation under examination by AFP/Department of Finance. Joint submission to go forward to Ministers for consideration.
Recommendation
7. While AFP members continue to perform functions on behalf of client Commonwealth organisations and under the direction of those organisations AOSL be recredited to the AFP.
Action
Cost recovery for uniform police deployment to airports under consideration. Where AFP members are seconded to other Commonwealth organisations they do not count against the AFP's AOSL.
Recommendation
8. The guarding of Family Court judges residences and court premises cease to be a function of the AFP.
Action
Static guarding of Family Court judges residences ceased to be function of the AFP on 28 February 1986. Presence at court precincts reviewed against potential threat.
Recommendation

9. Functions associated with the use of uniformed police inside the Family Court and relating to process serving for the Family Court be removed from the AFP, or else a commercially based cost recovery system be imposed.
Action
See Question 8. Guidelines on `user pays' being developed.
Recommendation

10. All the current general policing and guarding duties carried out by the AFP at Australian airports be performed by other agencies-State police, the Australian Protective Service and private security companies.
Action
Review of AFP operations at airports being conducted to develop functional plans and `modus operandi'.
Recommendation
11. Pending the transfer of uniformed function at airports, the Department of Aviation be billed for the services provided so that costs may be included in the changing algorithm.
Action
Under consideration by Government in 1986-87 Budget context.
Recommendation
12. The AFP plainclothes presence at airports be enhanced.
Action
AFP operations at airports being reviewed in accordance with ministerial objectives and priorities.
Recommendation
13. The diplomatic and consular guarding function be transferred from the AFP.
Action
Provision of static guards where necessary is under review by the Officials Committee on Law Enforcement.
Recommendation
14. The static guarding function at official establishments be transferred from the AFP to the Australian Protective Service.
Action
Approved in principle, action on transfer expected to be completed by 1 July 1986.
Recommendation
15. The static guarding function at the current Parliament House be transferred from the AFP.
Action
Being reviewed in the context of guarding arrangements to be put in place for the new Parliament House.
Recommendation
16. The AFP no longer execute warrants or serve processes on behalf of Commonwealth client organisations; alternatively client organisations should be charged a commercially-based cost recovery fee.
Action
AFP execute only those warrants directed by the Court. User pay principle being reviewed at present.
Recommendation
17. The user pay principle be applied generally to all Commonwealth organisations and other major users of AFP resources.
Action
The application of this principle is at present under review.
Recommendation
18. Greater use be made of skilled civilians on contract and of special member provisions of the AFP Act to alleviate shortages of skilled members.
Action
Application of the ``Human Resource Use'' policy recommended by the Joint Management Review which is a general policy in relation to this issue is now in place.
Recommendation
19. The AFP Act be amended to permit:
1. the re-appointment of former members
at the discretion of the Commissioner
within 12 months of departure
at the same rank
2. permanent part time employment on the same basis as for the Australian Public Service.
Action
Under consideration at the present time.
To be considered further when APS policy resolved.
Recommendation

20. A review of classification structures be carried out, particularly in the AFP plainclothes functions and the concept of salary loadings for qualified detectives actively involved in investigative and intelligence functions be considered.
Action
Discussions are current between the AFP and the AFPA on classification structure in the AFP.
An allowance for members designated detective or engaged in investigative/intelligence duties was awarded by the Federal Police Arbitral Tribunal in December 1985.
Recommendation
21. The conversion of discretionary or non-urgent overtime funding into additional staff, with appropriate temporary funding over the next 2-3 years.
Action
Needs to be considered in conjunction with proposed staff increases.
Recommendation
22. A study be conducted to quantify the offsetting effects of extra capital and equipment expenditure with a view to budget action in 1986-87.
Action
Study not yet undertaken.
Recommendation

23. The development of regular statistical reporting from the regions and major line areas at Headquarters, together with appropriate analysis, be given a high priority as a fundamental requirement of good management.
Action

A complete review of the operational Information Management Reporting system within the AFP Investigations Department, including the collation and analysis of statistics, is nearing completion and its implementation will be a priority in the enhanced computer system currently being acquired by the AFP. The project is a pilot for possible development throughout the Force.
Recommendation
24. A mobile resource and systems audit team be constituted to assist in the allocation of resources and in management systems.
Action

The Commissioner has created a Force Development and Analysis Branch within the Office of the Commissioner of Police, to provide a capacity for long term planning including resource use and deployment.
Recommendation
25. The policy in relation to eligibility for promotion courses be reviewed.
Action
Being reviewed by the AFP Personnel & Training Policy and Procedures Committee in conjunction with the AFPA.
Recommendation
26. Staffing for the ACT Region remain at its current level for the foreseeable future.
Action
Implemented in accordance with Ministerial Objectives and Priorities Statement.
Recommendation
27. Funds be provided for appropriate office accommodation in Eastern and Southern Regions, and current proposals for the construction of a purpose built headquarters building in Canberra be pursued.
Action
Proposals being pursued. Government has provided ``in principle'' approvals for the acquisition of office accommodation in Sydney and Melbourne.
Recommendation
28. AFP scientific services be developed consistent with overall objectives and priorities.
Action
Deployment of resources made available to the AFP in the short, and long term, is in accordance with objectives and priorities. Scientific Services will continue to be developed accordingly.

talk.start.para: â€”I thank the Senate. I will not bother going through them individually, because I do not wish to take longer than is necessary. But of those 28 recommendations, five are under action and the rest seem to have the sort of notation beside them that states: `dependent on government consideration', `partly implemented', `under examination', `under consideration', `being reviewed', `being developed', `review being conducted', `under review', `approval in principle', and so it goes on. This shows the way in which the Government typically handles reports. If one wants to do nothing, one refers it for report, and that is exactly what seems to be happening in this regard.

speech.para: There is also the question of duties. We have had raised regularly by all sorts of inquiries-by the Australian Federal Police itself and the Australian Federal Police Association-the question of surveillance functions, airport duties and so on. The Bill is totally inadequate. After all the time there has been in which to prepare a Bill of this sort, there is absolutely nothing in it which will make any worthwhile alterations to the system. This fiddling along with a few alterations is neither here nor there. There is no doubt that crime is big business and it pays well. I would even venture to suggest that the fringe benefits tax, capital gains tax and the assets test will not really interfere with the people who are at the top end of organised crime. There appears to be nothing in this legislation or in the actions of the Government at this stage which will slow it down in any way.

Again, we have been told that Australia is the weak link in international crime investigations. I cannot see anything in this Bill that will change that situation in any way. There is not one change. Instead, we see these few fiddling, housekeeping type amendments which at this stage do no more than say that a policeman who is on dog duty is entitled to take his dog. He now has the authority to undertake protective duties outside the Australian Capital Territory in accordance with his normal functions. There is a change to the review committee of the appeals board. There are monstrous changes such as those that really give us an opportunity to see the Government's attitude towards conquering crime. I do not take any of those changes very seriously, even though I guess they are a necessary part of the clerical work of the Federal Police. The Opposition will not oppose the Bill.

speech.speaker: Macklin Sen M.J.

talk.start.para: â€”The Australian Democrats also will be supporting the Australian Federal Police Amendment Bill, which is of a brief and largely technical nature. It is designed to align the powers of the AFP with the functions of the AFP; to clarify the conditions under which the AFP members are seconded; to improve certain administrative arrangements; and to provide, as Senator Archer has said, for the use of police dogs. In relation to the latter amendment, it is pleasing to see that provision is finally being made for the use of police dogs in hitherto prohibited areas. Now, where a police dog is under the control of a police dog handler, the dog can lawfully be where it is lawful for its handler to be. None of us would deny that this is a wholly sensible arrangement. We can only applaud the fact that this anomaly has now been overcome and that the Senate has moved to remove this enormous obstacle to the fight against crime. Law breakers such as drug smugglers can no longer avoid the attentions of sniffer dogs in certain areas. This is highly pleasing.

speech.para: There is not much more that one could say about the Bill. It only nibbles at the edges of the numerous problems currently confronting the Australian Federal Police, which impinge on the fight against organised crime in this country and the responsibilities of the Parliament and the Government in this regard. It has been pointed out by the Australian Democrats a number of times that it is quite clear that the force is underpaid, overworked, short-staffed and, looking at the comments made constantly in the media by its representatives, thoroughly fed up with its position. There is little doubt that morale is affected adversely when, in recent years, demands on the force have increased many times without a commensurate increase in resources, staffing or funding.

The community and the Parliament expect that the Australian Federal Police will be our major force against organised crime, but members have had to be found to protect Family Court of Australia Judges after the tragic events of recent years, and the Coastal Protection Unit has to be serviced. Additional items are being found constantly. Today we had the news of another operation that the Federal Police will have to carry out in terms of protection of certain Ministers and others in the service of the Parliament. In addition, of course, the force's other responsibilities must be carried out satisfactorily. It is undoubted that this cannot be done on a shoestring budget, nor can trained police officers be plucked out of the air.

The effective administration of this sector of the Special Minister of State portfolio requires far better planning than has been evident in the past. It is pleasing to note the five-year approach that the Australian Federal Police is adopting. I reiterate, however, that with an inadequate budget, inadequate staffing and limited resources, the AFP cannot do what is expected of it or demanded of it by the legislation of this Parliament. There is no doubt, for example, that some investigations have been shelved indefinitely for want of manpower. It seems very strange that in keeping this force understaffed and underfunded we are, in effect, preventing it from doing work which would increase revenue. It is certainly the wrong way of going about solving crime or pursuing criminals. As the Commissioner of Police has pointed out, the best technology and legal advice is available to criminals and is often well ahead of that used by or available to the law enforcement agencies. Of course, this is also true of the Australian Tax Office officials, but is even worse when the position applies to the Australian Federal Police. The lesson to be drawn is that if law enforcement is to maintain the status quo, much less redress the balance in areas such as the use of high technology, we as a nation will have to pay more. I suggest that if we are niggardly in this area it will be to our cost and the cost of the community.

Demands for experienced investigators by commissions of inquiry, the Office of the Special Prosecutor and the National Crime Authority have placed great strain on the resources of the Australian Federal Police, particularly at a time when it is developing its strategy to meet the Government's objectives. The original charter outlining the priorities of the Australian Federal Police combined general policing and investigating organised crime. In September last year, the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) tabled a new charter of objectives which reflects the need to consolidate the AFP as a Federal investigative body with emphasis on specialist functions rather than general policing functions. The directives stressed the importance of an improved intelligence organisation, improved surveillance, technical and forensic support groups and witness protection. A quite proper high priority is placed on increasing the effectiveness and scope of investigations into organised crime, maintaining a capability to investigate large scale fraud against Commonwealth revenue and responding quickly to specific references from Government. However, when one looks at the objectives and the resources, one sees how mismatched they are. The additional resources that have been made available to meet these objectives are meagre compared with the needs set out in those objectives. In the 1984-85 annual report, the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police drew attention to scarce resources and stated that shortage of manpower and funds remains his major concern. He says that crime is costing the nation dearly already and unless the needs of policing in Australia are recognised and effective police counter measures initiated, the loss to our nation will be incalculable.

The fact is that we are pressing on with a band-aid approach in this area and as long as we do so we will not be able to develop a preventive as well as reactive capability. One assumes that the Commissioner is using restrained language and we therefore must pay heed to the real depth of the problem. I could go on to detail other problems; for example, the appalling state of Federal drug squad cars, the stress associated with the long hours worked by some to cover staff shortages, and the other dangers confronting members of the Australian Federal Police. This stress is not made any easier to bear when the police know that their hands are tied behind their backs because they are not given the resources either in human personnel or in technology to make the proper fight against crime, be it petty or organised, any easier to undertake. It is obvious that even if immediate action were taken, it would take some years to train the officers necessary to fill the requisite specialised positions.

In short, the matters covered by this Bill are welcome, but they do not squarely address the outstanding problems confronting the force. The Government's increase in resources has not been adequate and rhetoric will not catch criminals. The Government must get its priorities in order and until it does we will continue to have the quite unsatisfactory situation that we have before us as far as the Australian Federal Police is concerned.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: â€”If the Australian Federal Police Amendment Bill is indeed a nothing Bill, as Senator Archer said, I have to say that his speech was entirely consistent with that characterisation. Senator Macklin's contribution, at least in its opening bars, was about the only one I can think of in recent parliamentary history when Sir Billy Snedden's famous interjection against Gough Whitlam might have been appropriate. I think it is inappropriate for me, given the utterly uncontroversial nature of this Bill, to detain the Senate further on the second reading. I commend that sentiment to others in the Senate as the evening wears on.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

proctext.para: The Bill.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

speech.para: (1) Page 1, sub-clause 2 (2), line 12, leave out ``of the Principal Act''.

This is a momentous amendment to leave out the words `of the Principal Act' where they appear. This expression was a drafting mishap and does not have any substantive significance at all. I say for the record that I think it is unfortunate that the House of Representatives declined to treat this as a proper case for a Chairman's amendment, which is the procedure which has been traditionally adopted where a self-evident slip has been made and where there is no prospect of confusion but a great deal of prospect of delaying the passage of the Bill if the formal amendment process is required. With those comments I commend this correction to the Senate.
