debate.title: COMPANIES AND SECURITIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

proctext.para: Debate resumed from 30 April, on motion by Senator Walsh:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Hill Sen R.

talk.start.para: â€”The Companies and Securities Legislation Amendment Bill 1986 is a Bill to amend both the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Act 1980 and the Companies Act 1981. It is part of the co-operative scheme and it therefore comes to the Senate after a determination of the Ministerial Council. Basically this Bill will replace the pro rata partial takeover regime with a proportional bid system. It attempts to achieve a number of other objectives as well. For example, it attempts in particular to change pre-bid escalation agreements and to address that problem so that institutional holders of shares will not have the advantage of smaller shareholders in being able to negotiate agreements for the sale of their shares with escalation provisions that will allow them to escalate the price to that which is offered in a subsequent bid. Being large shareholders they are able to assist the offerer to attempt to reach his threshold of 20 per cent with the assurance that they will not financially suffer by agreeing to the sale of those shares prior to the eventual bid. The Bill attempts to stop that by providing that any escalation agreement entered into by a bidder in the six months prior to a bid may not be triggered by higher prices offered under the bid. As a matter of interest that rule will apply whether the bid is partial or full.

speech.para: Additionally the Bill attempts to deal with what is known as the multiplier effect. The policy that the Government seeks to adopt is that there can be no so-called multiplier effect permitting a larger proportion of acceptances to be made in relation to an original block of shares where the offeree shareholder accepts a proportional bid and then sells the balance of his shares in the target company to another person who, in turn, accepts the offer for a proportion of the shares he has purchased. Additionally the Bill attempts to deal with the inclusion of what have been known as the `shark repellant articles' in the articles of association of companies. It deals with that by allowing a company to include in its articles a provision requiring a shareholder plebiscite before a partial bid may proceed. Finally, the Bill also amends certain provisions in relation to substantial shareholdings.

It is no secret that this Bill arose substantially out of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd takeover debacle and is therefore tainted with the emotion of that duel which is still continuing. Unlike most of these Bills which come before us-of course normally we have about two companies amending Bills each year-this particular one never went to the public in the form of an exposure draft. On this side of the chamber we believe that it raises a number of important questions: First, the process by which laws are made under this co-operative system and the frustrations that the Senate experiences in not being able to fulfil its proper and constitutional role. That is a matter upon which I will expand later tonight. Furthermore, it raises the question of the whole emotive takeover environment in which we find ourselves in this country at the moment. It raises questions on the economic and social costs and benefits of takeovers. It also raises the question of the wisdom of its primary provision in attempting to outlaw pro rata or partial bids in favour of proportional bids; whether this has been an over-reaction and whether it really achieves the goals that are claimed for it. One of those claims is that it provides a greater equity between large and small shareholders and that is a subject which must be addressed. Finally, it also raises questions which arise out of particular details of the Bill-matters that arise out of the escalation provisions to which I have just referred and particularly matters that arise from the provisions which allow for the `shark repellant' provisions. I will address those in more detail in a few minutes. I begin with the first matter I mentioned-the question of the role of the Parliament in relation to companies legislation. What we are required to do again tonight is to provide a rubber stamp. In being asked to fulfil that role, we are being asked to take part in a farce.

talk.start.para: â€”It is a familiar farce.

â€”Yes, it is a familiar farce. The last time I spoke on one of these Bills I said it was a farce. Now I say it again. We will be told that it is not possible for the Senate to amend the Bill because it has come to us from the Ministerial Council. By passing this legislation we change the appropriate laws of the States and if we attempted to amend it we would therefore be changing a law of a State contrary to that which has been agreed by the ministerial representative of that State through the Ministerial Council. We will be told that we cannot do that. In fact what we are allowed to do is comment and criticise.
â€”And wave our arms.
â€”And wave our arms and make some constructive comments which some people might read. Beyond that, our task is basically non-existent. So what we are doing is quite farcical.
â€”An exercise in futility.

â€”As my colleague says, it is an exercise in futility. We hope that this situation will change. Mr Deputy President, you will be aware that, to assist us in the changes, the Senate has finally taken the matter to task and set up an inquiry, through its Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, to review the role of the Parliament in the exercising of the task of the National Companies and Securities Commission and also the task of the Minister and the responsibility of the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities.

speech.para: Finally, after experiencing the effects of the scheme since it came into operation in 1978 and experiencing the frustrations I have referred to, which, I hasten to add, have been referred to by both sides of the chamber, the Senate through that Committee-I am pleased to see the Chairman, Senator Tate, is present in the chamber-will wrestle with that problem and attempt to find a better way for this Parliament to meet its constitutional responsibility.

The second matter I said I wanted to mention is the framework behind this Bill-the current atmosphere in relation to takeovers. There is obviously a preoccupation within the Australian business community with the subject of takeovers. Billions of dollars are being borrowed and spent on purchasing successful companies. Nobody is borrowing these massive sums in an attempt to build up companies and businesses into successful corporate entities. We find that the preoccupation in this country lies in taking the short cut to wealth and power through borrowing and taking advantage of the generous taxation provisions. Massive sums of money are generally borrowed off-shore in order to follow that short cut by acquiring a successful company.

A question that should face the Government and the Parliament is whether a legislative answer to that problem can be achieved. We can legislatively restrain or retard the ease with which a takeover can take place but we run the risk of suffering from the shortfall because it would mean that inefficient or stale management would be protected in a way that we regard as undesirable. So what it really comes down to is that what is needed from the business community of this country is a change of attitude rather than a change of law by the Government. In mentioning a change of law, I still say-perhaps it is a little beyond my brief-that there are ways that can easily come to one with a little imagination, particularly through the tax laws, by which greater incentives can be given to encourage those in the business community who are prepared to put their efforts and their skills into the growth and development of productive activity rather than simply attempting to take over what has been achieved by others. I bring that point to the attention of this Government and urge that it give greater consideration to what can be done to assist those who want to build the productive endeavour of this country.

The typical attitude in relation to takeovers at the moment can be found in the speeches of Mr Bosch and others, who refer to the `takeover game'. Mr Bosch, in his address to the Company Directors Association of Australia Takeovers Seminar in April of this year, in what, with respect, was basically a good address, fell for what I believe is the same error that we see so often in the business community. For example, in relation to this Bill Mr Bosch said:
. . . I shall offer a few reflections on how the Bill will affect the takeover game in Australia.

Regrettably that is what it has become. That is how it is even being referred to by the Chairman of the National Companies and Securities Commission. The sooner that we can get beyond regarding it as a game and get back to constructive growth in this country, the sooner we will be able to wrestle with the shocking $14 billion balance of trade deficit that we will have this year. Whilst mentioning the Chairman of the NCSC, I have been somewhat concerned as to the attitude he has been taking in basically expressing the view that there are too many takeovers. I have wondered whether that is the appropriate type of sentiment to come from the chairman of a chiefly administrative body; but on further reflection I think that his comment no doubt arises out of the frustration that governments of Australia, which should be looking primarily to those questions of policy, simply are not doing so. I wonder whether that comes back in part to the problem that again no one government is responsible for this field; rather when the responsibility is shared through the Ministerial Council, with no individual immediately and primarily responsible, one tends to look to someone else to take the responsibility.

I urge governments to accept that there is a need to play a lead in this matter. There has been a shocking neglect in recent years in the area of policy relating to this subject. Apart from a neglect, there is also an inconsistency. On one hand, we hear this Government saying: `In our new spirit of free market power we think it is inappropriate for us to interfere or become involved'. On the other hand, we know that the Government conducted kitchen cabinet inquiries in secrecy into the wisdom of the takeover of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. That shows an obvious inconsistency and it also demonstrates a great uncertainty of direction on the part of this Government, and it is time that a real lead was shown.

The third area that I said I would mention in this contribution deals with the primary part of this Bill, and that is the outlawing of pro rata partial takeovers in favour of the proportionate system. A question that has to arise is: Will that be beneficial to small shareholders, when the Government claims that it will overcome much of the coercive force that could be placed upon small shareholders? Is that valid or have we been carried away by the rhetoric of the debate and been convinced, without a proper and thorough examination, that small shareholders will be beneficially advantaged by this legislation?

On this occasion we have had no exposure draft. In many ways, these exposure drafts have been the compensation offered for the Parliament not being allowed to fill its traditional and constitutional role of full scrutiny. What has been offered in lieu of the public exposure draft is the opportunity for the public-by `public' I do not mean only individuals, but obviously all of the professional bodies and those with a direct interest-to scrutinise the Bill, provide advice and recommendations and then be given the assurance that those recommendations would be considered by the Ministerial Council before the Bill is brought to the Parliament.

As the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) will recall, on previous occasions, in answer to our frustrations, he has been able to say: `But, of course, there has been a long public exposure, and expressions of concern have been taken into account in a redraft of the Bill'. On this occasion there has been no such exposure, which I think is a bad trend in what is already a flawed system in Australia. It means that there will possibly be a greater reason for us to query and scrutinise the primary validity of this attempt to assist small shareholders.

There is no doubt that this is not a one-sided debate. In recent times, academic and business writers have been expressing concern that these provisions do not achieve their objective. I refer to the recent contribution of Professor John Coffee of the Columbia University Law School which appeared in the Company and Securities Law Journal and also to the very worthwhile contribution of Mr S. Hannes of the Macquarie Bank Ltd which appeared in the August edition of the Company and Securities Law Journal, both questioning the basic validity of the argument that is put to justify this change in the partial takeover law in Australia. What is happening with this law is that what is possibly the most highly regulated system in the world is becoming further regulated. That may be necessary, but it requires a very careful cost-benefit analysis. What is quite clear from these writers and I think from all others except the Government, which has not acknowledged it, is that what will be achieved by this legislation is to make partial takeovers more difficult.

If the Government's goal is to retard takeovers in this country I would have preferred it to come clean and to say that that is the goal, rather than attempting to justify it under the guise of provisions that in some way will basically assist the small shareholders of this country. It is interesting that, in a telex that the Opposition received only in the last few days from the Australian Associated Stock Exchanges, it has been prepared to come clean. It refers to the Bill as a Bill which is aimed at making it more difficult for an offerer to succeed with a partial takeover offer. It acknowledges the real purpose of the Bill and I think it would have been of benefit to this Parliament and to the Australian people if the Government had done so. What we have is a mechanism which increases the costs of takeovers, which therefore makes them more unlikely. There are many and varied views as to whether the provisions will achieve what this Government states are its objectives; that is, to provide greater safeguards and equity for small shareholders.

Finally, I said that I would mention a few of the particular provisions that cause us concern-one of which I think we would be of a mind to amend but for the fact that we know the Australian Democrats are convinced that they do not have the power to support amendments in this Bill and we know that we would not receive Government support. That area is the one concerning the shark repellant provisions of articles. Mr Acting Deputy President, as you no doubt will be aware, the North Broken Hill company has just amended its articles of association to allow such a provision, so it obviously will become reasonably common place in the future. The amendment, which is basically a defence mechanism against takeovers, requires a plebiscite to acquire a 51 per cent approval from shareholders before a partial bid can go ahead.

I think I might have mentioned earlier that this Bill originally came from a paper produced by the Companies and Securities Law Review Committee which was put down in March this year. That Committee advised against including the power of the companies to amend their articles in this way. I think it calls for the Government to explain why the Ministerial Council has gone against that advice. It is interesting that the reasons that were given by the Committee in opposition to amendments of the articles in such a way have been taken up by writers such as Mr Hannes from the Macquarie Bank Ltd, whom I mentioned a few moments ago and who adopts those reasons and expresses grave concerns as to whether these provisions will be in the best interests of the community. They have been taken up by the Australian Associated Stock Exchanges and, as the Minister would know, their representative, Mr Bain, has been in the parliamentary building today expressing the grave concern of his exchanges as to whether these provisions are in the best interests of the takeover code within this country. He gave three reasons for this in his telex, to which I have just referred: He said:
This plebiscite provision will be counter productive because it will confuse shareholders, particularly private shareholders, who will be unsure when the offer is current and when it is not.
He said further:

Professional investors will often vote for the offer to be made even though they have no present intention of accepting it. They would do this because it keeps their options open and while there is a partial offer on the table there is a better chance of a white knight or counter bidder emerging. Thus the intention of the provision will be negated . . .
When putting this particular provision in balance with the other provisions of this amending Bill he said:
It is unnecessary to introduce a provision which effectively enables the majority to deny the minority the right to dispose of its property as it sees fit.

What that amounts to is a restriction on individual shareholders, whether they be small or not, to transfer their shares. Rather, the majority of shareholders will be able to determine, through a plebiscite, whether or not they are entitled to do so, which is a major restriction on the transferability of shares in this country. It seems to the Opposition that there is considerable merit on this occasion in the arguments that have been put up by the stock exchanges and in the arguments that have been put up by the Companies and Securities Law Review Committee to which I have just referred--

talk.start.para: â€”The National Companies and Securities Commission; is that what you are talking about?

â€”No, I am talking about the Committee. I thank the honourable senator for her help, but I am talking about something different. We think there is considerable merit in those arguments and, as I have indicated, we would be of a mind to amend this Bill if we were able to do so. We suggested to the representatives of the exchanges that the best course open in such circumstances was to take their plea to the Government because, of course, it is within the Government's hands to return the Bill to the Ministerial Council for further consideration. I understand that the Minister and the Government have refused to do that but we, from the Opposition, in a last ditch effort, urge that course upon the Government again tonight.
â€”Which course?

â€”I am sorry that the Minister was not listening. I see that his advisers have picked it up. I am pleased that at least they have been listening. We urge that, in relation to the shark repellant provisions, the Minister take them back to the Ministerial Council.
â€”That is not a bad idea, actually, but it is not a course I am going to follow.

â€”I am pleased that the Minister acknowledges that it is not a bad idea. We urge that course upon the Minister tonight. If the Minister does that, at least this flawed system of company law which we have in this country will have an opportunity in practice to work just that little bit better.

speech.para: In summary, as I said before, the Opposition does not oppose the Bill. We support the goals which are claimed in it-that is, that the smaller shareholders be treated more equitably. We express doubts as to whether those benefits will occur in practice. We express considerable doubts as to the cost-benefit of this Bill-whether the costs will outweigh the doubtful benefits which I have mentioned. As I said before, we would have preferred the Government to come to the Senate with the real objectives of its Bill, which is to retard takeovers rather than the spurious objectives that are claimed of it. We express grave reservations about the inclusion of the shark repellant provisions and we again register our irritation at the Parliament being used as a rubber stamp.

speech.speaker: Haines Sen J.

talk.start.para: â€”Like the Futures Industry Bill, which has not yet come before the Senate, the Companies and Securities Legislation Amendment Bill before us tonight, as Senator Hill has already mentioned, emanated from the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities and is introduced as part of the Commonwealth's obligations under the co-operative companies and securities scheme. Because of that it has all of the problems that Senator Hill outlined. Its passage by this Parliament has the effect of automatically amending the corresponding State companies and securities legislation and this, as Senator Hill indicated, makes life rather difficult for the two Houses of Federal Parliament that have to vet and presumably pass this legislation since any amendment has to be referred back to the Ministerial Council and has then to be approved by a majority of that Council with all the attendant time delays that occur. If the Government thinks that Senator Hill and I have any criticisms of that with regard to this piece of legislation, I suggest that it wait until the Futures Industry Bill actually comes before the Senate because not only do we have concerns about that and the abrogation of our powers through the role of the Ministerial Council, but the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills probably wrote the longest report on the Futures Industry Bill that it has ever written on any piece of legislation that that Committee has been looking at since its inception.

speech.para: Let me just say by way of preface to the debate on the Futures Industry Bill that the Government's response that self-incrimination clauses and reverse onuses of proof and so on that occur right through the futures industry legislation have occurred in the past under various Bills relating to the NCSC system does not mean that we ought necessarily to sit back and allow them to continue. I think the Government may have to rethink some of its attitude to the sort of legislation that emanates from the Ministerial Council. I am well aware of the fact that the Council was established under the Fraser Government regime and it does seem a little cheeky of Opposition senators now to be complaining about it; nevertheless, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee's concerns on the Futures Industry Bill are, I think, justified and do warrant some attention being paid by this Government to the whole principle of Bills coming from the Ministerial Council being put and passed as they are presented by this Parliament in order that the States can then have similar companies and securities legislation.

Certainly the Australian Democrats will not oppose this attempt by the Government to put some rationality into the laws governing take- overs, although we feel they have not gone far enough. Again, as Senator Hill said, they do attempt to inject some equity amongst shareholders into the whole system of takeovers, but it is marginal at best. The most significant change is the outlawing of that form of partial takeover know as pro rata and that in itself is a much needed reform. I must confess that until earlier this year when Bell Resources Ltd began its enthusiastic attempts to take over Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd I, like a lot of other people including members of this chamber and the other place, did not know the difference between the various sorts of partial takeovers that were around the place and had never heard of a multiplier effect other than in a classroom situation. Because my husband and I hold some insignificant numbers of BHP shares we learned very fast what was going on with regard to those takeover bids that Mr Robert Holmes a Court was making for the Big Australian.

Pro rata partials have given the big institutional shareholders far too much power vis a vis the smaller shareholders in deciding on the success or failure of a takeover bid. Conversely that means that the small shareholder has been disadvantaged with the sort of situation that occurred with the first Bell Resources bid for BHP. I might add at this point that the problem was compounded by the fact that the multiplier effect was applying at that stage so we had a situation where somebody was able to sell to Bell Resources the percentage necessary of his shares, then sell off the rest to somebody else, who could also sell a percentage, and so on, until I gather the smallest fraction of a share was left remaining of the original parcel held by the original person.

Typically pro rata partials have worked to the benefit of institutional shareholders, as I have said, in the following way: A company makes an offer, for example, for 30 per cent of the capital of the target company. The offer runs for a certain length of time, and for the purposes of this exercise let us say that it runs for a month. At first small shareholders do not know what to do. They have their shares and hold those shares for all sorts of reasons. They are not well versed in the ways of takeovers. They may have inherited the shares or they may have simply accumulated them at the suggestion of their sharebroker, and they are certainly not well up in the particular games that are played by major groups in the share market. So they dither around for a while. If they accept they risk losing the opportunity to sell at what could be an even higher price should the raider choose to increase the bid at some later date. In this situation most small shareholders decide to hang on and see what happens closer to the closing date.

With regard to the Bell Resources takeovers of BHP, a number of media advisers-that is people who habitually go on radio and advise small shareholders what they should do-have in fact been recommending that small shareholders hang on to their shares and see what happens. So, they do that; they hang on until closer to the closing date. The institutions which might control something like 50 per cent of the shares on the stock exchange currently generally also do likewise. After all, they are in it for the benefit of the people they represent and they, too, want the best possible price. As the closing date draws near the institutions might decide that no better offer is going to be forthcoming and they accept then for all the shares they are entitled to sell. The small shareholders who have been waiting perhaps for a lead from the institutions then attempt to follow that lead and are likely to be too slow in reacting and are then not able to accept before the closing date. They are, in fact, significantly disadvantaged vis a vis the large institutional shareholders.

The institutions have a very good reason for holding off and acting at the last minute. When a company makes a bid of the sort I just mentioned all the acceptances are counted after the closing date and the offerer buys out the accepters on a pro rata basis; that is, the number of shares is divided into the number of acceptances needed and a ratio is worked out to apply to all accepting shareholders. If the institutions think an offer is good, it is in their interests to prevent as many small shareholders as possible from accepting. This gives them the chance to sell a greater proportion of their shares. By using this sort of brinkmanship they can profit at the expense of small shareholders.

After the passage of this legislation which is, as Senator Hill said earlier and I said a moment ago, assured because of the restraints placed on us in this place due to the legislation emanating from the Ministerial Council, only proportional partial takeovers will be allowed. This was the form which the second Bell Resources offer for BHP took. It ensures that if somebody bids for 30 per cent of a company, each shareholder will be able to sell only 30 per cent of that particular person's shareholdings. This ensures that all shareholders will get an equal opportunity to benefit from the bid. As I said, this is a reform which is long overdue.

Maximum acceptance conditions have also been outlawed by the Bill before us tonight. In other words, an offerer cannot be protected from the effects of making an offer at an unrealistically high price through restricting the acceptance level other than through naming the total percentage of the capital the offerer hopes to acquire. Maximum acceptance conditions can have the effect, of course, of making a proportional bid into a de facto pro rata bid.

Another form of, shall we say, collusion-although it may not be deliberate; effectively it is collusion-between the large institutional shareholders and corporate raiders has been the use of escalation clauses. This means that a bidder can come to the institutions and say effectively: `Look, I am planning on taking over company X. I will give you, say, $5 a share for your holding now. However, I may have to go as high as $6 in order to get all the shares I want'. I guess that is known as showing all the cards that one holds. In effect, he is suggesting to the institutions that an agreement be signed that allows the institutions to benefit from any higher priced offer that the offerer is forced to make at a later date. Of course, this gives the raider a good foot in the door to commence the bid and also gives the institutions the chance essentially to have two bites at the cherry which is being dangled before them. The small shareholder does not get this opportunity. The small shareholder does not know about the opportunity and is not in a position to take advantage of the opportunity. Of course, it is unfair to give the opportunity to the institutions just because they are big, powerful and available in some way to be approached easily, quickly and readily by the raider.

The law has therefore been changed to ensure that substantial shareholders, that is those owning at least 10 per cent of the capital in a company, need only notify changes in their holding if the change involves one per cent or more of the company's shares. Effectively, this will reduce the onerous paperwork requirements on substantial shareholders but will still alert companies to major changes in holdings of their shares. Of course, as a party, we do not support needless paperwork and we are glad to see that this provision will be altered.

However, we believe that the problem of takeovers needs more attention than the Government simply is giving it in this legislation. I suspect that the Government has developed a strategy to keep itself in office which essentially revolves around buying off financial interests. We have seen that in the last couple of months the Government found the money, not withstanding the alleged economic problems faced by this country, to buy off the private banks to the tune of some several hundred million dollars. It succumbed to the banks' blackmail that if some form of deregulation was not introduced for interest rates they would simply dry up the money that was available for housing loans. We saw that too, perhaps to a lesser extent, with the funds that this Government was prepared to make available to the oil companies following the drop in the oil price resulting from the behaviour of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

The Government unquestionably is aiming its attention, its bids-wooing if one likes-at the big financial institutions and the big financial interests in this country. As a consequence there is no doubt that the finance sector has become the glamour sector of the moment. It is the sector that this Government believes it needs in its pocket if it is to be successful, particularly if it is going to be successful at the next election. Might I say in passing that the Government in doing so is tending to ignore those sectors of the population which I would have thought were the traditional concerns of an Australian Labor Party Government. I have said that on a number of occasions in more appropriate places and I do not intend to pursue it at this stage.

With deregulation and the entry of foreign banks the business Press too is focusing its attention on financial matters as it has never done before. Deregulation has become, if one likes, the buzz word of the moment. I presume the Government feels that if it gives financial markets what they want the business Press will consider the Government to be a responsible economic manager. To a very large extent so far it seems to have worked. The business community is fairly satisfied with the manner in which this Government is wooing it. If the business sector has not exactly been lying down and allowing its tummy to be tickled, it has not been biting the hand that feeds it either.

I would have thought that any impression one may have had that the Government was doing a good job economically would have been thrown out of the window over the last month or so. Record balance of payments deficits, the ever climbing foreign debt and alarming falls in the level of productive investment show that the Hawke Government is presiding over an economic disaster largely contributed to, I might add, by private sector borrowings from overseas and by the fact that those people who grizzle that our exports are not keeping up with our imports are the very people who purchase expensive imported motor cars, clothing and so on.

The obsessive belief of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that what is good for the financial sector and good for financial interests is necessarily good for the country is being shown up for the fallacy that it is. There is so much money to be made by financial wheeling and dealing today that the prospect of investing in real assets to create jobs and export income is looking very unattractive indeed. Why take the hard way out when the easy way is being offered to one on a plate by the current Government? A few figures will serve to make my point here. In 1984 $1.9 billion was used to fund takeovers. By 1985 this had jumped to $4.2 billion. Already this year we have seen in excess of $5 billion put into Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd shares in takeover bids, defences and interlocking share deals. At the same time, investment in plant and machinery is at an all time low. Expenditure on fixed capital is lower now than it was in 1981-82.

We believe that this Government, in its cynical effort to stay in power, has sold the country down the drain. We must act now if we are going to act at all to put the brake on takeovers. Instead of encouraging productive investment, currently we are encouraging so-called entrepreneurs to borrow funds from overseas and buy up other companies, often many times their size. They can afford to do this because the ordinary Australian foots the bill through the taxation system. Therefore, the taxpayer must no longer be expected, indeed forced, to fund the activities of the corporate raiders through negative gearing so that these people can borrow billions of dollars overseas, send millions of dollars in interest repayments out of the country, deduct those interest repayments for tax purposes in this country and, in the process, take over, in an essentially non-productive way, another Australian company.

Certainly, the Australian Democrats do not wish to see takeovers banned altogether. That would be stupid. However, we want the present bias in favour of the bidder to be redressed. I suggest that this country can no longer afford to waste its resources in share market paper-chases; essentially that is all they are. We must encourage real investment to create jobs and exports and not encourage profit making through non-productive taxpayer subsidised takeover bids. As I said at the beginning of this speech, the Australian Democrats will not be opposing the legislation partly because we believe it does do something to correct the inequity that currently exists between shareholders caught up in takeover bids and partly, of course, because simply we are not in a position to do anything at all, apparently, to a piece of legislation which emanates from the Ministerial Council under the Fraser Government proposal which attempts to set up similar and co-operative companies and securities legislation.

speech.speaker: Hamer Sen D.J.

talk.start.para: â€”The current takeover code is a mess and we should scrap it as soon as possible and start again. The problem is that the present legislation is too technical and is primarily concerned with procedures rather than equity and fairness. The code is very complex; even our most experienced practitioners often cannot interpret it accurately, and the judges who apply the law have little experience in corporate law and practice. The present regulations and practices have produced a great deal of unfairness, especially to small shareholders. Of particular concern should be the ability of institutions to obtain higher prices for shares than are available to small shareholders, the use of escalator clauses, and the disadvantages caused to small shareholders by pro rata partial offers.

speech.para: We should also look at the results of the present system. Someone who wants to gain control of a company can make a bid, but the current holders of control cannot make a counter bid; they are forbidden to buy their own shares. It is not an equal contest. The contest is loaded in favour of the raider. I should make it clear that I am not against takeovers. Our economic efficiency depends on inefficient management being called to account. We must not produce a system that protects them. The trouble is that our present system is biased the other way, and corporate raiders are making a great deal of money without producing anything. Compared to full bids, partial bids are notoriously difficult to defend against. In Australia, an increased percentage of recent takeovers, now estimated at 40 per cent has been partial bids, a figure which contrasts sharply with the American experience. In 1984 the figure was approximately 20 per cent. One option we should look at is to eliminate the partial bid altogether. We could raise the threshold shareholding to, say, 30 per cent and if a raider wanted to go beyond that he would have to make a bid for all the remaining shares. This would require greater financial backing and would discourage post-acquisition asset stripping.

It might be useful to compare our takeover system with some others. In the United States, partial takeover bids are freely permitted, subject only to the requirement that all shares tendered be pro-rated if the offer is oversubscribed. Thus bidders can and do purchase control through creeping acquisitions in the market, which is unregulated to a large extent. But while the bidder is unregulated, so also is the target, which can engage in aggressive defensive tactics. This may include the sale of assets and the making of discriminatory self-tenders. These defensive methods threaten the bidder with serious losses, especially if the bidders do not acquire most of the target's shares. Thus, the bottom line is that, while the substantive law does not discourage partial bids in the United States, the self-help remedies available to the target do. The situation is much simpler in the United Kingdom. Partial bids are prohibited unless approved by the panel on takeovers and mergers and the target company's shareholders. The law in the majority of Canadian jurisdictions achieves an even more sweeping result by requiring a bidder who privately purchases more than 20 per cent of the target's shares, at a specified premium over the market price, to follow up these purchases by making an offer within 180 days thereafter at an equivalent premium for the remaining shares.

The current Australian system allows partial bids to be made in such a way that shareholders are pressured or intimidated into accepting offers which are inadequate. In reforming the takeover code, this unacceptable practice must be given the most serious consideration. The current system allows an offer to be framed so that acceptances are prorated backed if the offer receives acceptance for more shares than are being sought. Thus, the proportion of a shareholder's holding which is acquired by a bidder, and for which the shareholder receives the bid price, depends on the acceptance of the offer by other shareholders. If all shareholders accept a partial bid, they receive the bid price for only a portion of their respective holdings. Many shareholders would consider this an inadequate return for control of the company. However, some shareholders may seize the opportunity to break ranks and accept the offer, thus receiving the bid price for their entire holding. The current system involves a game of cat and mouse, often resulting in a stream of acceptances in the last days or even hours of an offer. This is particularly evident in a bid which has been relatively unsuccessful.

In short, the present rules may set up an incentive to accept an offer in an attempt to secure a disproportionate share of the prize offered to gain control. Under the current code, shareholders have little option other than to sell when it becomes apparent that control will pass. The current system entrenches the practice that it is in the financial interests of all shareholders to accept the offer even though they are opposed to the transfer of control to the raider. Only in this way can they share in the once-off benefit from the passing of control. All this gives a clear advantage to the professional or institutional investor over the small shareholder who faithfully follows his board's advice to reject the offer. The current rules place the large shareholder in a much stronger position. A potential bidder seeking to acquire a 20 per cent holding before launching a bid will no doubt approach the large or institutional shareholders to purchase their shares. The proposed changes must deal with this problem.

In March 1985, the Companies and Securities Law Review Committee released a paper on the subject of reforming the current system with regard to partial bids. The Committee considered a number of proposals to amend the code in relation to partial bids in order to redress the balance between the offerer and the interests of the target company's shareholders. The Committee recommended three significant reforms. The first was to introduce a special 10 per cent threshold for partial bids. Under such a proposal, a partial bid would not be allowed where the offerer was already entitled to at least 10 per cent of the company's voting shares and a successful partial bid would increase such entitlement to more than 20 per cent. This proposal would introduce greater equality amongst shareholders, large and small. The coercive effect of the partial bid, as the present laws allow, would be diminished as the proposed reform would require the offerer to obtain a greater proportion of the shares by way of formal bid rather than by open market purchases. A 10 per cent holding is also less of an obstacle to a potential counter-bidder than the current 20 per cent threshold. Thus, a more competitive market is encouraged and shareholders are the beneficiaries.

The Committee also recommended restricting a partial bid to a specified proportion of each shareholder's holding. Under such a proposal, a partial bid may be made only for a fixed proportion of each shareholder's holding, thus a proportional bid. It is argued that four advantages would flow from the elimination of pro rata bids. First, it would add certainty to the system. Each shareholder is aware from the beginning of the offer period of the proportion of his shareholding which may be accepted by the offerer. Secondly, the abolition of the pro rata offer would remove the element that supplies the coercive engine in a partial bid. Thirdly, it gives the opportunity to participate in the value of any control premium to all shares. Fourthly, it reinforces the incentive for all shareholders to determine whether the bid price, if paid on only a portion of their holding, represents a fair premium for transfer of control.

The third recommendation of the Committee was the introduction of a mechanism designed to eliminate the uncertainty associated with partial bids. Specifically, the Committee suggested that the maximum offer period for a partial bid should be one month with a consequential prescription of the time within which the consideration for the partial bid should be paid, and this period should not be capable of being extended. The Committee also considered various defence tactics available to target companies to ensure that partial bids succeed only if approved by the target company's shareholders in general meeting. It is, of course, an inherent feature of partial bids that control passes without the need to acquire a majority of the shares. A separate question is whether control should be allowed to pass without the consent of the owners of a majority of shares. Should consensus amongst shareholders be required before there is a change in control?

Such issues must now be addressed-especially since the `shark repellant' proposal has been flagged by the Macquarie Bank and the `poison pill' proposal raised by Lloyds International. I was not responsible for these terms, Madam Acting Deputy President. The `shark repellant' proposal, involving an alteration of the articles of association which would require majority shareholder approval before control could pass, was rejected by the Committee. Similarly, the `poison pill' proposal, involving the issue of shares to ensure an offerer does not secure control unless a majority of shareholders approve the partial bid, was also rejected. The Committee dismissed such defensive tactics, claiming they would be `inconsistent with the principle--

talk.start.para: â€”You have mixed up shark repellants with the poison pills.
â€”Does the Minister want me to repeat it?
â€”You just gave us a second run on the shark repellant rather than explaining what a poison pill was.

â€”No, I explained them both. I think the Minister had better look at Hansard tomorrow for elucidation. As I was saying, the Committee dismissed both such defensive tactics, claiming they would be `inconsistent with the principle that a share in a public company should be transferable without the consent of other shareholders'. The Committee also questioned whether shareholder ratification would be a `valid means of expression of informed shareholders' will'. In introducing this Bill, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), I regret to say, revealed a disturbing lack of knowledge. This point was highlighted by Terry McCrann in the Age on 2 May 1986 and it is worth quoting. Mr McCrann wrote:

speech.para: In debate on legislation to amend the Takeover Code, Mr Bowen came out with a series of quite staggering statements-staggering in their suggestion of an almost total lack of understanding of the very legislation under discussion, and the amendments he was introducing.

When such-what may be described as-a gaping black hole of knowledge is revealed in the first law Minister in the land, and the person who one way or another sits at the very top of the pyramid of legislation and regulation of business and commercial activity in this country, it can be little other than deeply disturbing.

So much for Mr McCrann. Nevertheless, Mr Bowen's and the Government's proposals for reforming the code are with us. This Bill proposes eight major changes: First, all partial bids are to be restricted to a proportion of each shareholder's holding. In other words, the pro-rata bid is to be done away with. Secondly, for both full and partial offers, maximum acceptance conditions are to be prohibited. Thirdly, benefits under escalation agreements entered into within six months of the bid, whether full or partial, are to be cancelled. Fourthly, all Part A bids, full or partial, are to be subject to a minimum price, being the highest price paid for shares in the target company by the offerer within the previous four months. Fifthly, the so-called multiplier effect is to be eliminated from partial bids. Sixthly, `shark repellant' provisions may be put into the articles of listed companies which would subject takeover bids to a plebiscite of a target company's shareholders. Seventhly, shares held by a nominee or trustee on behalf of different persons are deemed to be subject to separate offers for each share holding. Finally, the substantial shareholder provisions of the Companies Act are to be amended so that shareholders holding over 10 per cent will be required to notify net variations of only 1 per cent or more in their holdings.

Although the Opposition does not oppose the Government's reforms, I have a number of criticisms to air. There does not seem to be any attempt to analyse the economic effects of the Bill on takeovers. The Takeover Code has an important impact on the level of foreign investment in Australia and on the attitude of foreign investors towards Australia. It would seem that the major thrust of the Government's reforms is to ban pro rata partial bids. It must therefore be asked: Is this consistent with the Government's current foreign investment policies? The Government has not clearly explained its position in this area. Indeed, proportional bidding will make foreign acquisition harder so the Government is in effect encouraging foreign companies to make full bids and then subsequently to `Australianise'. The obvious result is that some foreign investors will be deterred from investing in Australian companies. Is this what the Government wants? Again, the Government's position is unclear and I would like to hear a clear explanation of its intentions.

The introduction of plebiscite provisions also raises a number of important issues. These provisions are designed to give the ordinary shareholder a say in whether or not his company should be taken over. Has the Government considered that such a provision may simply be used by entrenched minorities to protect their position and to prevent fellow shareholders selling at a fair price? Does the Government intend that one's ability and right to deal with one's shares will be dependent on a vote of one's fellow shareholders? Under the Government's reforms, the offerer and the person associated with the offerer are prohibited from voting on a plebiscite resolution and the approval required is the proportion specified but not exceeding one-half. The offerer is to be given notice of the result 14 days prior to the end of the offer period and 10 per cent of shareholders can ask for a review by a court of the plebiscite provisions. In introducing such reforms, the Government must give clear answers to a number of questions. What will be the effect on the level of takeover activity in Australia? Accepting that the level of takeovers at the moment is too high, has the Government established what a proper level of takeovers should be? Has the Government considered that the reforms will probably deter desirable foreign investment?

With all this in mind, we at least now have some reforms to counter the current unsatisfactory situation. Australians are truly sick and tired of the non-productivity of the takeover bid at today's level which gives corporate raiders enormous profits-but the economy and Australia benefit little. We must also look at whether the present cumbersome structure of legislation by a committee of Federal and State Attorneys-General, advised by the Companies and Securities Law Review Committee, is capable of dealing with such a complicated and rapidly changing problem. As was pointed out by Senator Hill, the problem of a committee is that no-one is responsible. The question of the responsibility to this Parliament and the inability of this Parliament to amend legislation in desirable ways, is very serious.

The Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs is looking at the loss of power by the Federal Parliament which the present system requires. When we have its report, we must look again at the whole way in which the takeover code is amended and policed. I have no desire to place restraints on the free market or on our free enterprise system. But the passion for takeover after takeover must be restrained, because what we need in Australia is productivity.

Finally, we must turn our attention to the present struggle for Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd in the context of this debate. Some would argue that to oppose, debate or even introduce amendments to the code creates uncertainty in the market. But debate over legislation does not create uncertainty. This is created by natural forces within the market. We must not become transfixed by the struggle for BHP. We must decide these matters on merit and not be diverted by the immediate drama. Those who argue that debate and proposed reforms cause uncertainty are usually direct participants in current market events and are motivated by old-fashioned self-interest. In our deliberations, we must not be influenced by black knights, white knights or other superficial considerations. Reform is obviously necessary. We must ensure that the proposals will be a stimulus to productivity and a more efficient corporate sector. It is time for this Government and this Parliament to show leadership.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: â€”It is a bit late at night to be showing leadership of any kind, but I think it is appropriate to respond quickly to some of the issues that have been raised during the second reading debate. I should say at the outset, in response to Senator Hill, that it is not true that the Bill arose out of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd fracas. It arose out of the Companies and Securities Law Review Committee report which had been set in train well before anything had happened in relation to BHP.

speech.para: A discussion paper was released by the CSLRC and the issues involved in this issue were exhaustively debated at seminars and other occasions of that kind. Certainly, it has to be acknowledged that most of the issues in this Bill are well known and have been amply considered. I can understand the criticism that this Bill, I think uniquely of this series of company law amendments, has come forward without a full scale exposure period. There was, however, a universally perceived need to get the Bill in place quickly once the policy decision had been made to outlaw partial pro ratas so that we did not have a flood of pre-emptive pro rata bids trying to beat that particular legislative deadline. That was the consideration that motivated the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities. Given the familiar character of most of the issues involved, I think it was a defensible decision.

During the course of the debate the usual whinges were expressed about the Senate's defacto inability to amend legislation of this kind, coming forward as it does from the Ministerial Council, with the full scale imprimatur of the States and with all sorts of consequences flowing from the amendment of the passage so agreed. I acknowledge the force of those arguments. I have been obliged to do so on a number of occasions in government, but the solutions, of course, are in our hands, as they were for the Fraser Government which introduced this abomination of a co-operative scheme in 1978; that is, to grasp the nettle of Commonwealth legislation and reliance upon the corporations power and whatever else we can find, and have a properly run--

talk.start.para: â€”Introduce it with your national land rights legislation.

â€”At least there are no compensation payouts to be contemplated in this context, unlike some others of a more delicate kind. I simply repeat that I have always been a vigorous proponent of unilateral Commonwealth legislation in this area. I notice an increasing disposition on the part of the federalist forces opposite to acknowledge the utility of a legislative scheme of that kind.
â€”That is not unanimous.
â€”It may not be unanimous. I hear a bellow from the outer darkness from Senator Crichton-Browne--
â€”The forces of righteousness.

â€”The forces of righteousness still have to overcome a degree of prejudice on this matter, as will others, and make themselves come to appreciate what is for once in the national interest. But that is a debate for another day. I think the issues have been well exposed by Senator Haines and Senator Hill.

speech.para: Turning to the substantive provisions of this legislation, Senator Hill asked whether the Bill would really overcome coercion of small shareholders or whether it was mere rhetoric. I believe, as does the Government, that the Bill is based on a carefully considered set of recommendations by the CSLRC, that it does have broad business support across the spectrum and that the particular package of measures that it deals with will have a useful and perhaps salutary effect in giving some considerable measure of protection to minority shareholders. If one were to adopt the robust view of Senator Hamer that the whole takeover code is too technical and it ought to be scrapped entirely or, I think he said as a sort of lesser option in a slightly less robust mood as his speech wore on, that partial bids raised difficult problems and maybe they should be eliminated altogether. If not scrapped, the takeover code could at least be simplified by cutting a swathe through some of these provisions. I simply make the point that if this were done, big companies would become virtually impregnable to takeover.

Often the partial bid is the only thing that can be afforded. I suppose BHP is the best extant example of that. The sum of money involved in a full takeover bid is almost beyond grasp, even it would appear to Mr Holmes a Court, although one can never make assumptions of that kind these days. But clearly it is important in the interests of the efficient functioning of Australian capitalism-to which, of course, the socialist Hawke Government is strongly committed-that we do not have entrenched, inefficient managements. The bleatings of managements-entrenched, inefficient and otherwise-about some aspects of this takeover legislation have been wondrous to behold and certainly not a very edifying spectacle for those of us who want to see a robust, competitive environment in fact as well as name.

Coming to the specifics of the substantive provisions, it would appear from the debate here and elsewhere that there is general support for the outlawing of pro rata partial bids in favour of proportional bids, in favour of the abolition of the multiplier and removal of maximum acceptance conditions, and the outlawing of escalation agreements. People might have reservations and concerns about this or that aspect of those provisions, but, by and large, they seem to have general assent. Where there is much less of a measure of agreement is in relation to the so-called shark repellant provisions, enabling a shareholder plebiscite to be written into the articles of association on a 75 per cent majority vote of those present and voting-it being acknowledged that those present and voting, even taking into account proxies and so on, might represent a rather small proportion of the total shareholding of the company. I suspect that is probably the case with Mr Bethwaite's rather deft defensive manoeuvres with North Broken Hill Holdings Ltd recently.

There is a concern that provisions of this kind, notwithstanding the hurdles that technically have to be jumped, might be relatively easy to include. They could be used once again to entrench inefficient and weak managements from the chills of a takeover raid.

I understand those arguments. They have been strongly put by the stock exchange, not just in the context of this legislation, but over a longer period. There are, of course, counter arguments to the effect that one is, after all, talking about a majority of shareholders taking the decision, and taking it in the knowledge that such a provision may have some depressing effect on the price of the shares in a takeover environment. Arguments can also be made that all that such a plebiscite provision does is give shareholders a further option to consider the desirability of a bid separately from the question of their participation in it, their actual purchase of the shares in question.

I thought the arguments were finely balanced. It is probably desirable that this matter be reconsidered after the passage of this legislation. It is simply wildly impractical, as we all know and as, I think, Senator Hill will acknowledge, for this legislative package to, in effect, be shelved or deferred. There cannot even be-the way that the legislation is now written-a proclamation of these provisions in a selective way. It is really a matter of accepting or rejecting the whole package. The atmosphere in the financial market-place is such that it is important, I believe, to put to bed any uncertainty that might exist about pro rata partials being outlawed. It is important that the air be cleared and the ground rules that have been expected to be put in place be put in place, but that will still allow an opportunity for this matter to be reconsidered. I indicate that the Government will accommodate the raising of this matter with the Ministerial Council in the future in order, perhaps, for a more extended consideration of the pros and cons of this so-called shark repellant clause to be made. With those remarks, I commend the Bill to the Senate and hope that we can have a speedy Committee stage of this Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

debate.title:
CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL 1986
[COGNATE BILL:
BOUNTY AND SUBSIDY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986]

proctext.para: Debate resumed from 8 May, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: â€”I wish to confirm whether the Government intends to have a cognate debate on the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1986 and the Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill 1986.
â€”Yes.

â€”These Bills contain a whole series of detailed adjustments to the industry assistance measures which are in place and, as such, represent the most characteristic opportunity this chamber gets to debate industry policy. In a sense, that is a pity because the debate tends to focus on the immediate assistance or adjustments to the assistance being proffered in the legislation. Perhaps there is inadequate emphasis in this chamber and in the House of Representatives on the broader issues which go to the health of manufacturing industry in this country. That matter is of very considerable importance because it seems now to be the common wisdom that we have a very serious problem in the manufacturing industry in Australia. This is an important part of the wider economic problems we face and has led to the very erratic behaviour on the part of the Government over recent weeks: The suggestion that we are approaching banana republic stage; the suggestion that we are about to have the most important economic meeting of a summit-type since the National Economic Summit Conference; the obvious disputation between the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke); and the situation where the Prime Minister is now endeavouring-with more or less success we are yet to know-to put his stamp on leading the Government out of the economic morass into which it has led this country.

speech.para: Manufacturing industry is getting increasing prominence because, as the Government is prone to bleat whenever the economic issues are raised in this chamber or in the House of Representatives, the country has seen a decline in the terms of trade and that means our traditional reliance on mining and primary production looks to be more perilous today than it has been in the past. It is a matter of relatively recent history that we were worrying about the Gregory thesis. We were deeply concerned that our major problem was an overvalued dollar caused by the massive excess of exports over imports. It is a nice reminder of how much fallacy there is in economic predictions that the besetting worry just a few years ago, in particular in the period around 1979 and 1980-that we had a problem of an excess of exports-has faded from everybody's memory.

Now the perceived problem is with respect to imports, which will not go away. Our exports cannot pay the import bill, the invisible bill, with which we are now inflicted and there are no obvious ways for reducing our import bill other than by the use of a government-induced recession. All this is very serious stuff because it goes to the standard of living of all Australians and to our capacity to meet many of our national ambitions. I know of no economists who are predicting a significant turnaround in our balance of payments situation, and that may be the greatest cause for optimism that we have. I do not have much sense of optimism when I look at the Government and its apparent incapacity to come to grips with some of the significant basic problems we face, but I am reminded that economic circumstances change and if all economists are predicting the same thing, it is almost certain that the opposite will occur. I can only hope for Australia's sake that we see some easing of the non-domestically inflicted problems that we face.

It is no good sitting around waiting for something to turn up. Now that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has turned up, we can get on with the debate. The fact of the matter is that, on all the indicators we have at present, Australia has no choice but to look to some restoration of health for its manufacturing industry. If we are to do something about the balance of payments, which is such a significant problem for us now, it is undoubtedly true that the perceived wisdom now is that we have a very great national interest in seeing a better circumstance for our manufacturing industry.

In debating the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill and the Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill I want to make the point that the sorts of provisions contained in this legislation are not the major part of any solution to the problem. The major part of any solution to the problem is in providing a general environment for manufacturing in Australia which will give investors confidence that there is a long term future for manufacturing in this country and that new money invested in manufacturing today will show a return which is in some way competitive with the returns which can be obtained by investing in government bonds or in some other apparently safe or completely safe form of investment.

It was interesting that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce in Question Time over the past two days, in response to questions about what has impacted upon investment in Australia, suggested that interest rates were the primary cause of the recent decline of investment and listed as his second point the uncertainty about the Australian dollar. Today in Question Time he conceded or agreed that wages were also a significant factor in his equation. It is important that the debate on the future of the manufacturing industry in Australia should be centred not so much on what tariffs we impose to protect Australian manufacturers or what bounties or subsidies we provide in lieu, but rather on the provision of a genuinely competitive environment for Australian industry.

talk.start.para: â€”Hear, hear!

â€”The Minister acknowledges that quite frequently in the speeches he makes, usually more bluntly in the speeches he makes outside the Parliament than the speeches he makes within the Parliament. That acknowledgement is yet to be reflected in any substantial attempts by the Government to come to grips with the problem the Minister diagnoses. The major criticism the Opposition would make of the approach of the Government and the Minister to industry policy is that to some extent it is conducted in an environment which is not particularly favourable to the outcomes the Minister seeks. It is one thing to pursue the general policy of forcing Australian industry to face up to external competition-that is an objective with which the Opposition agrees and on which it has consistently supported the Government when it has introduced measures which have that end in view-but the real difficulty for those who are asked to respond to this new, more competitive environment is that there are so many elements of the Government's policies which diminish the capacity of industry to respond. I refer to the taxation system as one very obvious area of complaint, not least of which is the legislation which has been through the Senate in the past few days of sittings, almost all of which, with the exception of the research and development legislation, has involved additional taxation imposts on industry, including manufacturing industry. Since we are due to adjourn, I will leave my specific comments on the Bills until tomorrow morning.

speech.para: Debate interrupted.

debate.sub1.title: Gold Mining Industry-Stroke Victims-Government Expenditure-United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation-Women

interject.speaker: The PRESIDENT

talk.start.para: â€”Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

interject.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

speech.speaker: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

talk.start.para: â€”Earlier in the day I had an opportunity to speak for just a few moments; now that I have a greater opportunity I will take advantage of it. Earlier I spoke of the merits of retaining the exemption on the tax on gold. The volatility of gold prices is certainly a factor which has a greater impact on the gold mining industry than on any other mining industry. The maximum price paid at the Perth Mint for an ounce of gold in 1980 was $752.50. Two years later, in 1982, the minimum price for an ounce of gold had dropped to $291.85. This variability deters both investors and lenders because of the higher risk which it entails. There is very little that the industry can do to insulate itself. Gold producers are price takers and have no control over the price they receive for their product. This means that gold mining companies have no constant stream of revenue upon which they can depend. It also means that they have no ability to pass on any rise in costs.

speech.para: Again, by way of comparison, coal contracts have a base price fixed per tonne with provision for adjustments to be made to this price according to changes in other factors. These other factors may vary between contracts but they might, for example, include a term which allows a price increase, for example, whenever a national wage case grants a wage rise and so on. Gold has no such guarantee of profitability. Facing a price for gold over which they have no control, gold producers must absorb any cost increase by taking it out of profits. This increased risk requires premium returns for people who invest in the industry. Any tax which is imposed on the industry will be like any other costs. It will not be able to be passed on in the price of gold. The traders in Hong Kong, London and New York certainly have no sympathy for the Australian gold mining industry. Any tax will have to be absorbed out of the profits which gold miners and prospectors make.

I would like to examine the wastage which may result if a tax is imposed on gold. I have already mentioned how present gold mining companies may be forced to mine only high grade ore in an effort to meet their debt commitments. The imposition of a tax will have an even more marked effect on future mines. Looking at the combined factors of the risk involved in the industry, the inability to pass on cost increases and the difficulties of financing gold mining operations, it becomes obvious that if a tax is introduced on the industry and profits are reduced from what they would be without a tax, exploration will begin to target only on high grade ore bodies. Not only would this be an enormous waste of gold which would otherwise be mined, but also as high grade ore bodies become more and more scarce, so the opportunities for the industry contract. Even now, gold mining is operating on ore qualities which are far less than they were last year.

The New Celebration Mine owned by Newmont Holdings at Kalgoorlie operates on an ore grade of only 2.8 grams to the tonne. This project would expect to produce 1,400,000 grams of gold each year which, at a price of $15.90 per gram, would produce $22,260,000 in revenue. This project will employ some 60 people and represents an investment in the range of $10m. This project is going ahead despite its low grade. It may well be that it would never have started had there been a tax on gold and were the profits it could achieve half what they are at present. There are many other gold mining operations which are proceeding under the present tax concession to the industry which may not proceed at all if a tax is imposed. Many operations are working on grades of ore which are extremely poor. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table giving the average grades of ore in the majority of mines in Western Australia.
