talk.start.para: â€”I emphasise the point once again. With the disadvantages which gold mining companies face and the low grades of ore which are typical of gold mining today, if a tax is imposed there will not be enough return left in many low grade ore bodies for investment to be worthwhile.

speech.para: There is another aspect to the present gold mining industry which relates directly to the fact that Australia exempts gold mining from tax. There is a significant amount of overseas investment in the gold mining industry in Australia rather than in some other country which has gold deposits, simply because Australia does not tax its gold mining industry. In the United States, for example, company tax rates for gold mining are 15 per cent for up to $25,000 and 46 per cent for between $100,000 and $1m. That gives an idea of the levels of taxation that are being levied on gold mining activities in America and the incentive that gold mining companies have to come to Australia. The incentive for investors to choose a country where there is no taxation on gold mining is obvious. The extent of the impact of foreign investment in gold mining in Australia should not be underestimated. In a publication entitled `Foreign Ownership and Control of the Australian Mining Industry' the Australian Bureau of Statistics indicated that in 1982-83, 41.1 per cent of the people employed in the gold mining industry and 41.8 per cent of the wages paid by the industry were attributable to foreign capital. Thus there is a significant amount of the industry which owes its existence to foreign investment. The tax concession gives Australia a certain attractiveness which does not occur in other countries where tax is imposed. If this concession were removed it would put a significant proportion of the industry at risk.

Although there is a high proportion of foreign equity in the industry it does not mean that Australia is giving a tax concession to a large number of foreign controlled companies. Despite high levels of foreign investment, rarely does this amount to foreign control. The same publication to which I referred earlier indicated that of the 92 gold mining sites in Australia in 1982-83, only two were actually controlled by overseas interests. If we can attempt to look to the future it is possible to predict that Australia could miss out on significant investment in the gold mining industry from South African interests. There is no need to attempt to explain the turmoil which is presently occurring in South Africa. This unrest is causing many South African people and a great amount of South African capital to flee that country. Much of this money is coming into Australia and as disturbances in South Africa worsen, I believe that this will continue, if not increase. This is because Australia provides a politically stable environment with a well developed infrastructure. In addition it is almost certain that these companies are assessing the tax implications associated with alternative gold producing countries.

Typical of this move is that being made by the American company Amax. In the Sydney Morning Herald of 17 February this year it was reported that the company was considering spending 30 per cent of its exploration budget in Australia. The Managing Director of Amax, Mr Born, when commenting about South Africa, said:
My problem is trying to find deposits outside a country which I do not want to be in. I do not want to invest in Africa.

Another aspect of foreign equity in the Australian gold mining industry is the question of repatriation of profits. If profits are not taxed in Australia there is a strong incentive to retain them here rather than return them to the home country where they will be taxed. Retained profits are frequently reinvested in the industry. If a tax is introduced for gold mining there will not be the same incentive to retain the profits in Australia.

What is the end result of these features of the gold mining industry? It is that the introduction of a tax will have an effect way above and beyond that which occurs when any normal industry is taxed. The impact of a tax on gold will be particularly vicious. It will stop industry which otherwise has a great future.

It is the net effect of all the factors which I have mentioned which brings me to the final reason why it makes no economic sense to tax the gold mining industry. When an industry is going to be devastated in the way the gold mining industry will be if a tax is introduced, it is necessary to look at the net amount the Government would expect to make by taxing that industry. The Treasury estimates that a tax on the mining of gold will earn the Government initially $90m and ultimately $100m per year.

talk.start.para: â€”We wouldn't do that.

â€”No, we certainly would not. We would not have a tax on gold. What is more, if there were a tax I am quite sure we would repeal it. From the Treasury estimate figure must be deducted the extra amounts the Government would have to pay in unemployment benefit and the amount of income tax revenue which the Government will lose when the industry grinds to a halt. The Australian Gold Mining Industry Council estimates that another 8,000 people could be employed in the Australian economy if the tax free status of gold were maintained. Those people would be employed directly in gold mining itself and in all the industries which depend for their incomes on the gold mining industry. These include the farmers who provide the food to the towns, the builders who build the houses and the transport operators who carry the goods to the gold mining towns, and so on. If the tax free status is not maintained this employment will be jeopardised. It is predicted that exploration will decline by 50 per cent on 1985 levels and production ultimately is expected to decline by 20 per cent per annum. When the growth in the industry is replaced with decline, the chance that the predicted increase in employment will actually materialise must be subject to considerable doubt.

speech.para: The Treasury itself must be taken to have cast some doubt on future growth in the gold mining industry after a gold tax is imposed. In the White Paper on the Reform of the Australian Taxation System, the Treasury indicated that it expected that the revenue which would be raised from a tax on gold would be $90m in the second year of taxation and then $100m for each of the third, fourth and fifth years of taxation. If the Treasury expected that the gold mining industry would maintain the spectacular growth of recent years, one might have expected it to predict a rising stream of $100m. Perhaps even the Treasury is pessimistic about the future of the industry after a tax has been imposed.

If growth in the industry is stopped we must look at what the Government will actually raise by imposing a tax on gold. In so doing, I wish to dispel the notion that the gold mining industry contributes nothing to tax revenues. The gold mining industry, by employing many people, using many goods and services resulting in the building of many buildings, contributes to income tax revenues, sales tax revenues and local council revenues. If growth is stopped and the 8,000 people which the Australian Gold Mining Industry Council expects to be employed in gold mining and associated support industries are not employed, significant tax revenue will be lost.

A person on average weekly earnings is already paying around $96 per week in income tax. Allowing for some tax deductions and sales taxes it is reasonable to assume that a person on average weekly earnings is paying $100 per week in various forms of taxes. Thus, if growth in the industry is stopped, and the predicted 8,000 people who would otherwise have been employed are not employed, that will represent a loss in tax revenue, in my view at least-in my modest calculations-of $41,600,000, if each of the 8,000 people were on average weekly earnings. If we assume that on average those people are married with one child, the Commonwealth will be liable to pay $186.30 per week in unemployment benefit. Over a year, for those 8,000 people, this involves an expenditure of $77m. I am not assuming that those 8,000 people will become automatically unemployed. On the present level of unemployment-it was 7.9 per cent in the April quarter-one cannot be optimistic that there will not be dislocation and that in due course those people will find themselves unemployed.

talk.start.para: â€”No one will read this.

â€”I say to Senator Gareth Evans that it becomes apparent that the Commonwealth would actually lose by imposing such a tax. It is possible that the imposition of any tax will so kill incentive that it will result in less revenue being raised. If income taxes were raised to 95 per cent, for instance, probably so few people would bother to work that less revenue would be raised.

speech.para: Just where this borderline is varies with each industry. For the reasons which I have stated, I believe that in the case of gold mining the point is very low. There are aspects of the gold mining industry which make it particularly sensitive to taxation. I have attempted to express some of these aspects. The Government should consider this fact and reject any proposal to introduce a tax on the gold mining industry. If the Government does this the industry will continue to grow in the fashion in which it has grown over the last several years. If it does not it may well be responsible for bringing stagnation and decline to one of Australia's most vibrant and exciting industries.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: â€”Tonight I want to refer briefly to a matter that I raised first on the adjournment on 5 December last relating to strokes and the death rate in Australia as a result of strokes, the third highest killer in Australia after heart attacks and cancer. I point out that if Australia could reduce its incidence of stroke per thousand head of population to the level that exists in America-that is, reduce it from 2.02 per thousand to 1.4 per thousand-it would not only of course save many thousands of lives but also save the Government something like $500m a year in the costs of caring for the survivors of stroke, because something like one-third of people who suffer a stroke do survive and need care of various kinds. Many are hospitalised and many end up with residual handicaps requiring some degree of care, while of course many have to spend time in some other kind of institution. At the moment there are something like 180,000 stroke victims in Australia.

speech.para: I rise tonight to commend the Government, because, since I spoke on this matter last December, the Government has now made permanent the once-off funding of about $70,000 it provided last year to the Brain Foundation of Australia, which is concerned with this matter. Instead of that being a once-off grant, the Government has now provided $70,000 per annum, indexed for five years. To a large extent this is being spent in Queensland on a program which involves testing of blood pressure as a preventive medicine prospect. I am glad that my cousin, Senator Peter Baume, who is a physician with some knowledge in this matter, is here. This program, which is a trial program in Queensland, involves blood pressure testing at the work place.

I commend the Government for supporting the Brain Foundation in this first rate operation. However, the Government having taken this initial step, may I encourage it to add strokes to the nine priorities that the Government presently has in respect of funding for national health and medical research. I understand that at present it gives a priority to the following nine items: Addictive behaviour, obviously relating to drugs, aging, alcohol abuse, rehabilitation medicine, Aboriginal health, environmental toxicology-which I presume means pollution of one kind or another, but environmental toxicology sounds like good bureaucratese for it-health evaluation, public health, and acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

Obviously those nine items are matters of great significance, but I suggest that, apart from the humanitarian problems involved in the incidence of strokes, in view of the enormous cost of strokes to the community-as I said, it is the third largest cause of death in Australia, after heart attack and cancer-there is some enormous merit in including research into strokes on the list. At the moment it is included to the extent only of the aging item, but in fact something like a quarter of stroke victims are under 65 years of age, so it is not necessarily appropriate to include strokes in the aging category and to depend on that for adequate funding of strokes.

I now want very briefly to refer to a matter that was raised in the Senate today by Senator Walsh. He claimed that about half the examples of waste that the Waste Watch Committee had pointed out related to matters under the previous Government's jurisdiction. I simply say that Senator Walsh is hoping that, like Goebbels, by repeating a lie long enough and often enough it will become accepted as being the truth. No matter how often Senator Walsh repeats this nonsense it is simply not true. Not one of the grants under the enormous range of programs that the Waste Watch Committee has pointed out was ever made by the Fraser Government.

If Senator Walsh is saying that some of the programs under which these grants were made by the Labor Government were introduced by the Fraser Government he is right. But, of course, he is just as right as anyone who would say that it is a disgrace that the Curtin Government introduced a taxation system which took away the rights of the States to impose income tax and that our present taxation ills and the absurd rates being charged at the moment are all the fault of the Curtin Government. Now that is absolute arrant nonsense just as, of course, it is nonsense for a coalition government to be either credited with or blamed for all the present social security arrangements even though coalition governments introduced the great bulk-in fact almost all the social security benefits-that presently exist. It is deceptive nonsense for anyone to assume from the fact that a program was introduced by someone that everything that then happens under that program is the responsibility of that government.

I repeat: Not one of these absurd wasteful grants which embarrassed the Minister for Finance because he was not sufficiently competent to prevent them being made was made by the Fraser Government. In fact, the first of the grants to which we drew attention was not made until the second half of 1983-something like four or five months after the Fraser Government was defeated. The great bulk of the grants to which we have drawn attention took place well over a year after the defeat of the Fraser Government; this applies even on those programs which had been introduced by the Fraser Government. I simply say that I am overjoyed to see that Senator Walsh is so determined to go to even these extraordinary lengths, these deceptive lengths, to try to diminish the impact of the Waste Watch Committee because it shows how we are dramatising to the Government what it has done wrong and how the Australian people will not be deceived by the sort of mendacious nonsense coming from Senator Walsh on this matter.

speech.speaker: Watson Sen J.O.W.

talk.start.para: â€”The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation has come under severe criticism in recent years. Two of the heavyweights of world politics, Britain and the United States of America, have both been highly critical of this organisation and what is seen to be a lack of proper direction. In fact, the United States House of Representatives produced a very damaging report several years ago which summarised what it believed to be its major problems. The American decision on funding has highlighted some very real problems of UNESCO which are yet to be properly corrected.

speech.para: In fact, not all is well with UNESCO. It has strayed from the ideals upon which it was funded. These ideals were the exchange and broadening of education and culture throughout the world and the spread of scientific knowledge. For example, it has in the past been recognised for its gallant fight against illiteracy. Unfortunately, at present UNESCO does not have the same significance or standing as it had several years ago. Its impact has been severely diminished. One of the criticisms is that the organisation nowadays has become far too political and that it has politicised many of the issues which should, by definition, remain outside its boundaries. Many of these initiatives, of course, have nothing to do with the organisation's roles. It has also been charged with becoming inefficient and non-objective. Its headquarters are situated in Paris, where 70 per cent of its entire staff is now located. Only 30 per cent are in the field. This surely is an indictment in itself.

UNESCO must diminish the weight of its bureaucratic machine. Staff morale is another thing to suffer under the present set-up. According to a UNESCO Staff Association poll in 1983, only 13 per cent of 1,100 staff responding believed that their employer allowed them to participate satisfactorily in the management of the organisation. A major criticism levelled at UNESCO, one which is particularly damning, is that the organisation tried to interfere with the freedom of the Press some years ago. It tried to establish a system whereby journalists all over the world had to be licensed. It sought to impose government control on media content. This is quite beyond the realms of its normal jurisdiction and totally intolerable from an organisation with such goals.

Clearly, corrective action is needed to bring UNESCO back into its proper role. UNESCO must put its house in order. With staff costs accounting for something like 60 per cent of its total expenditure, this organisation must recognise and redefine its priorities. It must have good budgetary control and, most importantly, it must fill staff vacancies with the most capable people, not necessarily with people of a similar political mind.

speech.speaker: Walters Sen M.S.

talk.start.para: â€”I will not detain the chamber for more than a couple of minutes. I would just like to read into Hansard a letter I received today. It was addressed `To whom it may concern'. It is from the women and mothers of Canberra and starts by quoting Mr Hawke:

speech.para: We want to give women the opportunity to make a full contribution to Australia's development, whether they work in the home, in the paid workforce or in any other aspect of life.
We want to give women a choice, we want to give women a say, and we want to give women a fair go.
R. J. Hawke
National Agenda for Women
Office of the Status of Women.
The letter goes on:

We who are opposed to have family allowances paid at a flat rate, are coming to believe that these are empty statements. We who have made a choice to make motherhood a full-time career and therefore rely upon income derived through family allowance and the constantly threatened dependent spouse rebate, are feeling as though the present Government rather than making this choice a realistic one, are trying to reduce or remove it.

As the real value of family allowances are eaten away constantly by rapidly escalating prices, many single income families in which a woman has exercised this right to choose to remain outside the paid workforce, are struggling to maintain adequate standards of living.

And this same Government who claim that they want to give women a choice, a say, and a fair go are considering further reductions to the income available to ourselves and our families which make the choice they claim a strong commitment to, a viable one.

Does the Government mean to imply that mothers who despite financial sacrifice are still committed to the full-time care of their families, are not considered to be women and thus deserving of a choice?

Is the Government by its own actions more strongly committed to the family with one child and both parents working? After recent threats to our family budgets, does the Government still expect us to believe that they have any real intention of giving women outside the paid workforce any form of choice whatsoever?

The Government has illustrated its support for women in the paid workforce through The Office of the Status of Women, Affirmative Action Policy, C.E.S. training schemes for women re-entering the workforce, child care and the like. We demand that it also recognise our right to make our choice not only by easily made statements in the National Agenda, but by actions.

It is time that the Government demonstrated a real commitment to the families of Australia. It is time to prove to all families that they are considered to be a valuable asset and worthy of real support. It is time to prove to mothers working in the home that their freedom of choice will not be threatened by economic bullying at budget time.

We demand a definite commitment from the present Government to maintain the dependent spouse rebate, to maintain eroded family allowance payments at their present value, and rather than making empty statements to women in the home to channel their energies into the indexation of family allowances.
Give us a real choice, a real say, a real fair go!!

I give every support to the women and mothers of Canberra who have taken the trouble to express what so many people in Australia feel, not only women but also families as a whole, including the husbands. This Government has no idea of true equality. At every Budget it threatens the dependent spouse rebate and the family allowance. The women of Australia, the mothers who are choosing to stay at home and look after their children, object very strongly to this very great threat.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: â€” Senator Crichton-Browne left us in no doubt where he stood on the gold tax, but he could perhaps have spared us some of the detail, given the lateness of the hour and the existence of festivities proceeding elsewhere. He might have followed the example tonight and indeed tomorrow night of Calvin Coolidge-I think it was Calvin Coolidge; undoubtedly Barry Jones will correct me if it was not-who, on one famous occasion when asked what the sermon he had just attended was about, said: `Sin'. When he was asked what the preacher had said about sin, Coolidge replied he was against it. I commend that precedent to Senator Crichton-Browne.

speech.para: Senator Michael Baume talked about 180,000 stroke victims. I think there was a danger of there being 180,001 if he kept going any longer tonight. Mr President, you maintained your forebearance admirably. We are indebted to you in the Senate for that. From Senator Watson we had a familiar litany of complaints about the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation which seems to have become a kind of article of tory faith to espouse. I suppose Senator Walters cannot be blamed for wanting her ten inches worth in Hansard, but I only wish it had not been tonight. As to the last contribution, I only hope that the women and mothers of Canberra are happy with Senator Walters as their champion. Others might have some reservations, but this is not the time to be churlish enough to express them.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.02 p.m.

talk.start.para: â€”On 8 May 1986 (Hansard, page 2635), Senator Vanstone asked me in my capacity representing the Prime Minister a question without notice concerning the promotion of Priority One: Young Australia. I undertook to check the details of what had happened.

answer.para: The Prime Minister has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In the debate on Priority One in October 1985, the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism was referring to full page press advertisements on Priority One: Young Australia which the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism had funded. The audience for these was not only young people but the public at large including employers, unions, parents and so on.

The item under consideration in the Senate Estimates Committee was the $2m allocation to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet to continue the on-going Priority One promotion campaign commenced by the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism, to conduct the consultation with your people and to provide for follow-up activities. The press advertisements placed under this allocation were directed to young people and related to the phone-in consultation.
